IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Opioid drugs remain the most effective analgesics for the treatment of moderate and severe pain. However, chronic opioid use can cause pain hypersensitivity and the loss of their analgesic effects, which remain a major obstacle for adequate treatment of painful conditions using opioid drugs. This proposed work will identify the key molecular targets responsible for opioid-induced pain hypersensitivity and tolerance and provide new information for the design of effective strategies to improve pain treatment with opioid drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: There is a growing emphasis on and the need to utilize advances in the fields of omics, big data, and systems science to understand how the interactions between individual, micro-, meso- and macrosystems influence health and disease. We need to train nurse scientists who can utilize the skills necessary to incorporate systems science approaches to health promotion across the lifespan. With this preparation, new and innovative approaches to enhance health at the individual and population levels can be developed and tested.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biology;Nurses;Scientist;Societies;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Interdisciplinary Nurse Scientist Training in Multilevel Approaches: Biology to Society

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The InQuBATE T32 at the Georgia Institute of Technology will train PhD candidates spanning the biosciences, engineering, and computing to integrate computational models, data analytics, and the experimental study of molecules, cells, and populations. By fostering a quantitative and data-driven mindset, the T32 will train the next generation of thought leaders to identify principles underlying transitions between health and disease in complex living systems spanning microbial communities, developmental pathways, tumor microenvironments and the dynamics of tissue. Overall, InQuBATE will help transform the foundational and applied study of computational- and data-intensive biosciences in the 21st century and prepare diverse trainees for impactful careers across academia and industry.
PROJECT_TERMS: Acceleration;Biological Sciences;Environment;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Integrative and Quantitative Biosciences Accelerated Training Environment
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - B[TWD-B]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pathogenic variants in the gene KCNC1 encoding the voltage-gated potassium channel subunit KV3.1 have recently been established as a cause of neurological disease, yet the cellular, synaptic and circuit mechanisms underlying cognitive impairment and epilepsy in KCNC1-related disorders is unknown. Using a novel mouse model of KCNC1-related epileptic encephalopathy, I propose to link across scales to define the ion channel, neuronal, synaptic and circuit-basis of this devastating disorder, as well as basic roles of KV3 channels in normal physiology. This training fellowship will capitalize on my experimental strengths while addressing key gaps in my conceptual knowledge and technical skills and methodology to propel me toward my career goal to be an independent investigator committed to understanding the mechanistic basis of neurological diseases to inform novel treatment development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Left ventricular assist devices (LVADs) are increasingly used in the US to support heart function in the growing population with advanced heart failure, and they can improve length and quality of life. However, worsening or persistent kidney dysfunction after LVAD placement is common and harmful. This project seeks to understand and predict how LVADs affect kidney health, to help patients who receive LVADs achieve longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The phosphatidate phosphatase is a conserved enzyme from yeast to human that catalyzes the dephosphorylation of phosphatidate to yield diacylglycerol that is used for the synthesis of triacylglycerol and the major phospholipids phosphatidylcholine and phosphatidylethanolamine. The enzyme-mediated control of phosphatidate content plays a key role in the transcriptional regulation of phospholipid synthesis genes, membrane phospholipids, and growth of the nuclear/endoplasmic reticulum membrane. Genetic defects in yeast, mouse, and human are manifested in metabolic disorders that include obesity, lipodystrophy, peripheral neuropathy, myoglobinuria, and inflammation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Newborn brain injury is one of the most significant causes of impaired outcomes in American children, but the impacts of both excessively high and low blood sugar is surprisingly poorly understood. Using an innovative method to monitor blood glucose levels continuously, it has been discovered that more than half of newborns with encephalopathy have high blood sugar, which independently is associated with abnormalities in immediate brain function and brain injury. Understanding how specific levels of low and high glucose in the early neonatal period impact on long-term outcomes by school age will not only help with early identification of babies at greatest risk, but also tailor appropriate treatments to improve long-term outcomes in these vulnerable newborns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Horizontal gene transfer by natural transformation contributes to the rapid spread of antibiotic resistance and virulence factors. Using the cholera pathogen Vibrio cholerae as a model system, we propose to characterize the basic biology and mechanisms of natural transformation in a physiologically relevant environmental context. These studies may inform novel strategies to combat clinically relevant infections and stem the spread of antibiotic resistance and virulence in diverse bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid-alcohol polysubstance use is common and is accompanied by worsened health outcomes. There is little to no research characterizing the temporal patterns of such polysubstance use or the neuro-biobehavioral outcomes of polysubstance use. The proposed project will assess temporal patterns of opioid-alcohol polysubstance use in humans and use these data to develop rat models of polysubstance use in order to characterize its biological and cognitive consequences and thus guide development of therapies to ameliorate pathological outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The overall goal of this application is to provide Dr. Lauren Gyllenhammer support and protected time for an intensive,  supervised career development experience in the biomedical, and developmental sciences, leading to research independence. Based on a rigorous research question and methodology she has developed, Dr. Gyllenhammer will conduct  trans-disciplinary research to investigate the potential for maternal prenatal stress to potentiate the effects of maternal  insulin resistance on the development of offspring adiposity and mitochondrial health. This application describes her  academic background, training activities, research strategy and career development plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Allergic diseases afflict 40% of the United States population, but it is unknown how allergens activate dendritic cells which are required for the initiation of allergic immune responses. A research program will be undertaken to study the neuroimmune interactions that endow sensory neurons with the ability to detect allergens, and how sensory neurons and dendritic cells interact to promote the activation of the allergic immune response. These studies will provide fundamental basic immunological insights into how allergic disease is initiated and will lay the foundation to develop novel therapeutic strategies to prevent and treat allergic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A longstanding goal of retinal restoration therapies is to devise methods that enable the replacement of retinal neurons from endogenous cell sources. Embryonic retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells have a transitory ability to regenerate retinal neurons, but as RPE cells mature they lose their neural competence. The proposed study will leverage multi-modal data analysis to interrogate the molecular foundations of RPE cell identity, with the intention of recovering the regenerative potential of RPE cells at advanced stages of differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative As recreational and medical cannabis use becomes more prevalent and the strength of legal market cannabis increases, users and policy makers need timely information on the impact of current strains on cognitive function and if there are forms or potencies that minimize cognitive harm. Our global hypothesis is that the effects of cannabis on memory vary as a function of the ratio of CBD to THC (the two major cannabinoids in cannabis), with THC having adverse effects that can be counteracted by CBD. To that end, we will test the effects of cannabis strains with differing THC and CBD levels on recognition memory performance as well as event-related brain potentials (ERPs) that have previously been found to be related to different underlying memory processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of Americans suffer from chronic pain, opioid misuse, and opioid use disorder. New intervention strategies that integrate mindfulness, physical therapy, and/or medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) are needed to improve health outcomes in these vulnerable patients. To accomplish this aim, we propose the Opioid and Pain Effectiveness research Network for Mindfulness and Integrative Health Intervention Development (OPEN-MIIND), a multidisciplinary research center dedicated to addressing the opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: OVERALL Project Narrative The overall goal of this INBRE renewal application is the facilitation of quality biomedical research activities throughout the State of Louisiana with an emphasis on building research capacity and workforce development. Starting with 2016, overall operations have been re-organized to maximize effectiveness and impact by increased involvement of the PUI Steering Committee members via bi annual retreats written reports, appointment of Core Liaison Officers (CLO) representing each Core, and creation of a “Core Bucks” funding mechanism to support access to Cores for all PUI faculty. In this application, additional major changes are proposed to further improve the currently successful LBRN program, such as: expansion of the number of PUIs from seven to eight by adding the University of New Orleans (UNO) campus; expansion of undergraduate research experiences to include entire academic year, as well as summer experiences in both academic and industrial settings by soliciting additional financial support for the LBRN program from not-for-profit-institutions, as well as from for-profit institutions.

PHR: Project narrative  The Administrative Core (AC) is central to the leadership and administration of the Louisiana Biomedical  Research network (LBRN). It communicates directly with NIH program staff and is responsible for the overall  organization, management, and assessment of the Developmental Research Project Program (DRPP) and  Undergraduate Research Opportunities. The AC will oversee the cores and their interactions. The AC is led by  the Principal Investigator PI in close collaboration with the Program Coordinator (PC) and is supported by the  Directors of the two Cores Molecular and Cellular Biology Research Core (MCBRC) and the Bioinformatics  Biostatistics and Computational Biology, Core (BBCC), Steering Committee (SC) members from the primarily  undergraduate institutions (PUIs) and three other eminent scientists will assist the PI and PC with the tasks  and decisions necessary to maintain and grow the LBRN. The External Advisory Committee (EAC) will  evaluate all of the component parts of the LBRN and provide a detailed critique, to be discussed with and  acted upon by the AC. Additional assessment of the LBRN will be provided annually by the internal evaluation  team and in year 2 and 4 by an external evaluations team.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People not only form social relationships themselves, but they also form an understanding of the relationships among other people. A lack of such understanding, or inaccuracies in perception, can contribute to social isolation in the elderly or reduce a person’s ability to influence the social world around them. Understanding all this gives us new insights not only into how the human mind works, not only into certain kinds of social isolation, but also into why some people are better able to foster the diffusion of innovative public health ideas and behaviors among their social connections.

PHR: Project Narrative BIOINFORMATICS, BIOSTATISTICS, AND COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY CORE (BBCC) The LBRN Bioinformatics, Biostatistics and Computational Biology Core (BBCC) is an interdisciplinary core of biostatisticians, modelers, biocomputing scientists, software tool developers and bioinformaticians with expertise in various biomedical related research areas. This core provides training through seminars, workshops, hands-on lab specific training, and direct one-one consultation. Headquartered at the LSU Center for Computation & Technology (CCT), BBCC serves to educate, train and support project investigators and their teams across Louisiana, and to lead and support translational research activities at the frontiers of biomedical science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance Supplementing vitamin B3 derivatives to increase nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) has recently shown promise in preclinical studies as a potential treatment for heart failure. However, this promise is based on a dosing strategy that may not be feasible in humans and much remains to be learned about the metabolism, mechanisms of action, and therapeutic potential of these molecules at doses that can be tolerated. The grant explores each of these questions using innovative surgical models, genetics, and state of the art mass spectrometry techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Fractures due to osteoporosis remain a major health concern that drastically hinders the quality of life, especially among the elderly, and incurs large medical costs. To facilitate the development of new clinical tools that assess the contribution of bone matrix quality to fracture risk and the identification of new mechanisms involved in bone fragility, this project will ascertain whether non-enzymatic post-translational modifications (NE-PTMs) of collagen are predictors of poor fracture resistance of human bone and whether their levels are specifically greater in those with osteoporosis than individuals without the disease. Furthermore, by employing matrix manipulation studies and molecular modeling, we will assess the effect of non-crosslinking vs. crosslinking NE-PTMs on fracture resistance and identify a mechanism by which NE-PTMs affect collagen structure and hydration, respectively.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative In opioid use disorders (OUDs), withdrawal from chronic opioids is characterized by a negative affective state that enhances the risk of relapse and overdose, however underlying circuit mechanisms remain elusive. Here we focus on the habenula, a known brain aversion center. We hypothesize that neurons of the habenula, which express the mu opioid receptor (MOR), are key to aversive emotional states of morphine withdrawal. We combine opto/chemogenetics in a novel MOR-Cre line with behavioral paradigms of short- & long-term morphine withdrawal and cutting-edge animal MRI to investigate a novel circuit hypothesis, which we think relevant to OUDs 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the role of social media platforms and their underlying algorithms in surfacing common mispercep- tions surrounding medication assisted treatment (MAT) for opioid use disorder (OUD) is key towards sustained recovery. By leveraging robust audit methodologies to investigate algorithmic pathways of MAT misinformation (MATM), coupled with machine learning techniques to detect the prevalence of MATM on Twitter, this project will conduct mixed methods evaluations of the developed computational artifacts relating to an hitherto unexplored- but-significant phenomenon in the OUD medication and treatment domain. The research will shine new light on the relation between an individual’s online information environment and risky OUD behavior, and offer formative insights to initiate evidence-based interventions to reduce such risks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chikungunya is an emerging vector-borne virus that is becoming endemic in the Americas. Using experimental evolution and functional genetic approaches, we will explore the relative importance of genetic diversity for virus transmission and the evolution of resistance to viruses in mosquitoes. Our project will inform strategies for developing broad-spectrum, virus-resistant mosquitoes via genetic modification, and for developing epidemiological risk maps for chikungunya globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell therapies have the potential to revolutionize disease treatment, but require more complex, variable and costly production methods. The main goal of this project is develop aptamer-based technologies for traceless cell selection in manufacturing of cell therapies. We anticipate that the proposed research will lead to next generation technologies relevant for scalable and more affordable production of CAR T cell immunotherapy, monocyte-based cell therapies and stem cell treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Molecular chirality is at the heart of biological function, disease and development. While vibrational circular dichroism (VCD) can precisely measure molecular chirality and, consequently, molecular structure, available instrumentation can only record data from bulk samples. This instrument development project seeks to develop a prototype, termed VCD imaging microscope or VIM, to record chirality from microscopically heterogeneous biomedical samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Adolescent alcohol abuse causes progressive neurodegeneration that parallels Alzheimer’s disease-related pathology, including chronic neuroinflammation, persistent degeneration of basal forebrain cholinergic neurons, hippocampal neurodegeneration, and lasting cognitive deficits. The proposed studies will investigate adolescent alcohol abuse as a novel etiological factor priming and accelerating progression of basal forebrain and hippocampal neurodegeneration with age to Alzheimer’s disease. Prevention studies will link adolescent neuroinflammation and cholinergic degeneration to age-related neurodegeneration and cognitive deficits observed in human Alzheimer’s disease and provide new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Ceramides are products of fat and protein metabolism that accumulate in individuals with obesity or dyslipidemia. Herein we investigate their contribution to cancers in the gastrointestinal tract by dissecting their impact on the ability of intestinal stem cells to use nutrients and proliferate. The work could uncover new therapeutic approaches for combating gastrointestinal cancers associated with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We focus on studying non-canonical forms of coding (temporal coding and “analog” coding) to delineate the molecular, biophysical, and circuit mechanisms that underlie neural coding and behavior. We have identified 2 neural circuits in Drosophila that allow for exquisite experimental control and where the impact of temporal pattern codes or analog codes on both target neuron physiology and animal behavior can be rigorously investigated. This study will contribute to the understanding of the fundamental principles that underlie how neural codes generate neurophysiological signals and behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infectious pneumonia remains an urgent public health threat, causing millions of worldwide deaths each year and leading to chronic pulmonary and extrapulmonary complications in many survivors. The discovery that therapeutic manipulation of lung epithelial antimicrobial responses can robustly protect hosts against an expansive array of bacterial, viral and fungal pathogens despite impairment of leukocyte function offers a novel opportunity to protect vulnerable populations against these outcomes. This proposal supports a program investigating the mechanisms underlying the unique synergistic signaling events that drive protection, the effector molecules that yield staggeringly broad protection, and the regulatory events that promote durable protection, so that this protective phenomenon can be translated to maximally protect susceptible patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Energy failure, or insufficient energy to support normal function, can lead to a wide range of diseases of aging including neurodegenerative and heart diseases, but we do not know how to treat it. In this proposal, we will define the most robust mechanisms by which cells regulate their energy levels, and determine if targeting these boosts the function and survival of human cells that are susceptible to diseases of energy failure. These studies will determine how to most effectively increase cellular energy levels, and begin to assess the therapeutic potential of increasing energy in diseases of energy failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Immunoglobulin A (IgA) antibodies are prominently secreted in the intestines and coat a fraction of the intestinal bacterial microbiota. Nothing is currently known about the potential involvement of IgA antibody responses in control of and immunity to intestinal fungal microbiota (mycobiota) coexisting with bacteria at this body site. Here we will study the role of IgA antibodies in immunity against specific intestinal fungi and virulence factors by these organisms to determine if these antibodies can protect the intestines against fungi-fueled inflammation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While individuals with epilepsy are often diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and anxiety disorders, the underlying neurobiological reasons for this co-occurrence are poorly defined. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Macrophages and fibroblast-like synoviocytes (FLS) are cells present in inflamed joints that have been implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The long-term goals of this project are to understand how cytokines and inflammatory factors expressed in RA joints (synovium) activate these cells to drive inflammation and the disease process. This project will investigate how signaling pathways activated in RA synovium regulate macrophage inflammatory responses to gain knowledge that can be used to increase anti-inflammatory signaling and more effectively treat patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to dissect the mechanisms of protection against Shigella dysentery by studying the evolution of naturally acquired immunity in a longitudinal mother-infant cohort from Malawi; we will interrogate the biophysical and functional properties of maternal antibodies in sera and breast milk and immunity in infants from birth to 2 years of age. Naturally acquired antibodies will also be monitored longitudinally in a cohort of Malawian children 2-5 years of age. The research proposed is novel and has the potential to identify immune components associated with protective immunity in children, which can inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics for the most vulnerable.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Because antiretroviral therapy alone is unlikely to end the morbidity and mortality associated with mother- to-child transmission of HIV, there is considerable interest in developing immune-based interventions to combat perinatal HIV infection. Here we will use the pediatric rhesus macaque model of HIV/AIDS to assess whether gene therapy with the antibody-like entry inhibitor eCD4-Ig can protect infants from immunodeficiency virus acquisition and treat an established infection. If successful, the proposed research will establish the pre-clinical foundation for using gene therapy as prophylaxis and therapy for perinatal HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative – OVERALL We propose the first Center for Perioperative Mental Health. We will focus on improving the mental healthcare of older adults undergoing surgery and other invasive procedures. The integration of mental healthcare into perioperative care could improve depression, anxiety, and quality of life. This Center has the potential for substantial public health impact by revolutionizing the approach to perioperative care, based on firm evidence and clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project proposes to contribute toward identifying risk factors and elucidating their subcellular and cellular underpinnings for developing Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (AD/ADRD). Identifying and investigating factors that increase risk for AD/ADRD is important, not only because it may guide us toward uncovering new biological mechanisms underlying AD/ADRD but also because it could help identify those individuals with high risk for developing it. In this proposal, we leverage our expertise and experience in studying brain development, employing a combination of neuroanatomical, electrophysiological and behavioral approaches to test the novel hypothesis that prenatal alcohol exposure early in gestation is a risk factor that predisposes the progeny to developing cognitive impairments that could lead to AD/ADRD later in life. We expect the findings of this project to point to new vistas and spawn new directions of investigation that will increase our understanding of prenatal alcohol exposure as a prospective risk factor for developing AD/ADRD and enhance our ability to predict and manage the development of AD at its early stages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Trauma and surgical sepsis frequently lead to death and/or persistent critical illness, however there are no targeted therapies to improve outcomes. With advances in technologies, we can now measure changes in gene and protein expression in thousands of cells at the single cell level and at the same time measure levels of thousands of biomolecules in the circulation. We will continue to apply these technologies to the study of trauma and sepsis to identify predictive biomarkers and identify novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Radiation therapy has many benefits that explain its widespread use, but its curative potential is limited by the induction of toxicity in the tissues surrounding the tumor. This project aims to improve the efficacy of radiation therapy by combining it with high-intensity focused ultrasound. The hypothesis underpinning this scheme is that ionizing radiation nucleates nanosized gas bubbles, which would enhance cell killing through ultrasound cavitation effects.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Comprising a significant proportion of the global health workforce, nurses are uniquely positioned to develop and lead research to understand population health problems, inform health interventions, optimize health systems, and promote health within communities and across populations. The Research in Nursing and Global Health (RiNGH) training program aims to prepare junior nurse scientists with the knowledge and skills to advance global health equity through team-based, interdisciplinary research. This training will provide enhanced education, scholarly mentorship, and career development to pre-doctoral and post-doctoral trainees in nursing science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Neutrophil recruitment to sites of injury is critical for host defense, however neutrophil activity in tissue can also lead to exacerbated inflammation and tissue injury. Our work suggests that neutrophil recruitment in inflamed mucosa is regulated via synergistic interactions of vascular endothelial cells and tissue macrophages. Thus, proposed studies will investigate new mechanistic aspects of macrophage effector function and their interactions with endothelial cells to regulate neutrophil trafficking in inflamed mucosa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Based on data from our lab and other labs, it has recently been suggested that transformation from castrate resistant prostate cancer (CRPC toward neuroendocrine prostate cancer (NEPC), a lethal form of prostate cancer, is associated with epithelial plasticity and induced by either N-Myc induction or RB1 loss. Currently, the synergy between MYCN induction and RB1 loss to drive progression to NEPC through the induction of DNA methylation proteins and methylation program are clinical unmet needs. Our multidisciplinary project, which builds on extensive and validated preliminary data, will provide insight and clinical rationale for treatment decisions and for patient selection for appropriate therapies, a step towards personalized cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of the Building Access to Food through Systems and Solidarity (BASIS) Study is to improve diet by  providing culturally appropriate food access and attending to drivers that limit the ability to achieve nutrition  security in Sunset Park – a community of Mexican and Chinese American families in Brooklyn, NY that has been  hard-hit during the COVID-19 pandemic, has lagged in economic recovery, and where residents are  disconnected from government supports. We aim to implement and evaluate a whole-of-community intervention that will prioritize sustainability in the long-term, in partnership with four farming/gardening organizations, one  elementary school and three community-based organizations with programmatic offerings that will include  linkage to federal, state and local aid and workforce development; a subsidized fresh produce box program,  gardening and nutrition education; and a social marketing campaign to promote healthy eating. BASIS presents  a powerful model to improve diet in immigrant communities by addressing determinants of food access in a  community-centered, culturally competent way, and by fortifying community empowerment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite their importance for every aspect of reproduction, the somatic tissues of the Drosophila female reproductive tract are relatively understudied. This work will use single-cell RNA- sequencing of mated and unmated females from two diverged natural populations to characterize reproductive tract cell diversity and gene expression evolution for the first time. Next, a set of reproductive tract genes will be knocked out and evaluated for reproductive function, including a) receptors in the seminal receptacle which may mediate the female post- mating response and b) newly-originated genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study addresses our gap in understanding how the early life human gut microbiome responds to diet and antibiotics, including impacts on functional maturation and horizontal gene transfer of antibiotic resistance. This research is relevant for public health because it will improve our understanding of the effects of antibiotics and diet on microbiome dynamics beyond the coarse level of microbial communities and establish predictive models for future personalized antibiotic treatment and dietary recommendations that minimize collateral damage and maximize development of the healthy infant microbiome. By complementing data from two unique human cohorts with hypothesis testing in a mouse model this project is relevant to the NIH's mission of leveraging basic research in mechanisms of health and disease to improve outcomes in treatment and maintenance of human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals experiencing financial strain (i.e., an inability to meet basic financial needs) may be more likely to use substances as a coping mechanism for the stress associated with financial strain, but they may also be eligible for financial support from anti-poverty programs such as the federal Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC). The few studies that have examined the relationship between financial strain and substance use have largely focused on alcohol and on acute financial strain due to sudden job or income changes, and have not explored whether financial support from federal policies such as EITC affect this relationship. Using 2013-2019 data from the Population Assessment of Tobacco and Health study, this project will examine: 1) whether financial strain is associated with cannabis, CNS depressant, alcohol, or polysubstance use, 2) how the duration of financial stain (i.e., acute financial strain due to sudden job or income loss, chronic financial strain due to persistent deprivation, and intermittent financial strain due to repeated economic insecurity) affects substance use, and 3) if financial support offered by the federal EITC may lower the risk of financial strain and subsequent substance use.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of this project is to understand how quantity and quality of the language input directed to children by their caregivers is influenced by genetically-influenced child characteristics of language and temperament. The overarching activity of this research project is transcription, coding, and analysis of naturalistic parent-child interactions that have been collected as part of a longitudinal study of over 300 same- sex twin pairs and their parents. The knowledge gained will reveal how child factors contribute to the parental language input children receive and the longitudinal consequences of this relationship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is the leading cause of cancer deaths in both men and women in the United States. This proposal aims to study an orally available inhibitor of the ATPases RUVBL1 and RUVBL2 as a radiosensitizer and immune stimulator for cancer therapy. If successful, this work may provide the framework for developing a combination therapy that enhances the efficacy of both radiotherapy and immune checkpoint inhibitors, which are currently used for treatment of patients with NSCLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This study proposes to develop robust methods for analysis in one step of coenzymes and antioxidants that are fundamental to the functioning of all living cells and their abnormal levels are associated with numerous diseases including cancer, heart failure, diabetes, and obesity. Owing to the extremely unstable nature of these molecules, conventional analysis methods are suboptimal and lead to inaccurate and misleading outcomes in the assessment of cellular functions. Our ability to reliably measure the unstable metabolites in one step based on the outcome of the current investigations impacts numerous areas of biomedical science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a major public health problem, and is responsible for 1.7 million emergency department visits, hospitalizations, and deaths annually in the United States. This research will produce key mechanistic and outcomes data to understand the impact of autonomic dysfunction following severe TBI, and guide future trials aiming to modulate autonomic function following severe TBI. In doing this, the burden of poor neurologic outcomes following severe TBI could be reduced.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: General anesthetics (GAs) are used for hundreds of millions of surgeries each year, but growing evidence suggests that they may induce neurobehavioral deficits not only in the exposed subjects, but also in their offspring. These proposed studies in rodents are designed to test our new hypotheses on the underlying mechanisms, behavioral, neuroendocrine and transcriptomic blood-based biomarkers, and potential targets for pharmacological therapies of the heritable effects of GAs. This study will draw attention to the urgent need to investigate the heritable effects of GAs in humans and will build a foundation for such studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Good quality sleep is essential for mental health as sleep has many beneficial and restorative effects like improving attention, working memory, emotional health, and clearing metabolic waste products. Conversely, insufficient sleep caused by stressful events markedly disrupts cognitive and emotional function, but little is known about how stress alters neural sleep circuitry. This proposal will reveal how sleep- and wake-active nuclei interact with stress-regulatory brain regions in order to elucidate neural circuit mechanisms underlying sleep homeostasis after chronic stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of fungal infections has risen dramatically in the United States over the last 15 years, and is now among the top 10 causes of death, partly because we lack novel and effective therapeutic drugs against fungi. To address this unmet medical need, we are working on understanding how the host senses and effectively restrains fungal growth. The knowledge gained will lead to the development of new and better strategies to therapeutically treat microbial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The perinatal period, defined as the time period during pregnancy and up to one year postpartum, is a vulnerable period for women affected by opioid use disorder, and which may be compounded by loneliness and social isolation leading to an increased risk of relapse, overdose, and even death. Despite recent advances in telehealth programs for postpartum women and for individuals with substance use disorders, no current treatment models exist to integrate maternal perinatal and OUD treatment with an emphasis on loneliness and social isolation. In order to adapt an existing supportive texting chatbot to decrease feelings of loneliness and increase engagement in OUD and perinatal care, we now embark on a study utilizing steps from intervention mapping to identify needs of perinatal women with OUD, develop new content appropriate to our target population, refine the accuracy of the content and messaging, and test the feasibility and acceptability of our new model, the Penny COPILOT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Antibiotics are widely used to treat human infections. However, in addition to targeting the intended pathogen, the top prescribed antibiotics also disrupt the healthy human microbiome, increasing susceptibility to various diseases. We propose to explore natural product peptides that selectively antagonize the activity of broad- spectrum antibiotics as a strategy to minimize this collateral damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Methods for evaluating the fate of single virions have led to a wealth of information on disease states but have been primarily limited to surface studies and artificial culture environments. This work will develop and apply high-speed 3D single-virus tracking methods to capture how viruses such as influenza and SARS-CoV-2 navigate the complex epithelial space. Outcomes from this work will shed light on the mechanisms through which virions traverse the first line of defense of the human immune system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart, lung and blood related diseases are leading causes of death in the US and around the world. Understanding the sex-specific genetic architecture for the risk factors for these traits in diverse populations (e.g. tobacco and alcohol use, lipids levels, obesity, etc) can aid in the discovery of the underlying biology, inform preventive strategies, and improve risk prediction, which are of great public health relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Using our cadre of 190 USW, CWA, immigrant worker center and Tribal trainers we will provide HAZMAT, HAZWOPER and related OSHA training to those who produce, work with, dispose of and transport billions of pounds of hazardous substances and wastes. Our target populations are 1) high hazard unionized workers, especially those who must respond to emergencies; 2) immigrant day laborers who are hired from street corners to engage in clean up and (re)construction activities; and 3) Tribal members who must respond to a growing number of toxic spills and weather-related disasters on their lands. Our mission is to bring high quality model education to thousands of workers who currently receive insufficient training on the hazards they face so that at-risk workers can better protect themselves, their co-workers and their communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is directly relevant to public health because it will uncover key neurodevelopmentally- regulated neural circuit mechanisms that enable the maturation of the prefrontal cortex during adolescence and the neurobiology that renders this developmental period susceptible for the onset of psychiatric disorders. This goal is directly aligned with the NIMH agenda by establishing a developmental framework in which mental disorders can be understood, specifically those arising during the adolescent transition to adulthood. This knowledge is expected to fully serve NIH mission by devising the proper timing of intervention strategies to prevent or mitigate the onset of mental disorders during critical periods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis, a particularly deadly form of heart failure, can now be treated by recently developed medications. The proposed projects will develop new heart imaging approaches to determine who is likely to respond to the new medicines, test a new ultrasound-based therapy to improve blood flow to the heart muscle and thereby improve delivery of novel drugs to the heart, and study bacteria in the stool with the goal of eventually developing diet-based strategies to address cardiac amyloidosis. In developing methods to improve treatments for amyloidosis, this project will support expansion of Dr. Dorbala’s patient oriented research program and enhance training for her mentees.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The major goal of this ongoing, successful training program is to provide microbiology trainees additional knowledge in infectious diseases and the skills to recognize opportunities for translation of new knowledge into clinical applications. An optimal environment is provided for (1) training in the latest concepts and techniques of microbiology research, (2) enhancing understanding of current challenges in infectious diseases, and (3) preparation for careers that influence research efforts that lead to more rapid resolution of important infectious disease problems. The program will continue to recruit highly qualified trainees from underrepresented groups, increasing the diversity of scientists performing research at the cutting edge of the microbiology/infectious disease interface.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: In this proposal, we aim to define how cells in the blood vessels in the lung communicate with each other and promotes the development of a deadly yet mysterious disease, pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). In doing so, we will test a new inhaled drug therapy for this disease, and we will embark on a first-in-human study to define a new imaging technique for better detection of PAH. If successful, our work could shape the principles of how PAH develops, offering much needed and more effective ways to detect and treat this deadly condition.

PHR: Project Narrative  This project aims at generalizing the LIBRA-seq technology for high-throughput mapping of antibody sequence to antigen specificity to make it universally applicable to a broad diversity of antigen targets, in the context of a wide range of antibody discovery problems. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lupus is one of the top 10 leading causes of non-accidental death in adolescent females. Children and adolescents with lupus develop early blood vessel injury that significantly increases their risk of early heart attacks and strokes in adulthood. We currently do not know how to monitor or prevent these changes in childhood-onset lupus, which is more severe and confers greater cumulative tissue damage than adult-onset lupus. The proposed project seeks to determine whether blood pressure patterns and blood vessel function can be used to evaluate vascular health in children with lupus, and to assess whether medications used to prevent heart disease in other conditions may be beneficial in adolescents and young adults with lupus.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Visual speech is helpful in real-world environments when access to acoustic speech is reduced by hearing loss. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Surgeons play a major role in the treatment of gastrointestinal (GI) diseases and it is imperative that surgeons remain at the forefront of the creation of new knowledge in the field. Given the rapidly changing approaches to biomedical research and the difficult funding environment, this T32 Program has been designed to provide the skills and experience to young surgeon-trainees so that they can pursue successful careers in surgical investigation. We are particularly focused on coalescing a faculty from a wide range of fields to bear on important GI surgical issues, such that our trainees understand the broad array of techniques and approaches available to answer clinically relevant research questions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) Complement proteins are implicated in immune hyperactivation during severe COVID-19, but underlying mechanisms are unclear. By leveraging diverse approaches in vitro and in vivo, this project explores a new role for complement membrane attack complexes (MACs) as alarmins activating inflammatory signaling. Our studies introduce a new paradigm for understanding MAC-related immunity in severe COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The absorption of dietary lipids and their transport to the circulation is essential for the maintenance of whole-body lipid metabolism and energy homeostasis; however, elevated postprandial plasma lipid, specifically triacylglyceride (TAG), is a significant independent risk factor for cardiovascular disease. This project will provide mechanistic insight into a newly discovered role for the protein DENND5B in the absorption of dietary TAG and its impact on cardiometabolic health. The overall objective of this proposal is to gain fundamental knowledge about the process of dietary lipid absorption by the intestine and its impact on metabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: United World Antiviral Research Network (UWARN) will address emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases by carrying out research on arboviruses, viruses transmitted by arthropods to humans, with collaborating partner research laboratories in Brazil, Pakistan, Senegal, South Africa and Taiwan. The research will develop innovative new diagnostic reagents, namely human viral-neutralizing antibodies and designed proteins that release light when antibodies to virus are present in blood. UWARN research will also improve understanding of how viruses manipulate the human immune system, facilitating development of better biomarkers to predict severe disease as well as host-directed therapies that could improve outcomes of viral infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Mycobacterium tuberculosis infections require long and onerous treatment: antibiotic regimens that could clear infections more quickly would improve patient outcomes. This proposal seeks to determine how Mtb battens down the hatches of its cell wall during stress, thus increasing antibiotic tolerance. This work will characterize some of the molecular mechanisms responsible for treatment recalcitrance in Mtb, and will lay the foundation for future screens for anti-tolerance drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: U-RISE at Sacramento State Program Narrative Even after decades of efforts to increase diversity and inclusion in the sciences, technological, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields, national data continue to show low representation of individuals from diverse ethnic and racial groups in the workforce. In addition, the low retention and proportion of degrees awarded to individuals from historically underrepresented and marginalized groups directly affect the Nation’s ability to produce a diverse and inclusive STEM workforce. U-RISE at Sacramento State will contribute to addressing these concerns by training talented students from groups historically excluded in the sciences for success, service and leadership, while increasing the number of individuals from underrepresented groups who pursue graduate degrees as biomedical scientists.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal requests a new small-animal positron emission and computed tomography (PET/CT) to support translational, disease-focused, and basic science molecular imaging research at Emory University. The current Inveon PET/CT system at Emory University is obsolete and at high risk of becoming inoperable due to service and parts discontinuation of the manufacturer. The new system will be operated and managed through the Center for Systems Imaging Core and continues to support innovative and NIH-funded preclinical molecular imaging development in the study of neurology, cardiology, oncology and infectious diseases in the greater Atlanta area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Our NIDDK T32 Training Program “Developing Pediatric Endocrinologists and Diabetes Psychologists for the Future” will be conducted at the Barbara Davis Center for Childhood Diabetes, University of Colorado School of Medicine and Children’s Hospital Colorado, Anschutz Medical Campus. Our PRINCIPAL OBJECTIVE is to develop Pediatric Endocrinologists and Psychologists who are well grounded in basic and/or translational science research skills required for advancing the field of knowledge in type 1 and type 2 diabetes and are educated in collaborative and integrated approaches for translating basic discoveries in diabetes into opportunities for advancing clinical research and care. Our OVERALL GOAL is that after their training, our trainees will have acquired the professional skills to become clinician scientists beginning productive academic careers as junior faculty investigators who will have the leadership capacity to make significant impacts in the fields of type 1 and type 2 diabetes in children and adolescents.

Mentored early research training experiences influence career choices and increase the likelihood of trainees to pursue medical careers in research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bidirectional crosstalk between sensory neurons and immune cells is central for integrating a wide range of signals, promoting responses against noxious stimuli while preventing exacerbated responses against benign stimuli. Dysregulation of this balance can lead to maladaptive responses culminating in chronic conditions involving inflammation, pain and itch. This study seeks to probe neuro-immune interactions that promote tissue homeostasis, which may result in novel therapies for chronic conditions involving pain, itch and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Musculoskeletal diseases are some of the most common reasons why people of all ages visit a doctor and are leading causes of disability around the globe. In the United States, 1 of every 7 people reports a musculoskeletal impairment and musculoskeletal conditions cost our society an estimated $269.3B every year. The prevalence of musculoskeletal conditions will continue to escalate in the next 20 years as the population ages. This trans- disciplinary program provides focused training to a new generation of biomedical researchers and physicians who will advance the science and treatment of arthritis and musculoskeletal diseases.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Investigative Hepatology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Research innovations in the field of child mental health conducted by specially trained clinician- scientists are desperately needed to adequately respond to the unprecedented youth mental health crisis in the United States. This T32 training program will build upon previous success in recruiting, engaging, and mentoring a diverse group of scientists who can advance the field in order to reduce the burden of child mental disorders. The program is designed to target current priorities in child mental health research, including: improving our understanding of pathogenesis, course and treatment of child mental health disorders; enhancing health equity; utilizing technological advances to enhance knowledge and care; and partnering with communities in the conduct of research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neither conventional preclinical models using rodents nor simple human stem cell models using pain-sensing nociceptors capture the complexity of human pain circuits. This hampers the discovery of solutions for treatment of chronic pain, which may potentially target multiple cell types (including both neurons and supporting glia), localized cell populations with distinct positional identities and/or the environment where these pain networks reside. This proposal will develop advanced human stem cell tools that will establish region- specific cells, circuits, and tissues, enhancing our fundamental understanding of human pain networks along the body axis and accelerating the creation of accurate models that can be used for high throughput drug screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autoimmune disorders affect millions of people worldwide and impose a significant burden on society, given the age groups they affect and their chronic nature. Current treatments either do not impact certain autoimmune diseases or are associated with significant adverse effects due to eliminating both pathogenic and protective immune cells. The Johns Hopkins Autoimmunity Center of Excellence will perform clinical trials in patients with multiple sclerosis and myositis, in addition to a collaborative project in participants with neuromyelitis optica (NMO) and myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody disease (MOGAD) with the goal of improving our understanding of the specific immune cell subsets driving these disease processes and ultimately identifying novel targeted treatment approaches for autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Drug use is the leading cause of preventable death in the United States. There is an urgent national need to equip the next generation of predoctoral addiction researchers with the expertise, tools, and techniques necessary to advance discovery science and accelerate development of therapeutics to address drug addiction. This grant describes a robust interdisciplinary training program, TRAIN@wayne, uniquely focused on the translational study of addiction neurobiology and exposure to state-of-the-art research methods and rigorous experimental design, complemented by robust career development and individualized mentorship.
PI_NAMEs: CONTI, ALANA C.;GREENWALD, MARK K (contact);LEDGERWOOD, DAVID M

PROJECT_TITLE: TRAIN@wayne: Translational Research in Addiction and Integrative Neuroscience
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Career Development Education and Training Study Section[NIDA-K]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative For a complex organ like heart that harbors large number of different cell types, a coordinated communication between individual cells is of paramount importance for efficient functioning of the heart. Extracellular vesicles or exosomes, small vesicles secreted by most cells are important mediator of cell to cell communication both within heart and with other cells/organs at long distance. This program will comprehensively characterize how after heart injury individual cell- derived exosomes communicate with other cells in heart and at long distance and how these communications affect overall heart repair after injury and hopefully will identify new mechanisms and therapeutic targets to enhance heart repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exosome are tiny vesicles secreted by most cardiac cells and are key mediators of cell to cell communication by transferring donor cell molecular cargo to recipient cells. Exosome are loaded with proteins, mRNAs and microRNAs that are specific to the parent cells and regulate molecular processes once delivered to target cell types. Therefore this core is essential for isolation, characterization, and analysis of exosome contents from different sources that will be utilized by all three scientific projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the Physiology and Surgical Core (Core C) is to support all projects by providing expertise to carry out numerous experimental approaches to examine cardiac physiology and pathology in the intact animal. These services will provide the backbone for the major focus of this Program Project Grant to determine exosome-mediated cell-cell communication both locally within the injured myocardium and distally with other organs and how these intracellular and inter-organ communications influence overall myocardial responses to injury and the repair process. Understanding these very important processes we hope will lead to the development of new treatments for heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cell-cell communication is key component of cardiac injury and repair. This project aims to understand the role of extracellular vesicles from injured cardiac muscle cells in communicating with resident endothelial cells and bone marrow progenitor cells and the consequence of this communication on the angiogenesis after myocardial infarction. Data obtained from proposed studies may potentially be crucial in understanding new mechanisms of ischemic heart injury and repair processes and potentially identification of new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 2 (Koch) Narrative (relevance): Elucidating novel roles for GRK2 and adrenergic regulation of secreted extra-cellular vesicles (EVs) and exosomes from myocytes and how this leads to changes in the secretome during heart failure and metabolic disorders will be critical to gain increased understanding of these disease processes. It is clear that the cardiac secretome (signals/factors released from the heart) can affect neighboring heart cells as well as distant organs such as fat cells and some of these crucial factors are packaged in EV/exosomes and levels of GRK2, which can be induced by stressors including ischemia and high fat diet, can alter what is secreted. Working with this PPG group will lead to elucidation of novel communicative signals between heart and fat that can lead to novel therapeutic targets not only for heart failure but also potentially for obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Acute ischemic injury, such as myocardial infarction (MI), is a major contributor toward the development of heart failure (HF), a progressive disease affecting millions of patients and costing billions of dollars annually. Myeloid cells are rapidly recruited to or activated within the heart following acute injury or stress where their regulation of cardiac function and remodeling are sensitive to β2-adrenergic receptor (β2AR) activity. The goal of this project is to define how myeloid cell-expressed β2AR regulates cardiac function and remodeling after injury and whether β2AR-selective therapeutics can regulate the myeloid cell-specific impact on injury.

PHR: NARRATIVE This T32 training program in the Environmental Health Sciences and Toxicology is designed to assure that trainees gain the skills they need to develop as successful independent, transdisciplinary, ethically engaged environmental health researchers and practitioners. It builds upon our unique focus on exposome research and affords trainees the opportunities to gain a holistic and rigorous knowledge-base, perform innovative research, and gain skills to excel in careers addressing significant public health challenges related to environmental exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative OVERALL; PD – Pascual, V. A major problem in the field of human autoimmunity is the diversity of clinical manifestations and pathways leading to disease. The ACE at Weill Cornell Medicine aims to 1) better understand pathways and mechanisms that contribute to development and amplification of Human Systemic Autoimmune Diseases, 2) develop tools and identify biomarkers to monitor these pathways in patients, and 3) share expertise with colleagues across all basic and clinical ACE Programs.The proposed Center will employ state-of-the-art technologies to gain insight into how two major and complementary compartments contribute to systemic disease: Immune cells and extra- cellular nanoparticles that can modulate the function of cells that uptake them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human autoimmune diseases comprise a large number of conditions including systemic diseases such as Lupus or Rheumatoid Arthritis and organ-specific diseases such as Type 1 Diabetes and Multiple Sclerosis. To understand this complexity, there is a need to continue the multidisciplinary work that has been fostered by the Autoimmunity Centers of Excellence Network over the last 25 years. The Emory Autoimmunity Center of Excellence will continue our work in Lupus while collaborating with other ACE Centers in the study of other autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autoimmune diseases afflict up to 12% of the US population and remain a common cause of morbidity and early mortality. Non-toxic, effective therapeutics often do not exist. This program focuses on identifying molecular homogeneous subsets of patients to aid trials, inform treatment and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OVERALL: Targeting Cellular Senescence to Extend Healthspan—NARRATIVE In this Program Project Grant renewal application (Targeting Cellular Senescence to Extend Healthspan), our overall goal is to build a firm foundation of multidisciplinary discovery science in cellular senescence that leads to a pipeline of therapeutic strategies that slow or prevent age-associated diseases. Using a highly integrated approach across 3 Projects and 4 Cores, our work aims to provide fundamental insights into the mechanisms of cellular senescence and aging across bone, muscle, and brain; understand potential communications between these tissues in driving age-related dysfunction; and develop new drugs targeting cellular senescence and benefitting multiple aging tissues simultaneously.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) Autoimmune endocrinopathies affects a large number of Americans- ~20 million are affected by thyroiditis, and 1.45 million are affected by Type 1 Diabetes. Despite this, immunotherapies are not the first-line treatment for this immune-mediated condition, and autoimmune endocrinopathies have not been a focus of previous ACEs. This proposal will define immune mechanisms that drive long-term autoimmunity seen in autoimmune endocrinopathies that will lead to identification of targets for new immunotherapies to benefit patients.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative This FDA Vet-LIRN Cooperative Agreement Program will strengthen collaborative efforts among Federal, State and local resources to promote animal health and increase food safety and security efforts. This program will bolster laboratory testing by advancing methodologies used to detect animal food for adulterants and contaminants, protecting both food and companion animals and public health.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: FDA Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network Cooperative Agreement Program

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative This goal of this application is to enhance the veterinary diagnostic capacity and capabilities of Animal Disease Research and Diagnostic Laboratory (ADRDL), South Dakota in support of improving the national food safety system. This project will allow ADRDL to participate in Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network (Vet-LIRN). Through this program, ADRDL will serve as a regional sequencing lab and also will perform diagnostic testing as required by Vet-LIRN.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Strengthening national food safety system by improving veterinary diagnostics

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative: The VDL will support the Vet-LIRN through participation in FDA/Vet-LIRN sample analysis in the event of an animal food/feed contamination event, providing analytical data to FDA for potential regulatory use, and participation in additional projects, i.e. method development and validation as determined and directed by the VPO. The VDL will maintain its infrastructure for diagnosis of bacterial contamination in order to provide this support.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: UMN VDL Infrastructure Support to Build and Support Capacity to Respond to Animal Foodborne Outbreaks

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Vet-LIRN Project Narrative- Feb., 2022 The Oregon Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory (OVDL) wishes to continue its collaboration with the Food and Drug Administration Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network (Vet-LIRN) wherein the OVDL will provide sample analysis, analytical data for regulatory use, and support for small scale method development and validation. These veterinary diagnostic testing activities support the Vet-LIRN’s objectives of facilitating early detection of animal food/drug adulteration or contamination as a component of the FDA’s overall responsibilities in these endeavors. Surveillance and testing for feed contamination in our animal populations promotes public health by protecting our nation’s food supply as well and our companion animals.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Vet-LIRN

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Virus-associated malignancies may account for an estimated 15 percent of all human cancers worldwide, which represents a significant component of the global cancer burden. Both HIV and EBV have documented associations with a number of malignancies and people living with HIV are at a higher risk of developing cancer despite antiretroviral treatments. This study aims to identify and characterize novel interactions between exogenous viral factors and endogenous retroviral oncogenes that play an essential role in virus-associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study is timely as its findings have the potential to address the concerns recently raised regarding the lack of clarity on managing pregnant women with blood pressure levels in the ranges of lower thresholds according to the 2017 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guidelines. The findings may also inform early clinical triage strategies and risk stratification of women with combinations of blood pressure categories in pregnancy and comorbid obesity and diabetes. The public health consequences of this study are enormous, given that the pregnancy and postpartum periods significantly impact long-term health of both women and their offspring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Transmissible vaccines are being widely considered to control zoonotic diseases in animal populations, including Ebola, Marburg, Sin Nombre hantavirus, and rabies. However, before transmissible vaccines are introduced, the benefits and risks must be considered. This study will provide the first empirical estimate of how well a transmissible vaccine spreads, and it will determine whether adverse evolution has occurred due to the widespread use of a transmissible vaccine, or if not, whether it is likely to occur.

PHR: Narrative The immune system in the uterus is required to fight infection while at the same time maintaining the pregnancy and protecting the pregnant person and the fetus. As pregnancy progresses, the immune system evolves to accommodate the unique needs of the pregnancy which changes over the course of gestation. This proposal aims to define the immune programs activated in response to infection with the ultimate goal of identifying novel diagnostic and therapeutic strategies to improve pregnancy outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative: The FDA Vet-LIRN Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory Program enables, nationwide, the analyses of animal diagnostic samples and animal food/drug products. The Program fills a gap for the FDA Office of Regulatory Affairs (ORA) regarding veterinary diagnostic samples that greatly facilitates early detection of and response to animal food/drug adulteration and contamination events. Through the Vet- LIRN program, FDA leverages the expertise of a national system of university, state and federal veterinary diagnostic laboratories to provide additional capacity and capability, obtain veterinary diagnostic information critical to ORA response, and strengthen the overall national food safety system.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The Vet-LIRN program adds a unique component to FDA investigations and testing programs, by directly examining veterinary diagnostic samples to facilitate early detection of animal food and drug adulteration or contamination. The previous outbreak of Salmonella infantis in humans from commercial pet food, and melamine in dog food as well as infant formula directly highlight the importance of effective screening of animal food and tissues to prevent disease in humans. Virginia Tech Animal Laboratory Services (ViTALS) is fully accredited by the AAVLD, a member of NAHLN, and has been a member of the FDA CVM Vet-LIRN community since 2012, and has experience and expertise in testing clinical samples and can provide technical skill and support for ongoing outbreak testing.

PROJECT_TITLE: CVM Vet-LIRN Veterinary Laboratory Diagnostic Program (U18)

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A first-tier laboratory member of the Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network (Vet- LIRN) and also a non-cooperative agreement member of the Food Emergency Response Network (FERN) since 2005, the PADLS New Bolton Center Laboratory at the University of Pennsylvania provides comprehensive veterinary diagnostic services to the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and the surrounding region, making it an ideal part of the Veterinary Laboratory Investigation and Response Network. Our diagnostic samples for toxicology, microbiology, molecular diagnostics, and pathology testing are most commonly submitted by veterinarians, but other clients include food animal producers, various government agencies, and veterinary diagnostic laboratories in other states that lack toxicology sections. Some analyses are requested as part of normal surveillance activities or routine necropsies, while others are associated with cases of excessive, unexpected, or otherwise unexplainable animal losses or illness that may potentially pose a risk to animal health and/or animal or human food safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative High grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC) has a dismal prognosis, largely attributed to late diagnosis and poor responses to standard of care treatment. It is therefore essential to better understand the mechanisms of HGSOC development in order to identify potential strategies for early intervention, particularly in high-risk patients. In this proposal, we outline a series of experiments exploring the relationship between norepinephrine signaling and fallopian tube derived high grade serous cancer spread to the ovary in hopes of developing a new strategy to prevent or delay the development of HGSOC, ultimately improving clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children who are critically ill and receiving mechanical ventilation are at increased risks for experiencing high levels of stress and pain, which negatively impacts immediate and long-term health. The current standard of care for treating stress and pain is to provide analgesic and sedative medications, which are associated with increased risk of delirium and posttraumatic stress disorder. This randomized crossover trial will compare the effects of live and recorded music listening on biomarkers of stress and pain among children receiving mechanical ventilation in the pediatric intensive care unit, to identify the key components of a music listening intervention and explore its mechanism of action, i.e., the biological pathway through which music listening decreases stress and pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We aim to increase the efficacy of lung cancer screening with low dose computed tomography (LDCT) by developing methods to accurately predict risk of lung cancer and/or progressive obstructive lung disease at the time of screening. Our approach will focus on objective biomarkers: LDCT derived radiomic biomarkers of lung structure and an epigenetic biomarker of smoking exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Communication and quality of life are greatly impaired by the loss of intelligibility that accompanies motor speech disorders such as Parkinson’s disease, cerebral palsy, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. The proposed studies refine a well-studied mechanism of speech learning, sensorimotor adaptation, to maximize its effects on intelligibility. By directly increasing vowel distinctiveness in speakers, and by characterising mechanisms underlying the variability, generalization, and retention of learning, this project takes the first steps to translate sensorimotor adaptation into a clinical tool for improving the efficacy of spoken communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Many neurological impairments cause localized damage to movement-related brain regions (e.g. motor neuron degeneration in ALS, or the areas surrounding an infarction following a stroke). Despite such damage, motor abilities often recover, or even persist without immediate deficit, owing to poorly understood compensatory changes amongst neural circuits distributed across unaffected parts of the brain. In this project, I will develop a platform for monitoring neuronal activity in multiple descending pathways that control brainstem orofacial circuits (in cortex, the superior colliculus, and the medulla itself) in order to determine the principles by which these pathways normally operate during movement—as well as how they adapt following brain damage in order to maintain stable motor output.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The goal of our project is to understand the mechanisms by which muscle sensory neurons contribute to exaggerated increases in sympathetic nervous system activity and blood pressure during exercise in cardiovascular disease. The experiments are significant because an exaggerated increase in sympathetic nerve activity results in vasoconstriction of the coronary and peripheral vasculature which leads to reduced exercise capacity and inadequate oxygen delivery to the heart and other tissues. Increasing our understanding of the mechanisms that cause the exaggerated increase in sympathetic nerve activity during physical stress may lead to the development of novel treatment options for cardiovascular disease patients.
