IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One potential mechanism that contributes to impairment in fragile X syndrome and the FMR1 premutation is autonomic nervous system (ANS) dysfunction. While ANS dysfunction has been linked to impairment, research has not examined the presence, onset, developmental trajectory, or developmental consequences of ANS dysfunction or the role of molecular-genetic factors. This project addresses these critical gaps and will have tremendous impact by greatly expanding information on the mechanistic underpinnings, biological pathways, and timing of symptom progression, which is essential to identify targets and timing of treatment to reduce symptom severity in fragile X syndrome and the FMR1 premutation.

Understanding the mechanisms that initiate and promote fibrosis will aid in developing novel therapeutics to block or reverse this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The N-glycan branching pathway controls immunity and inflammation by controlling turnover rates of proteins on the surface of T cells. However, which proteins are regulated in this manner, and how this pathway promotes expression of some proteins while inhibiting expression of others is unknown. We propose using a quantitative proteomic approach to analyze all surface proteins simultaneously and to examine the hypothesis that these extracellular glycans cooperate with intracellular endocytosis machinery to differentially regulate cell- surface protein turnover.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the lung develops, precisely timed interactions between epithelial and mesenchymal cells promote the growth of new alveoli and the differentiation of alveolar type 2 cells into alveolar type 1 cells. Preterm birth during the saccular stage disrupts this process leading to dysregulation of two key signaling pathways – Wnt and BMP – with resulting arrested lung development and permanent deficits in pulmonary function. In this proposal, we will synthesize data from live microscopy, single-cell multiomics, and spatial transcriptomics to define the role of Wnt and BMP signaling in normal alveologenesis and in neonatal lung injury, which will provide foundational data for new approaches to restore normal lung growth after preterm birth.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE A need exists for more pediatric clinical research to ensure that children are receiving appropriate medications, treatments, and devices that have been tested with children rather than adults. However, recruitment and retention in pediatric clinical trials remains a challenge. Parents play an important role in the decision-making process about their child’s participation in a clinical trial and a number of factors (e.g., awareness; knowledge; trust; fear) may inform their decision. Parents are in need of resources to help them better understand pediatric clinical research as well as facilitate high quality communication and shared decision-making skills related to their child’s participation in pediatric clinical trials. Thus, the goals of this application are to develop and test the feasibility of a web-based parent toolkit about pediatric clinical research (available in English and Spanish) using a user-centered approach that includes the voices from a diverse group of parents. This toolkit will have an impact on the field of pediatric health by providing parents with information and skills that are expected to increase pediatric clinical trial accrual.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiological studies have identified strong links between short sleep, the metabolic syndrome and diabetes, and laboratory studies have demonstrated downstream mechanisms by which sleep restriction impairs glucose metabolism, including reduced insulin sensitivity. However, sleep restriction in both free-ranging humans and prior experimental studies is accompanied by longer exposure to Artificial Light At Night (ALAN), an endocrine disruptor that can profoundly disrupt circadian rhythmicity. We will evaluate the extent to which ALAN-induced endocrine and circadian disruption is a primary upstream toxic exposure contributing to the sleep-restriction- induced impairment of glucose metabolism and consequent increase in diabetes risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Powassan virus (POWV) is a tick-borne flavivirus with the potential to emerge as a public health threat in the United States. Viral infection can be associated with severe neurological symptoms, and is periodically lethal. This proposal is focused on the development of a safe, non-replicating vaccine that can be used for prevention of a POWV-associated disease in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Affecting 50 M worldwide yearly, traumatic brain injury (TBI) is the leading cause of visual dysfunction and vision loss in sports-related injury, and automobile accidents in the United States. Preventing retinal cells from becoming dysfunctional or dying, with the attendant disability, is a major public health necessity. Our objective, to study mesenchymal stem cell-derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) which are functionally engineered to overexpress specific microRNAs for retina-specific protective actions in TBI, fits well with the NEI Strategic Plan’s goals to improve visual health via safe cell-free delivery of therapeutic molecules directly to retinal cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite decades of research in academia and the pharmaceutical industry, we currently have very few small molecule ligands that can address RNA selectively and elicit useful biological effects. This leaves a tremendous portion of cellular biochemistry and metabolism outside of our control. We are tackling this challenging problem by using computer-assisted drug design to develop novel RNA-targeting chimeras to control RNA stability and RNA splicing during the translation of disease-modifying genes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Deciphering the complex regulatory networks that control cell-fate decisions of embryonic cells is a major objective in the field of development. This knowledge may lead to the discovery of new tools in the battle against birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This multicenter clinical trial will examine whether a vaccine (“Triplex”) for a common viral infection (cytomegalovirus [CMV]) will be safe, effective and elicit CMV-specific immunity, and decrease the need for toxic CMV antiviral therapy in liver transplant recipients who are at high risk for CMV infection. If shown to be effective, this vaccine could be used as a way to better prevent CMV infection in transplant recipients and other populations with weakened immune systems who are at risk for CMV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Scarring in the lung can occur after inhalation of silica, asbestos and other particles, but no one knows how or why that happens. We believe that non-degradable particles reprogram cells in the lung to produce acid and other factors in a futile attempt to dissolve them, which causes collateral injury and fibrosis in surrounding tissues. The tissue damaging cells have many similarities to osteoclasts, cells that dissolve bone, which are eminently targetable with bisphosphonates and other readily available and FDA approved agents if our theory proves to be correct.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Disruption of the GDE2 pathway mimics neurodegenerative and synaptic changes observed in Alzheimer's Disease (AD). Proposed studies will use a three-pronged experimental approach employing electrophysiological, behavioral, and molecular techniques to determine how this pathway affects synaptic function and behavior. Outcomes have potential to provide deeper insight into underlying mechanisms of pathologies associated with AD that in the long-term may aid in the design of mechanism-based therapies for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A substantial proportion of the population maintains stable cognitive function despite the development of Alzheimer’s disease (AD)-related pathology. The neural mechanisms underlying this cognitive resilience are poorly understood, though an understanding of these mechanisms has immense therapeutic potential. The proposed research will investigate the independent and interactive effects of one candidate mechanism – compensatory elevation of dopamine synthesis – and AD-related pathology on memory performance and local functional connectivity using a multi-modal neuroimaging approach in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will enrich our understanding of how visual computation is organized and distributed across neurons and circuits at a critical processing stage, where the breadth of sensory feature encoding is greatly increased. These experiments will establish how synapses and molecules are preferentially recruited to fulfill the requirements of particular visual computations. Computational principles revealed by this study may allow us to predict neuronal function based solely on gene expression data, and will fundamentally improve important technologies, including machine vision and retinal prosthetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment is a debilitating side-effect of chemotherapy treatment that affects learning, memory, attention, and executive functions in cancer patients. This condition is worse in people who have the APOE4 gene, which is also the strongest genetic risk factor for Alzheimer’s Disease. The experiments in this proposal use a novel mouse model of chemotherapy-treated APOE mice to 1) identify circuit-based mechanisms in the entorhinal cortex underlying cognitive impairment and 2) test whether altering apoE levels can prevent CICI development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This study will greatly advance our fundamental understanding of how the brain controls movement and how brain areas interact to make simple choices. Uncovering the principles of operation in the motor system is likely to inform treatments for motor disorders such as Parkinson’s and enable better brain-machine interfaces for use by paralyzed patients. Understanding how brain areas communicate is vital for advancing treatment for stroke and traumatic brain injury, which often disrupt these connections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a severely debilitating cerebrovascular disease, which affects over 70,000 patients per year in the U.S., and is responsible for over half of stroke-related disability worldwide. So far, the diagnosis, surveillance, and prediction of outcome in intracerebral hemorrhage have mainly relied on visual and subjective assessment of head CT scans. Computerized assessment of medical images and machine learning algorithms can extract hidden features from CT scans and provide innovative tools for accurate outcome prediction and personalized treatment decisions in patients with hemorrhagic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sensory perception is vital for hand movement, and learning in both sensory and motor systems of the brain helps keep hand control smooth and accurate. Interactions between sensory and motor systems are not well understood, and the proposed research will systematically test a new framework for understanding sensory-motor interaction in hand control. Findings may enable advances in basic and clinical research areas that depend on mechanistic knowledge of sensorimotor function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Currently, we know little about how an intact brain plans for shoulder or combined shoulder and hand movements. Therefore, we propose to investigate the cortical communication and the brainstem’s activity during motor preparation for hand opening, arm lifting, and hand opening while arm lifting against various shoulder loads. Results are expected to establish the cortical circuits for various motor tasks, and identify the structure and cortical activity affecting the brainstem during the preparation of specific limb movements in an intact nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The rates of severe maternal morbidity (SMM) and maternal mortality (MM) have tripled in the U.S. since 1993, with the burden disproportionately falling on Black and Hispanic women. To address this maternal health crisis and growing inequity, states are increasingly turning to quality care collaboratives (QCCs) to disseminate quality improvement (QI) toolkits that are designed to improve maternal care processes and maternal health. We will combine first-of-its-kind QCC survey data with existing public data sources to evaluate the effects of QCCs and their QI toolkits on maternal care processes (cesarean births overall, and nulliparous singleton term vertex cesarean births) and maternal health outcomes (SMM and MM), with a particular focus on the effects among Black and Hispanic women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative American Indians (AIs) have limited access to healthy food and a high prevalence of diet-related diseases. This study will implement a tribal community supported agriculture program in which AI adults receive a weekly box of local fresh fruits and vegetables along with culturally tailored nutrition and cooking education. The program’s effect on diet and health outcomes and it’s cost-effectiveness will be evaluated, and study processes and findings will be broadly disseminated to support tribes in improving diet and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Current theories of how cerebellar cortical circuitry optimizes motor, cognitive, and emotional performance rely on two core assumptions: 1) circuit connectivity is rigidly conserved and stereotypical across cells and regions; and 2) Purkinje cell (PC) dendrites act as one homogeneous unit to process information. Challenging both assumptions, this proposal describes a PC subpopulation with segregated dendritic compartments that receive distinct inputs and exhibit heterogeneous signaling that influences PC computations and output. The influence of dendrite morphology–also incorrectly assumed to be stereotypical– on function introduces a structure- function relationship that substantially updates current theories of cerebellar function and provides a vital context for cerebellar dysfunction in diseases such as ataxia, essential tremor, and autism spectrum disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Axonal degeneration underlies many debilitating diseases including HSPs, ALS and Alzheimer's disease. This proposed study seeks to delineate the role of glial cells and the neuron-glia crosstalk in the pathogenesis of SPG3A, the most early-onset form of HSP. The long term goal of the study is to identify targets and therapeutics to rescue axonal and synaptic degeneration in HSP and other diseases that involve axonopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE The ever-changing landscape of genetic research requires the training of scientists in state-of-the-art genetics and genomics technologies to answer fundamental mechanistic biological questions that inform us about human biology and disease. The University of Michigan (UM) Predoctoral Genetics Training Program will consist of: (1) a diverse cohort of Ph.D. trainees from six basic science departments spanning the UM Medical School and College of Literature, Sciences, and the Arts campuses; (2) productive faculty with diverse genetics research interests; and (3) a comprehensive curriculum in modern genetics. Here, we present our plan to train the next generation of genetics professionals through: (a) small-group learning experiences; (b) faculty led and peer-to- peer discussions; (c) training-grant specific activities that stress both the ethical conduct of science and critical importance of conducting rigorous and reproducible science; and (d) data-driven evaluation, outcomes, mentoring, and career development programs.

PROJECT_TITLE: Michigan Predoctoral Training in Genetics
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - A[TWD-A]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Growing attention has focused on the postpartum period as an important window to address maternal mortality disparities as half of pregnancy-related deaths occur postpartum, and Black and Latina women's excess burden of mortality and morbidity continues during this period. Black and Latina women experience more postpartum complications, ED visits, and postpartum readmissions than do White women. Our mixed method study uses an ecosocial framework to better identify Black and Latina women most at risk for poor outcomes following childbirth, the problems they experience, and to adapt an evidence-based intervention that aims to improve quality of postpartum care for high risk women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) is a widely used treatment for hematologic cancers; however, it can accelerate biological aging in recipients by up to 15 years and many survivors experience long-term symptoms that resemble an accelerated aging phenotype. This project aims to elucidate the important protective elements of social relationships and identify concrete, modifiable behavioral factors that contribute to biological and phenotypic aging in HCT survivors and can be used to develop biologically informed interventions to improve quality of life and prolong the healthspan of individuals with accelerated aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the etiological agent of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic and while extensive research over the past year have offered some clues about the strategies that SARS-CoV-2 uses to disarm the host immune responses, there remain gaps in our understanding of the mechanisms used by this virus to subvert host immune responses. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the molecular mechanism by which SARS-CoV-2 NSP14 protein inhibits host translation and down-regulates MHC-I antigen presentation to escape the host immune response. This study has the potential to improve our knowledge of SARS-CoV-2 virus-host interaction, allow new insight into mechanisms governing COVID-19 pathogenesis and viral immune evasion, as well as to provide additional therapeutic targets for antiviral development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with Tourette syndrome (TS) follow varying clinical courses, as some will experience substantial improvement over the course of adolescence while others will continue to experience significant impairment. Understanding the brain and cognitive features that mediate or predict different outcomes could revolutionize prognosis and treatment. This project will study children with and without TS over time, during the key ages of 10 to 14 years, to (1) investigate how brain and cognitive markers of TS develop over adolescence and relate to changes in symptom severity, and (2) make predictions about future symptom severity for individual children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The evolution of metastasis in colorectal cancer is poorly understood. Fundamental questions regarding the role of lymph node metastases in systemic progression, and the time point of divergence between primary tumor and distant metastases await resolution. Here, we will apply novel genetic approaches to study the evolutionary history of colorectal cancer metastasis in human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cryptosporidiosis is an enteric protozoal infection that is a leading contributor to child morbidity, mortality, and growth impairment worldwide. There is no vaccine for this parasite, and the only available drug, nitazoxanide, lacks rigorous controlled trials in South Asian children under one. This randomized placebo-controlled trial will test efficacy of nitazoxanide to treat both diarrheal and non-diarrheal Cryptosporidium infection in children 6 to 12 months in Bangladesh, and evaluate treatment’s effect on child growth.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) are a common cause of diarrheal disease throughout regions of the world were basic sanitation and clean water remain in limited supply. These infections have also emerged repeatedly in the United States, often in the form of large outbreaks despite robust sanitation. ETEC is the most common cause of diarrheal illness of soldiers deployed to developing regions of the world where these infections are highly endemic. Both nonimmune children living in these areas and returning veterans frequently experience symptoms that linger long after the diarrheal illness is gone. Many features of the acute illness, that may be severe and indistinguishable from cholera, as well as the subsequent illnesses that persist after the diarrhea has resolved still remain very poorly understood. Understanding how ETEC interact with the intestine and the changes in the intestinal lining caused by these infections could speed the development of treatment or prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, first, middle): Reddy, Jr., Bobby Project Narrative: In this project, Prenosis will build upon this work to conduct targeted analyses of the individual treatment effects of corticosteroids on septic patient outcomes. Using samples that have already been collected and stored in the biobank, we will leverage our existing pipeline to measure the 40 core biomarkers for 8,100 samples on these 2,700 patients: the pre-treatment sample closest to the time at which the treatment patient received steroids, the sample closest to 24 hours after the treatment patient received steroids, and the patients’ final samples to understand how treatment impacted biomarker profile and how these changes are associated with clinical outcomes of interest. Analytics built upon these data and analyses could dramatically improve diagnostic, clinical decision support, and drug development products for sepsis and COVID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Young women in South Africa are at high lifetime risk of contracting HIV, and will benefit enormously from a safe, effective HIV vaccine once it is available. However, as we know from the roll-out of the COVID-19 vaccine and from more than a decade of HIV vaccine trial recruitment, misinformation can reduce interest in or willingness to take the vaccine. In this study, we test messages that work like a “information vaccine” to build resistance to misinformation that young women may hear about the HIV vaccine; results from this study will help inform how to communicate about the HIV vaccine in South Africa to ensure that vulnerable groups like adolescent girls and young women can benefit from the vaccine's protection against HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE CRISPR-Cas systems are diverse bacterial immune systems that provide anti-viral defense, and have been exploited as programmable nucleases for a multitude of biotechnology and disease treatment applications. We will use Listeria seeligeri as a model microbe to investigate the activities of the RNA-targeting CRISPR-Cas13 system in its natural host. The research proposed here will both yield a deeper mechanistic understanding of how these unique CRISPR systems affect their hosts during anti-viral immunity, and also guide the development and application of Cas13-based biotechnologies that benefit human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Surgical decision-making is challenging for persons living with dementia (PLWD) due to limited longitudinal data on outcomes, a patient's limited ability to fully participate in the discussion, and an absence of evidence- based guidelines. We propose a mixed methods study to understand the epidemiology of surgery for PLWD, as well as patient, caregiver, and provider practices and challenges of surgical decision-making in clinical settings. We focus on surgery because it is common among elderly PLWDs, it often represents a critical inflection point in quality of life, and therefore is a fraught process for all involved.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop novel computational methods to predict the impact of multiple changes in DNA sequence on overall cellular state and help IGVF consortium data collection and analysis strategies. These efforts represent crucial steps toward enabling genomic medicine by comprehensively linking genotype with cellular phenotype.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE / PROJECT NARRATIVE  Given the critical roles of Siglec-glycan ligand interactions in immunoregulation, a deeper understanding of these processes may aid the development of new therapeutic modalities. These modalities can be used to ameliorate inflammatory syndromes (such as those associated with COVID-19 infection) by inducing the inhibitory functions of Siglecs or be used to augment anti-tumor immunity by suppressing Siglec’s inhibitory actions. Such modalities may be combined with FDA-approved therapeutic agents, such as anti-PD-1 based immune checkpoint inhibitors, to achieve better response rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The field of muscle cell biology muscular dystrophy translational research is expanding as academic and industry partnerships are yielding new potential treatments that are undergoing assessment in the clinics. Well-trained and highly motivated investigators in this field are essential for the progress of basic and translational muscle cell research as there have been major breakthroughs in mechanisms of disease and the emergence of new potential therapies for muscle disease. Trainees of the Muscle Cell Biology, Pathophysiology, and Therapeutics Program will fulfill its stated mission by advancing to positions of leadership in academia or industry and continuing to uncover basic principles in mechanisms of disease while also developing next-generation therapies based in muscle diseases for the betterment of patients and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is a leading cause of irreversible vision loss affecting 60 million people world-wide, however no effective primary prevention or treatment therapies exist for this blinding disease. While large-scale human genetic association studies have uncovered multiple genetic risk factors for glaucoma, the implicated genes and pathways are largely unknown. The goals of the proposed research are to characterize gene expression and its genetic regulation in glaucoma-relevant tissues from healthy human eyes, and to use this information together with human genetics studies to discover novel biological processes and pathogenic mechanisms for high- and normal-tension glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will model the network bases of aphasia in a uniquely informative cohort of neurosurgical patients, providing a distinct perspective on the pathophysiology of acquired language disorders that affect close to 1 million Americans today. A better understanding of the causal role of networks and connections in supporting language function carries the potential for improved patient care via better prediction of language outcomes and more effectively targeted neural interventions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing the burdens of illness and disability.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is an Alzheimer’s disease-related dementia that has been linked to mutations in the gene encoding for the tau protein (MAPT). This proposal aims to create a resource to study FTD by taking advantage of a family of rhesus monkeys carrying an exact replicate of an FTD-related mutation (MAPT R406W). PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Skeletal muscles are now being considered as an endocrine organ. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project is focused on characterizing genetic features of colorectal cancer among major Latino subgroups in the United States (i.e. Mexican/Central American and Caribbean), who differ in ancestral backgrounds and colorectal cancer mortality rates. Our aims are to identify new cancer driver mutations present in Latinos with high indigenous American or African ancestry and to test their implications for treatment response and prognosis. This area of research has received limited attention despite the compelling advantages of studying admixed populations for optimizing treatment strategies targeted to individuals of specific heritage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since there is no accepted animal model of myositis (inflammation of muscle), this study aims to characterize and utilize the first mouse models. Importantly, we will use these models to help understand whether Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM), the most common late adult-onset muscle disease, is primarily a degenerative disease or an autoimmune disease. These "personalized" and "humanized" mouse models will be used to validate novel therapeutic targets for this devastating myodegenerative disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance As a result of population aging, many low- and middle-income countries such as Lebanon face a rapidly growing burden of dementia. This proposal represents a collaboration between the American University of Beirut and the University of Michigan to develop a program of research capacity building and a population- based study to identify important new risk factors for dementia in Lebanon as well as the caregiver needs and arrangements for older adults. Findings from this program are expected to have substantial relevance for a better understanding of dementia risks and associated care needs in Lebanon and other low-resource settings around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T cells in the immune system develop through a multi-step process in which they first proliferate strongly to make many cells, then commit themselves entirely to develop as T cells, and only then start to express T-cell properties. This project grows from surprising evidence that certain genes that are best known for their abnormal role in leukemia may normally have another, benign role in the early developmental stages of T cells. The project tests whether this is true and what mechanisms the normal cells must therefore be using to exploit these genes while preventing them from causing leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to improve the ability of eye care providers to better assess the three-dimensional changes in the posterior eye that result from changes in progressive and pathologic myopia or high intracranial pressure, all potentially visually disabling diseases. Leveraging innovative imaging technologies developed by our laboratories and specifically designed analysis of posterior eye shape, we expect to provide quantitative information about these posterior eye deformations to support clinical care and research into the anatomical changes involved in these diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Violence is an urgent public health problem which reflects and reinforces social inequities, and high-quality early childhood education programs hold promise in addressing multiple sources of risk and resilience for inter- personal violence and self-directed harm. This project uses nationally-representative longitudinal survey data spanning several decades to estimate the effects of Head Start, a large-scale, comprehensive early childhood education intervention, 1) inter-generationally on suicidal ideation and inter-personal violence perpetration, and 2) intra-generationally on handgun carrying and inter-personal violence perpetration, along with interactive effects of demographic, social, economic, and environmental factors. This project will inform early childhood education and violence prevention policies and support the F31 candidate in developing methodological and content expertise needed to become an independent investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This study seeks to understand the long-term consequences to lung function in patients who recover from the novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The proposed deep learning algorithms will utilize chest X-ray and computed tomography images to identify post-COVID-19 progression subtypes and establish their associations with distinct clinical, imaging and mechanistic biomarkers. The knowledge gained from this study will improve the management and treatment of post-COVID-19 patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Asthma has increasing worldwide incidence and female sex and obesity are risk factors for severe forms of disease that can resist standard therapies. We have found that T cell glutamine uptake and metabolism play key roles to regulate gene expression and inflammation that could contribute to severe asthma. This study will test two candidate targets to suppress glutamine metabolism in animal models and patient samples and determine if this pathway may provide new therapeutic targets to overcome severe therapy resistant asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Since their discovery almost 50 years ago how opioid receptors facilitate the development of dependence and withdrawal at a circuit level is still not known. To address this question, we will chart the global cell-type identity, shifting connectivity, and ensemble activity of opioidergic networks by examining brains throughout various stages of addiction. By leveraging cutting-edge neuroscience technologies, we will map and profile neuronal ensembles and cell-types that mediate opioid action in the rodent brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We will develop statistically principled computational methods, algorithms, and tools to efﬁciently, comprehen- sively, and quantitatively proﬁle chromatin organization, to further elucidate the dynamics of transcriptional regulation, and to link the two through predictive models that provide mechanistic insight into how a cell's chromatin state inﬂuences—and is inﬂuenced by—its transcriptional state. Successfully achieving this would have enormous scientiﬁc and practical impact by enhancing our understanding of fundamental processes like cell growth and division, signal and stress response, and differentiation, as well as clinically relevant consequences of their dysregulation, whether in cancer, diabetes, or developmental disorders. We seek to develop computational methods that provide mechanistic answers to foundational questions about how cells function and are therefore broadly applicable across organisms, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Speech deficits are among the most prevalent and impairing of clinical features for individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), yet the specific barriers to speech production are poorly understood, and consequently, the existing treatments do not target the source of the problem. The objective of this study is to characterize the specific processes in the speech motor system in participants with ASD in order to understand the factors that lead to impaired speech. The long-term goal is to identify new directions for novel approaches to treatment that target the specific barriers to speech for individuals with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Infertility, which affects 10-15% of couples, can be caused by impaired egg and/or sperm production (gametogenesis). There remain key limits to our understanding of the gametogenesis processes, especially how sophisticated gene expression programs operate during these processes, impeding fundamental science and the diagnosis and treatment of infertility. To address these limits of knowledge we will build upon our discoveries of previously uncharacterized RNA-binding proteins that are crucial for gametogenesis, to now elucidate their molecular functions and mechanisms of action in the gene expression programs during gametogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Crosstalk between breast cancer cells and adipocytes results in tumor invasiveness, sustained cancer growth, and increased acquisition of aggressive tumor phenotypes. This proposal aims to create multicellular tumor spheroids to study changes in tumor invasiveness when cancer cells are co-aggregated with adipocytes. Multicellular tumor spheroids will be created using a custom surface vibration bioreactor, which will test the potential to generate tumor spheroids with improved cell-cell adhesion and scalability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Sterile inflammation, induced by cardiac surgery and chronic metabolic disorder, is a serious public health issue and clinical problem, as it can lead to heart failure and death. The goal of this research program is to explore the role of three new molecules/approaches in the regulation of macrophage function ( efferocytosis, polarization) to i.e., minimize such inflammation-triggered heart injury, with the hope of improving heart failure patient survival. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to advancing fundamental knowledge and translational study that will help to reduce the burdens of human disability.

PHR: Lung cancer screening is poised to substantially reduce lung cancer deaths, however there is evidence of racial disparities in its use. The objective of this project is to investigate the role of patient beliefs, stigma, and medical mistrust, as well as physician implicit bias on racial disparities in lung cancer screening referral and completion. We will conduct this study in a racially- and ethnically-diverse sample of smokers in a large primary care network in New York City.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Aging-related retinal degeneration is a major cause of vision loss in diseases including age-related macular degeneration (AMD). The broad goal of this study is to investigate the role of nuclear receptor RORα in mediating age-related chronic subretinal inflammation and retinal degeneration associated with AMD. The proposed project specifically aims to investigate the mechanisms through which a lipid-sensing nuclear receptor RORα modulates pathologic non-resolving subretinal inflammation to impact retinal health, and finding ways to target RORα and related pathways to resolve persistent inflammation and protect the retina. This work may lead to design of new approaches for alleviating pathologic persistent inflammation and preventing or slowing retinal degeneration in eye diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inhaled nitric oxide (“iNO”) has gained significant prominence in treating highly debilitating hypoxic lung failure in newborns, pulmonary arterial hypertension and pulmonary hypertension associated with pulmonary diseases. However, the market for iNO is limited due to the cost, complexity, and safety of the dominant tank-based delivery systems. The goal of this investigation is to develop a simpler, safer, compact, portable and more versatile means of generating and delivering iNO, offering the promise of lower cost and better treatment for existing iNO therapy, and the potential for a significant expansion of the patient population who can safely and effectively benefit from iNO therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variation in the atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) hormone, an important regulator of cardiometabolic health, may contribute to the burgeoning cardiometabolic disease burden in the United States. Micro-RNA- 425 (miR-425), a known negative regulator of ANP, may regulate the response of ANP to metabolic perturbations, and in turn, limit its numerous beneficial cardiometabolic effects. This study will assess the impact of high and low ANP genotype on the regulation of cardiometabolic health and provide the mechanistic basis for novel RNA-based therapeutics targeting the ANP-miR-425 axis for the treatment and control of the snowballing cardiometabolic disease burden in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative My research is focused on understanding the role of P311, a small protein that regulates the development, plasticity (switch among different types), and function of different types of fat cells (white, beige and brown). The goal of this research is to understand how this protein controls fat cells to influence the development of related metabolic diseases, such as diabetes. Knowing how P311 works can help us to develop novel strategies towards developing treatments for obesity and associated metabolic irregularities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative BET proteins are of great interest to public health for their involvement in: 1) different types of cancer such as lung, breast, and prostate; and 2) viral infection. This project aims to characterize a promising alternative region of BET proteins to lay the foundation for novel therapeutic strategies that will overcome current limitations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to analyze the role of VAV1-MYO1F a recurrent activating genetic alteration driving activation of the guanine nucleotide exchange factor VAV1 in Peripheral T-cell Lymphomas (PTCL). To dissect the role of the recurrent VAV1-MYO1F fusion, we will use a newly developed genetically engineered mouse model of lymphoma and characterize these tumors using a combination of molecular pathology and genomic profiling tools. Elucidation of the specific mechanisms mediating the oncogenic effects of VAV1-MYO1F will provide important novel insight on the pathogenesis of peripheral T-cell lymphomas and point to novel targets to be tested in experimental therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The research outlined in this proposal seeks to identify and define a non-canonical inhibitory circuit from the retina to the brain. Though all light information relayed from the retina to the brain was thought to be excitatory, our data suggests that a subset of the melanopsin-expressing, intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells release the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA. The presence of an inhibitory circuit from the eye to the brain necessitates a re-evaluation of the existing models for how light information is transmitted from the eye to the brain to influence behavior, and could lead to a better understanding of how light influences our sleep and daily activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: ATLAS OF REGULATORY VARIANTS IN DISEASE (ARVID)  Project Narrative Inherited risk for common diseases arises from multiple genetic variants, most of which reside in DNA sequences that may dysregulate gene expression in a way that predisposes to illness. An atlas of functionally validated disease variants, the genes they control, and the proteins whose binding they alter will help understand, predict, and prevent common diseases. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hemorrhage bears a significant burden to public health. Our novel device, which employs microscale electrical fields, is a promising therapeutic strategy that has been demonstrated to accelerate blood clot formation and may represent in a new paradigm to treat bleeding in trauma, surgery, and patients with blood diseases. In this proposed research, I will investigate the basic science mechanisms of this phenomenon and its potential as an innovative therapeutic hemostatic agent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Leishmania and related kinetoplastid parasites cause devastating diseases worldwide that afflict millions of individuals. Understanding how specific parasite organelles and surface proteins mediate transmission, infection and virulence is critical to controlling these diseases. This project will focus on the role of the flagellar membrane in both the insect vector and infectious mammalian forms of the parasite life cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is focused on efficiently identifying the genetic cause of inherited retinal degenerations (IRDs), an important cause of vision loss. By using cell-based assays to determine the functional significance of a large panel of DNA variants, the goal is to increase the throughput of diagnosing IRDs. The application of this knowledge could directly increase the number of inherited retinal disease patients eligible for gene-specific treatments such as gene augmentation therapy, reducing illness and disability from these blinding diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Intraventricular hemorrhage in very preterm infants leads to posthemorrhagic hydrocephalus, which currently can only be treated with surgery. Most often these procedures entail placement of ventricular shunts that incur a lifelong burden of malfunction, infection, hospitalization, family disruption and societal costs. Here, we propose a dose-finding, Phase I, randomized, controlled, double-blind trial to evaluate the safety of re-purposed medications, melatonin and erythropoietin, in very preterm neonates with recent-onset severe intraventricular hemorrhage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Cachexia is a major predictor of mortality that occurs with almost all chronic diseases. This project will identify the mechanism by which IL-1 promotes cachexia pathophysiology, fibrosis and lipid dysregulation. Effective tools to combat cachexia will impact a wide range of patients by: 1) increasing survival of physically taxing treatment; 2) increasing life span so that new therapies can be implemented 3) reduce debilitating pain and fatigue.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE Motility is essential for spirochetes to infect and disseminate in mammalian hosts, causing major diseases, such as syphilis, leptospirosis, and Lyme disease. The spirochetal motility is driven by periplasmic flagella, which are uniquely enclosed within bacterial outer membrane and are distinct from external flagella in the model systems Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica. A better understanding of the unique periplasmic flagella as proposed in the application will potentially lead to the development of new antimicrobial strategies that specifically prohibit spirochetal motility and prevent major human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Off-target effects by therapeutic agents are mainly connected to the toxicity of current drug candidates in clinical studies, while achieving specific inhibition of the desired target of interest is a challenging task due to the high degree of similarity among enzymes inside cells. We propose a research plan that combines computational studies, multi-step synthesis, biochemical assay, and structural biology to systematically investigate a family of enzymes and to identify distinct structural features in enzymes of interest. This research will provide new insights into specific inhibition mechanisms for targets of interest, and it aims to produce highly specific chemical agents that may be further developed to new therapeutic candidates.

PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is greatly affected by aging and inflammation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative  Craniofacial defects including cleft lip and palate are among the most prevalent birth defects in humans. Dysregulation of alternative RNA splicing has been implicated in a variety of congenital diseases, including human craniofacial defects, which have been shown to stem from misexpression of multiple RNA-binding proteins that regulate alternative splicing. By identifying the molecular mechanisms by which the activity of the the RNA-binding protein Srsf3 is regulated, as well as its alternative RNA splicing targets in facial mesenchyme cells, the research aims in this proposal will provide significant insight into the mechanisms underlying gene expression regulation during mammalian craniofacial development and potentially new therapeutic directions for the treatment of human orofacial clefting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Academy of Medicine and the National Institutes of Health have called for urgent action to improve the care delivered to the nearly 1,000,000 older Americans who die in intensive care units (ICUs) annually, or survive with substantial impairments. These patients often die with distressing symptoms, receiving more invasive, life-prolonging treatment than they would choose for themselves; their family members, acting as surrogate decision makers, often experience lasting psychological distress from the ICU experience. We will conduct a randomized trial to determine whether early integration of specialty palliative care with standard critical care can improve outcomes for critically ill older patients and their family members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance GenePattern is a popular bioinformatics software ecosystem that puts sophisticated computational methods within the reach of all biomedical researchers to address a variety of problems at the forefront of cancer research, including patient diagnosis and prognosis, identification of new drug targets, and understanding disease mechanisms. We will continue to support and enhance the system by providing interoperable access to additional software tools and data resources from GenePattern Notebook, a beginning-to-end computational electronic lab notebook environment for combining analysis and text. Moreover, we will expand our collection of notebooks that provide cancer investigators with scientist-oriented cancer analysis scenarios and tasks for use in their own studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Patients with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia (ADRD) are at higher risk of hospitalization and 30-day readmission (readmission) compared to other older adults. Readmission is expensive and increases the risk of institutionalization and premature death among ADRD patients. The main goal of this proposal is to use Michigan Medicine’s electronic health records to develop a tool to identify high-risk ADRD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Loss pf p53 function is a pivotal step in cancer etiology and oncogenessis. The recently identified RNA-binding protein, Tudor Domain-interacting Regulator of DNA Repair (TIRR) inhibits function in a multi-faceted manner (i) via regulation 53BP1/USP28/p53 complex and (ii) direct binding of transcripts from p53 target genes. Our proposal utilizes a combination of genomic, proteomic and genetic tools to understand how TIRR inhibits p53 to promote tumor development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Very early identification of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) cognitive vulnerability is difficult because the current gold-standard tests are 1) only sensitive to obvious, not subtle, cognitive impairment, and 2) measure peak performance at a single time point in a well-controlled environment that is detached from how a person functions in day-to-day life. Mobile health (mHealth) assessments that utilize common smartphone technology may help overcome these limitations by sampling cognitive functioning multiple times per day in ‘real-time’, characterizing not only the time-course of a person’s cognitive performance, but also the psychosocial context (e.g., interpersonal interactions, mood, loneliness) in which they are functioning. This study will establish mHealth tools to identify and measure risk and resiliency factors that influence AD symptom development, and ultimately, AD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular structures of proteins binding other biomolecules provide insight into biological, disease, and drug mechanisms. We will develop foundational tools to predict (1) the three-dimensional structures of protein complexes, including protein-protein interactions where conformational changes complicate predictions; (2) antibody-antigen interactions critical for immunology, diagnostics and therapies; and (3) interactions with glycans, critical modulators of protein function and molecular interactions. Additionally, we will create collaborative infrastructure for the Rosetta biomolecular structure prediction and design software including testing platforms, scripting and web interfaces, and training materials for new scientists.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sub-optimal transfer of clinical information during inter-hospital transfer (IHT, the transfer of patients between acute care hospitals) is common and can lead to patient harm. To address this problem, we will use key stakeholder input to refine and implement an interoperable health information exchange platform that integrates with the electronic health record and improves the reliability of and access to necessary clinical information in three use cases involving transfer of patients between sending and receiving hospitals with varying levels of affiliation and health record integration. We will assess the effect of this intervention on frequency of medical errors, evaluate the use and usability of this platform from the perspective of those that interact with it, and use these results to develop a dissemination plan to spread implementation and use of this platform across other similar institutions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Advancing Health Information (HIE) During Inter-hospital Transfer (IHT) to Improve Patient Outcomes

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Up to 20% of American couples experience infertility and miscarriage, and there are important racial and ethnic disparities in their rates, in access to fertility treatment, and in fertility treatment success. However, little is known about the influence of sleep and selected life stressors on infertility and miscarriage, nor the extent to which male exposures play a role. The proposed prospective study will identify understudied modifiable risk factors for infertility and miscarriage in couples, yielding important public health information about reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Large-scale studies have identified thousands of genetic variants linked to developmental defects, together with the regulatory elements harboring these variants and the cell types in which these variants likely function. Yet, the molecular, cellular, and functional phenotypes of each variant remain largely uncharacterized. We propose to establish a center that will systematically catalog molecular and cellular phenotypes for disease- associated enhancers in human development, focusing on elements genetically associated with congenital heart disease (cardiomyocytes), autism (neurons), and placental defects (trophoblasts). Together, our multifaceted and combinatorial approaches will open new horizons to understanding the impact of regulatory variants on developmental disease phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 80% of clinic visit information is forgotten immediately by patients, a significant impediment to self- management for older adults with multimorbidity, that leads to poor health outcomes. The proposed research will determine the impact of the emerging strategy of audio recording and sharing of clinic visits on the ability of older adult patients to manage their healthcare. It is expected that findings from this project will inform future policy related to the use of audio-recording as part of routine care and guide implementation strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Stroke is the leading cause of serious long-term disability in the U.S., but current physical rehabilitation strategies do not account for deficits related to cognitive aspects of movement and the hemisphere-specific nature of these movement deficits. The exploratory studies described in this proposal will use a novel paradigm to determine how deficits in cognition affect movement differently depending on side of brain damage and how these differences affect functional independence in chronic stroke survivors. Successful completion of this proposal will provide a strong foundation for developing personalized physical rehabilitation strategies focused on improving both motor and cognitive deficits.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Potentially pathogenic members of the intestinal bacteria, namely pathobionts, trigger inflammation in Crohn’s disease (CD). We have identified "IL-1b-inducing pathobionts", which selectively accumulated in patients with CD. Unraveling the mechanism by which IL-1b-inducing pathobionts promote disease will provide critical new insight into our current understanding of the pathogenesis of CD as well as aid the development of novel treatment options for CD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Juvenile justice-involved youth (JJIY) experience high rates of psychiatric disorders and trauma, yet low rates of mental health service receipt, all of which is associated with poor sleep. Though sleep promotion is associated with reduced psychopathology, there has not been a systematic study of the sleep of adolescents involved in the juvenile justice system, the correlates of sleep in this population, nor the options for implementing evidence- based sleep-focused treatments in various juvenile justice system settings. We propose a descriptive, mixed- methods study to 1) examine the nature and correlates of sleep among JJIY; 2) identify points of intervention in the juvenile justice system where sleep treatment can be delivered, personnel who can deliver it, and the resources needed to do so; and 3) identify strategies for effective translation and implementation of existing evidence-based sleep-focused interventions in system settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will examine midlife women's relationships and support exchanges with their late adolescent and adult children, as well as with other kin and non-kin, and the implications of these relationships and exchanges for women's psychosocial well-being. The experienced bi-national team will collect and analyze survey and in-depth interview data building upon an existing longitudinal panel of women in rural Mozambique, a setting that in many respects is typical of sub-Saharan Africa. The results of this study will fill important gaps in our understanding of intergenerational and community relationship dynamics and their consequences for women's welfare in rapidly changing resource-limited patriarchal contexts and will inform policies aimed at improving health and well-being of rural women and at optimizing health and social services for that vulnerable population segment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with severe neurological impairment (SNI) make up 25% of intensive care (ICU) admissions and >50% of pediatric deaths in the ICU, translating to significant parental stress that is exacerbated by communication challenges during critical illness. This project will prospectively examine relationships between parent perceptions of health care communication and parent psychosocial outcomes during their child’s ICU admission, to then refine and pilot test a novel communication intervention to serve the unique needs of children with SNI and their families. Together, this project has the potential to improve parents’ ability to share their perspectives and needs regarding their child’s health and wellbeing during critical illness, in turn, improving parent and child outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Better understanding depression as a precursor to Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is of significant public health impact. In this project we will integrate conceptual and technical innovations to measure tau, a key forms of AD pathology, in older adults with depression using both brain scans and blood tests, and determine how tau, depression, and memory and thinking function relate to each other over time to potentiate dementia risk. Findings from our study have the potential to make a near-term impact in clinical settings by changing the approaches we use to evaluate and manage depression in late life and prevent AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-smoking cessation weight gain hinders quit attempts, precipitates relapse, and increases the risk of obesity and type 2 diabetes. This trial will examine a novel approach, a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist extended-release exenatide combined with nicotine patch, for facilitating smoking cessation and mitigating post-cessation weight gain. Availability of efficient gain mortality approaches to smoking cessation and post-cessation weight would encourage more smokers to quit and reduce the risk of relapse and premature morbidity and among those who quit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Quantitative assessment of progression through aging, based on reliable biomarkers, is critically important for both advancing the fundamental biology of aging and practical applications, such as testing interventions that extend lifespan. We propose to develop robust biomarkers of biological aging in mice and apply them to known and candidate longevity interventions. These biomarkers may be of wide use by the research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE LatiNET will use a multilevel social network model to examine how SARS-CoV-2 misinformation and Conspiracy Theory (CT) messages are shared across five settings (friends, family, work, health service and influencers), impacting Latinx vaccine hesitancy. We will use Dr. Kanamori’s (PI) K99/R00 social network approaches and Drs. Uscinski’s and Stoler’s (Co-Is) misinformation and CT message framework to identify how network structures and dynamics introduce and spread SARS-CoV-2 misinformation and CT messages that could then influence Latinx vaccine hesitancy. We will also identify network structures and dynamics that promote discussion countering SARS-CoV-2 misinformation and CT messages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Approximately 1 in 3 women and 1 in 5 men over the age of 50 will suffer from a fragility fracture in their remaining lifetime. Fragility hip fracture is one of the most serious and debilitating outcomes of osteoporosis with a 20–40% mortality rate during the first year after the fracture. Therefore, we propose to develop a cloud-based platform for automatic, opportunistic screening of X-ray image studies that will stand by in the central imaging data server of a hospital, investigate each non-investigated femur X-ray study, and flag the studies of patients that are detected to be at risk for a fragility fracture of the femur.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Metabolic processes are involved directly or indirectly in essentially everything a cell does, there still remains much to learn regarding how proliferating cell metabolism is regulated. Pyruvate kinase M2 (PKM2) catalyzes the last step in glycolysis and determines whether cells can produce enough nucleotides to proliferate; its expression has been linked to a wide range of pathologies including cancer, heart failure, neuroinflammation, and neuropathic pain. This proposal will develop novel radiotracers targeting PKM2 that will enable an innovative method of imaging a hallmark of metabolism and has potential to improve our understanding of metabolic adaptations in multiple disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Learning and decision making are driven by expectations of future outcomes, yet how outcome prediction is generated by the brain to learn and inform behavior is poorly understood. We propose to investigate this issue by using a model system for the study of reinforcement-based learning—the visual corticostriatal circuit—which affords control over inputs predictive of future outcomes, as well as inputs conveying the occurrence, magnitude, and valence of outcomes themselves. The goals of the work are to: 1) characterize corticostriatal signaling of outcome prediction and the circuitry producing it, 2) measure cholinergic and dopaminergic signaling of rewards and punishments and establish how reinforcement signaling teaches corticostriatal circuitry to report outcome prediction, and 3) demonstrate that this outcome prediction signal causally informs decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of Americans with speech disorders of various etiologies receive speech pathology services, but the efficacy of therapy is limited by an incomplete understanding of the brain mechanisms involved in speech sequence learning. Results from the proposed research will provide fundamental knowledge as to how speakers learn to produce new speech sequences that is ultimately necessary to provide more effective assessment and therapy for individuals with speech disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In our everyday lives, we frequently encounter situations we have never previously faced and yet are required to make an appropriate response on the first try. This ability to rapidly and flexibly ‘self-program’ is one of the hallmark features of human intelligence. The proposed studies leverage exciting new developments in neuroscience, neurosurgery, engineering, and artificial intelligence to understand the neuronal circuitry underlying this amazing capacity.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Children who are HIV-exposed but uninfected in sub-Saharan Africa are an important, vulnerable population that survive the early years but often do not thrive. We will evaluate the impact of duration of HIV exposure in utero, immune status at birth and the psychosocial environment on neurocognitive development in children who are HIV-exposed but uninfected. This study will provide detailed evidence to identify the highest risk children within this group and to guide the future development of interventions to improve the well-being of children who are HIV-exposed in sub-Saharan Africa and throughout the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary cause of death from an opioid overdose is respiratory depression. Opioid-induced sedation further impairs respiration through largely unexplored mechanisms. The outcomes of this project will provide fundamental insights into the neurobiological control of respiration, the influence of opioids, and will possibly identify new strategies to alleviate respiratory depression and stimulate breathing.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Simulation is a promising solution to improve the technical skills of obstetricians for managing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), a rare but potentially life-threatening birth complication that disproportionately impacts underserved women in the U.S. We propose a staged, multicenter study to trial three innovations to overcome common obstacles to widespread implementation: a novel, affordable medium-fidelity simulator; remote synchronous mentoring; and asynchronous mentoring. If successful, results will inform best practices, advance education and training standards, and enable nationwide dissemination, including in low-resource settings. 1

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Resistance to antimicrobial agents limits treatment options for bacterial infections and is a major public health concern. Bacterial ribosome is a major antibiotic target. By modifying antibiotic binding site within the ribosome, enzymes responsible for resistance block binding of antibiotics, rendering them ineffective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project will capitalize on an ongoing and well-established late life learning (LLL) program, the University for Seniors (UfS), in Beirut, Lebanon and will include 500 previously enrolled UfS participants, 200 participants to be newly enrolled in UfS, and 700 age- and sex- matched non-UfS-participating community residents. The resulting cohort will be prospectively followed and will include two waves of data collection to rigorously evaluate the relationships of LLL with cognitive function, Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), and other related outcomes in older age, whether these relationships are mediated by educational and social engagement, and whether LLL would modify the influence of earlier and lifecourse psychosocial exposures. Through a detailed capacity building program, this application will build research and infrastructure capacities to delineate opportunities for dementia prevention in Lebanon and other low-resourced settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJRCT NARRATIVE Allergic asthma often starts in early childhood and progresses into adulthood. The central mediator of recurrent disease exacerbation is lung-resident, T helper 2 memory cells. This proposal investigates age-related mechanisms that underlie the establishment of the resident, T helper 2 memory cells in the early lung. The results are expected to identify novel treatment strategies to modulate the progression of allergic asthma from childhood to adulthood.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Food insecurity is an important social determinant of aging-related health outcomes. Understanding the impact of food insecurity on cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) is of direct relevance to the mission of the NIH, and specifically the NIA. The results of this project will have significant implications for health care providers, public health practitioners, and policymakers to synergistically address food insecurity, improve healthy cognitive aging, and reduce health disparities among older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The interpretation of new variants, especially those revealed by genetic testing in the clinic, is difficult and hampers the use of genetic information to improve the diagnosis and treatment of disease. To empower variant interpretation, we propose the Center for Actionable Variant Analysis which would measure the effect of ~200,000 single nucleotide variants in ~32 of the most clinically important genes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Many conditions with adverse pregnancy outcomes, including ectopic pregnancy, are associated with abnormal placentation. About 1 in 50 pregnancies (~120,000/year) in the US is ectopic, and they account for 4 - 6% of all maternal deaths. In this work, a systemically injected nanoplatform loaded with magnetic nanoparticles will be developed to precisely detect and image placental tissue with MRI and, once within the placenta, generate heat under alternating magnetic field exposure to selectively and non-invasively treat ectopic pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Radiation therapy, along with surgery, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy, is the gold standard for treating lung cancer. Unfortunately, during radiation treatment of the lungs, the heart can become damaged. In order to decrease the risk of heart damage, this proposed project will focus on establishing a clinical practice guidance model, based on pre-existing cardiovascular risk factors, to help clinicians choose the best type of radiation therapy and the optimal radiation dose for each individual lung cancer patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: After exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the subsequent clinical outcomes vary dramatically, from resistance to infection to severe TB meningitis. We will use genetic, genomic, proteomic, and bioinformatic strategies to examine the full range of this variation during the interaction with Mtb and its human host to discover mechanisms of resistance and susceptibility to infection and disease. Uncovering the genetic differences that underlie heterogenous clinical outcomes will lead to new insights into host-pathogen interactions, novel biomarkers for clinical management, and innovative immunomodulatory treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 illness is one of the greatest threats to mankind causing substantial mortality, morbidity and huge economic losses, and many suffer from effects of COVID-19 long after the acute infection is resolved. Effective vaccines offer the main path out of this pandemic but breakthrough infections and novel variants evading vaccines and causing severe pathogenesis are major concerns. Common genetic polymorphisms associated with COVID-19 illness and severity can be utilized to identify molecular pathways, genes and cell types driving disease pathogenesis. Our work here will identify functional COVID-19 GWAS variants, provide direct mechanistic insights and help define precise genetic-based severity risk scores in susceptible individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal will use young people as scientific partners to identify nicotine and tobacco- related misinformation on social media. In collaboration with these youth, we will then assess how interacting with this type of misinformation is associated with susceptibility—or being willing to try a nicotine or tobacco product—among youth ages 13-17, particularly Black, Hispanic, and sexual and gender minority (SGM) youth. This information will be used to develop messages to counteract misinformation, and we will assess how acceptable the messages are to young people through surveys and interviews.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental exposures can cause the accumulation of reactive oxygen species, which will lead to many diseases such as cancer and neurodegeneration. However, fundamental knowledge on how cells respond to this environmental stress is not fully understood. This proposal aims to carefully study how ubiquitin signaling participates in this oxidative stress response in humans, to promote new methods of mitigating disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to develop new chemical technologies for efficient preparation of fluorinated molecules, carbonyl compounds, and functionalized carbohydrates. These chemical entities are involved in every aspect of life and can be found in natural products, pharmaceuticals, dyes, pesticides, lubricants, polymers, clothes, and inhaler propellants. The accomplishment of the proposed research will create novel functional molecules to accelerate drug discovery and development, improve the quality of health care products, and promote the establishment of new materials for biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE The Johns Hopkins WRHR program will address the critical shortage of Ob/Gyn-trained researchers by recruiting junior Ob/Gyn faculty who demonstrate strong potential to become productive and independent physician scientists. The JH-WRHR Program leverages the abundant resources of Johns Hopkins University, the growing capabilities and research resources of the Department of Gyn/Ob at Johns Hopkins, and the critically important milieu provided by the national NIH-supported WRHR program. Together, these resources, coupled with a rigorously designed training program, will expand the pool of Ob/Gyn-trained researchers who will advance science of reproductive diseases, gynecologic disorders, obstetrical conditions, and cancers of the reproductive tract to improve the health of women.
