IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of adult-onset blindness and is linked to defects in the blood vessels of the eye. We have discovered that defects in a system (known as the angiopoietin signaling pathway) regulating vessels in the eye cause mice to develop a disease similar to polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy, the commonest form of late-stage “wet” AMD in patients of Asian and African ancestry. In this proposal, we will characterize the role of this system in disease, and test new drug candidates targeting the angiopoietin signaling pathway for treatment of polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a driver of cellular senescence in the brain and may contribute to neurodegenerative diseases such as AD. This project will allow the elucidation of the molecular mechanisms by which senescent cells contribute to neurodegeneration in the context of aging, obesity and AD. This knowledge could potentially lead to novel clinical treatments to counteract AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE These studies will explore connections between Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and a novel, non-cell autonomous, neuroprotective pathway involving lipid droplet formation in glia due to neuronal stress. The identification of pathways that contribute to AD-onset is likely a key component in the development of a successful therapy. By taking a multidisciplinary approach, our work will define the impact of glial LD formation on disease-risk, onset, and progression while considering the role of genes that are potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among females, reproductive mood disorders (peripubertal depression, postpartum depression, premenstrual dysphoric disorder, and perimenopausal depression) are prevalent and associated with substantial morbidity and mortality. Reproductive mood disorders are similar to other depressive disorders in symptom expression, but they differ in their greater predictability of affective state change resulting from changing reproductive hormone levels. Training the next generation of researchers in reproductive mood disorders will not only increase our understanding of the causes of these debilitating disorders and aid in the identification of therapeutic targets, but because reproductive mood disorders may serve as a model for studying affective state change, our comprehension of the causes of mood disorders overall will also be advanced.
PROJECT_TERMS: Mood Disorders;post-doctoral training;reproductive
PROJECT_TITLE: Postdoctoral Training in Reproductive Mood Disorders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mitotic cell division errors are a major initiating source of DNA damage that can trigger diverse forms of genomic rearrangements. The proposed research will utilize multidisciplinary approaches to investigate the origins of complex genomic alterations from fragmented chromosomes entrapped within aberrant nuclear structures called micronuclei. These studies will provide critical insight into the cellular and molecular mechanisms driving a spectrum of chromosomal abnormalities that underlie a range of human diseases and disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this proposal is to develop human age-relevant glial cellular models using direct reprogramming technology, in order to recapitulate age-associated phenotypes in brain aging and neurodegeneration and uncover novel underlying mechanisms. We propose to establish cellular models for brain aging and AD using astrocytes directly reprogrammed from fibroblasts of aged subjects and LOAD patients and co-cultures of astrocytes with other brain cell types. The proposed studies will likely help to define roles of glial cellular aging in brain functional deterioration during aging and uncover the underlying mechanisms, which could lead to the development of novel strategies to maintain brain health and reduce risk for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE An important aspect of successful genomic medicine implementation is developing effective approaches for screening at-risk family members after probands are identified, also known as cascade screening. A critical gap exists in our knowledge of the most effective method of delivering cascade screening. This study will compare contact by trained professionals versus the traditional, proband-initiated contact of relatives on the uptake of screening as well as the acceptability of the approaches by both probands and family members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The diversity, population size, and health challenges of metropolitan Houston provides an ideal setting for a NIMHD Research Centers in Minority Institutions (RCMI). The University of Houston (UH) proposes to establish the Helping Everyone Achieve a LifeTime of Health (HEALTH) Center for Addictions Research and Cancer Prevention to advance institutional infrastructure to pursue cutting-edge health-equity science. Investing in health-equity science has the potential to save lives and improve the overall quality and length of life for some of our most vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: This study is designed to investigate the status and longitudinal trajectories of maternal metabolic health and endocrine function for up to five years following pregnancy among women participating in the Puerto Rico PROTECT cohort study. Little is known about the health status of women after the postpartum period and until mid-life, despite emerging evidence that this life stage may be influential with respect to long-term metabolic health outcomes. This study will fill this knowledge gap among a population at high risk for both adverse metabolic health and exposure to environmental chemicals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal describes the elucidation of how DNA damage is formed, what the consequences of damage are, and provide the inspiration for the design of agents that are useful tools. DNA damage is associated with the etiology and treatment of disease, such as cancer. Revealing the molecular basis for such diseases and their treatments is facilitated by understanding the underlying chemistry, and impacts human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study will examine the relationship between discrimination, stigma, medical mistrust, health care utilization and health outcomes among homeless older adults in a novel, longitudinal cohort study. Older adults experiencing homelessness may be more likely to experience stigma and discrimination based on various characteristics common in this population (e.g., homelessness, being ethnic/racial minorities, and experiencing substance use disorder and mental health problems) which, in turn, has been linked to medical mistrust. This study will fill the gap in knowledge about medical mistrust as a barrier to health care utilization in older homeless adults and provide a toolkit for practitioners to build trust in health care systems and providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lipoproteins are essential particles that transport fats to different cells in the brain. In individuals with Alzheimer's disease (AD), lipoproteins are not taken up by cells properly and instead bind to other factors outside the cell such as amyloid, leading to amyloid plaque formation, and damage to brain tissue and function. In this proposal, we aim to enhance the activity of the enzyme lipoprotein lipase (LPL), which can help specialized cells called microglia remove excess lipoproteins, prevent amyloid accumulation, and protect against the development of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because improvements in quantitative trait mapping in model organisms is ultimately expected to increase the ability to associate genotypes with complex disease-related phenotypes in human beings. The proposed work will focus on age-related declines in health and fertility, where improvements in trait mapping will potentiate new horizons for gene therapies. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains developing fundamental knowledge that will help to enhance health and lengthen life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative We propose a five-year, pragmatic randomized controlled trial to compare the effect of a clinic-integrated community health worker (CHW) intervention versus treatment as usual on HIV outcomes and social determinants of health (SDOH) among 300 Black people living with HIV (PLH) who are not virally suppressed (>200 copies/ml). To directly test whether an integrated CHW intervention improves rates of viral load suppression among Black PLH, we will carry out a randomized pragmatic clinical trial of 300 Black PLWH, of whom 150 will receive 12 months of CHW support and a comparisons group of 150 Black PLWH who will continue to receive usual HIV care. To determine potential changes, HIV viral load will be extracted from electronic medical records at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months; and validated SDOH assessments will be administered at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: This training grant encourages individuals who are underrepresented in the sciences to seek research careers in the biomedical research, including Hawaiians and other Pacific Islanders, Filipinos, native Americans Indians and Alaskan natives, African Americans, Hispanics, under-represented Asians (Cambodian, Vietnamese, Laotian), as well as those from disadvantaged backgrounds and disabilities. MARC-Hawaii is a two-year training program designed to provide 10 students per year with the technical, operational and professional skills they need to apply to, be accepted in, and successfully complete PhD and MD/PhD programs at research-intensive Institutions of Higher Education. These underrepresented individuals will bring diversity in backgrounds, life experiences, and ideas to the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Gains in life expectancy and population aging are driving a sharp rise in Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD), emphasizing the importance of identifying factors that can protect against ADRD risk and cognitive decline in older ages. We will study how education quantity and quality affect cognition and ADRD risk, and investigate the role of genetics in driving ADRD risk as well as in moderating the relationship between education and ADRD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Caregiving is commonly acknowledged as one of the most stressful, under-recognized, under- paid, and under-supported jobs. The new MapHabit System Caregiver Training Program (CTP) will offer a technology-driven caregiver training platform that will train caregivers to be more knowledgeable about memory and dementia while also learning to better manage their own stress and their quality of life needs. In this way, caregivers can be more innovative in their care strategies using person-centered wellness plans and thoughtful decision processes. Informed patient care reinforces effective caregiving, reduces patient emergency visits, hospitalizations, caregiver dropout, and reduces overall burden on the healthcare system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Female reproductive aging in mammals is associated with altered retrotransposon expression, and altered retrotransposon-mediated gene regulation. Using genomics, mouse genetics, cell and molecular biology approaches, we propose to comprehensively catalog the expression of retrotransposons and retrotransposon:gene isoforms during female reproductive aging, and to investigate their functions in regulating the aging of oocyte and somatic granulosa cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to identify a pathogenic pathway mediating fibrosis in age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Since fibrosis is a major cause of blindness in AMD patients, the proposed studies will enhance our understanding of this blinding disorder. The information generated from this project will also reveal a new drug target for the treatment of subretinal fibrosis to prevent vision loss in AMD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative (3 sentences). Advanced chronological age is the greatest risk factor for developing Alzheimer’s disease, the most common cause of dementia and the only top ten cause of death in America without an effective treatment. This research proposal will closely investigate an aging process that recently has been recognized for its role in Alzheimer’s disease, called cellular senescence. The results will reveal how cellular senescence changes in the brain throughout the adult human lifespan in health and during progressive stages of Alzheimer’s disease, which may unveil new targets for developing disease-modifying therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Testing for the presence of risk factors for type 1 diabetes in blood before symptoms arise helps reduce the occurrence of deadly complications, while also establishing eligibility for potential treatments that can delay or prevent the onset of diabetes. Enable Biosciences proposes to achieve FDA clearance and establish quality systems for an accurate test for diabetes risk that can use easy-to-collect dry blood spot samples. Such a test will allow more people to get conveniently tested for diabetes risk and determine their eligibility for potentially lifesaving treatments.

ORG_NAME: VISITING NURSE SERVICE OF NEW YORK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Family caregivers often act as an extension of the care team during home health care for older adults, yet their capacity and needs are not systematically assessed which limits their access to necessary support. This proposal would develop, refine, and pilot test a self-assessment intervention for the home health setting to improve communication and support between the care team and family caregivers to patients with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias. Proposed research and training activities would support the career development of Dr. Julia Burgdorf, whose career goal is to improve home- and community-based care for older adults by developing pragmatic clinical interventions to advance provider-led engagement and support of family caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  V(D)J recombination and class switch recombination are two independent site-specific gene rearrangement processes that are essential for a healthy immune system, and when either of these gene rearrangement processes sporadically fail in humans, malignant tumors can develop. These account for the most common malignancies in young children, and account for most of those arising from the blood cells (leukemia and lymphoma); moreover, inherited defects in these processes also occur, accounting for the most common congenital immunodeficiencies. This proposal seeks to understand the mechanistic basis for these sporadic and inherited failures, knowledge of which is essential to predict clinical consequences and to genetically correct many of the defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Reducing human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infections in the US, which are increasingly concentrated in Southern states with a large rural HIV burden, will require interventions tailored to local-level epidemic dynamics that address racial and ethnic disparities and underlying drivers of transmission. We will partner with three state health departments where we have established relationships (Alabama, Louisiana, and Mississippi) to develop a suite of HIV transmission models that link rural and urban region and incorporate insurance, access to health care, housing instability, and the opioid epidemic. These models will project the likely impact of interventions that address HIV as well as social determinants of health and opioid misuse, to fill an urgent, unmet need for evidence-based guidance in prioritizing local interventions in the service of ending the HIV epidemic in states with a large rural burden of HIV.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the high burden of epilepsies in sub-Saharan Africa, many commonly occurring epilepsies remain understudied and poorly characterized. This proposal focuses on improving our understanding of the role of host genetics and its relationship to exposure to Onchocerca volvulus, a commonly occurring parasite, in the manifestation of epilepsy. Advances from these studies will provide mechanistic insights into epileptogenesis of acquired epilepsies and new targets for developing preventive measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a major unmet need for the treatment of depression because current pharmacotherapies for depression require prolonged administration for clinical improvement and they are often associated with high non-response rate. Recent clinical evidence has shown that a single sub-anesthetic dose of ketamine, a glutamate-NMDA receptor antagonist, induces a robust antidepressant effect within hours of treatment in 70% of treatment- resistant patients, however a circuit and synaptic-level dissection of ketamine’s mechanisms of action is lacking. Accordingly, the goal of this proposal is to identify circuits, cellular and molecular determinants responsible for the rapid antidepressant action of ketamine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic variation can cause individuals to differ in how they respond to their environment, leaving some human individuals susceptible to particular complex diseases. By understanding the evolutionary forces causing genetic-environmental interactions we may better understand the genetic origins of complex disease. As technology advances, expanded personal environmental data will allow greater investigation of genetic-environmental interactions in human health, and the genetic signatures of environmental adaptation can be leveraged to make predictions and decisions for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (TB) is one of the top causes of mortality and morbidity from infectious diseases. With the ongoing COVID19 pandemic, TB care has been severely compromised across the globe, resulting in a sharp increase in mortality and morbidity. The proposed research is relevant to public health as it seeks to understand how alveolar epithelial cells in the lung communicate with innate immune cells to mediate early protection from TB and identify mechanisms that compromises these protective immune responses resulting in disease progression. The knowledge to be gained will have direct implications in designing therapeutics or vaccines to target such mechanisms to boost TB immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is a progressive, irreversible optic neuropathy with variable presentation and clinical course and we currently lack the ability to pre-symptomatically distinguish patients at risk of severe and progressive disease from those individuals unlikely to develop glaucoma-related vision loss. Using existing data from two large biobanks, this project will use cutting edge machine learning approaches to define POAG phenotypes aligned with disease subtype and progression, use these to discover novel disease related genetic associations, and test their utility for identifying glaucoma cases in independent cohorts. Ultimately, we aim to develop a precision medicine approach using imaging and genetic features to improve our assessment of disease risk for any individual.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias (ADRD) take an enormous toll on public health and are more prevalent in Black Americans than White Americans. Structural racism, and its lasting effect on the distribution of neighborhood factors, such as green space, may play a role in cognitive health disparities. The proposed project will investigate the relationships between structural racism, green space exposure, and cognitive health disparities, as well as whether these relationships differ in communities that have undergone gentrification compared to those that have not.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Thousands of people in the United States each year suffer permanent voice loss because their voice boxes (larynges) are damaged from nerve injury resulting in vocal fold paralysis and in these cases, we currently have no injectable or minimally invasive options to restore normal laryngeal function. In this application, we explore a novel injectable cellular therapy that promotes nerve recovery and restores function of the voice box (larynx) after laryngeal nerve injury. We believe our findings will completely transform current paradigms for voice restoration in patients who have suffered vocal fold paralysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Candidate HIV vaccines for therapy of people who were already infected have met with limited success in clinical trials. One possible explanation for poor results is the tendency of a therapeutic vaccine to further expand anti-HIV immune cells that are already exhausted by chronic infection, rather than eliciting new and more effective immune responses. We want to understand what features of the vaccine and host allow therapeutic vaccination to elicit a superior immune response that may control the HIV virus after daily antiretroviral therapy is stopped.

PHR: The Administrative Core provides organizational structure for the OmiT-HIV program project grant, which seeks to understand and improve immune responses to therapeutic HIV vaccines. If the program is successful then it will lead to better treatments for HIV infection, possibly including treatments that do not require daily ingestion of antiretroviral drugs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HIV therapeutic vaccines seek to elicit new T cell responses that are long-lived and have the capacity to kill HIV-infected cells in the body. However, little is known about the quality of the T cell responses elicited by leading therapeutic vaccine candidates. In this Project, we will deeply characterize HIV-specific CD8+ T cells before and after vaccination in unique cohorts of people and macaques in order to better understand what kinds of T cells are elicited by the vaccines and how they can be harnessed to control HIV after antiretroviral therapy is stopped.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic sleep loss and short sleep duration are epidemic in modern society, representing an important public health issue. The goal of this project is to identify biomarkers that link adverse cardiometabolic risk with habitual short sleep duration and to determine if sleep extension reverses such risk. We expect these findings will help identify people with elevated cardiometabolic risk due to habitual short sleep duration and could improve our ability to quantify, track, and reduce an individual’s risk of type 2 diabetes over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project will examine how an HIV-infected person’s metabolism can affect their immune response to a therapeutic vaccine. We seek to develop techniques for altering metabolism either systemically or locally, at the site of therapeutic-vaccine administration, to make responses better. If successful then this project will explain why some individuals respond well to therapeutic vaccines and others do not.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This study is designed to help improve the care of SGM with AD/ADRD in LTSS by conducting a rigorous study of the policies of LTSS agencies in Minnesota and by training the state’s LTSS workforce in SGM culturally responsive care. The study of policy will inform whether LTSS agencies need regulation or have already adopted SGM appropriate policies. The randomized controlled trial will rigorously test the effects of an in- person versus an online training program on improving SGM culturally responsive care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer's disease (AD) and AD-related diseases such as Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis-frontotemporal dementia (ALS-FTD) are incurable. Proposed studies will test function of GDE2 as a new pathway that prevents neuronal cell-cycle re-entry and nuclear envelope/nuclear pore complex breakdown, two causal mechanisms of neurodegeneration important in AD and ALS-FTD. Discoveries made will generate new understanding of disease mechanisms and have potential to identify new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because it will provide critical data on the pathways to intent to act and leverage points for influencing actual bystander behavior among those who report knowing someone at risk for self-directed violence (SDV), including how youth perceive the outcomes of their actions. Importantly, this study will also identify how exposure to SDV may be differentially impacting the helping behaviors and the impact of such behaviors over time for sexual and gender minority as well as racial/ethnic minority populations, information key to designing more helpful suicide prevention strategies. As a result, we would expect decreased morbidity from SDV, improved quality of life for SDV youth and their friends and families, and a widespread reduction in medical costs associated with SDV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental disorders are among the leading causes of disability and morbidity worldwide, including Brazil, where despite having a comprehensive network of publicly-funded, free, community-based mental health treatment, it is estimated that only 26% of people with psychiatric conditions successfully connect to community-based care. We hypothesize that the successful adaptation and implementation of an evidence-based model of peer support to Brazilian culture, will contribute to enhanced levels of engagement, improved continuity of care, and improvements in quality of life and wellbeing among persons living with SMI in Brazil. After this study, we will have established the feasibility, acceptability, safety and tolerability, of adapting a low-cost, culturally-responsive, evidence-based intervention to improve post-acute supportsfor people with SMI who access community mental health treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social connectedness is a promising target for slowing the progression of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The current proposal uses cutting-edge methods to determine how aging disrupts a key mechanism underlying social connectedness – social cognition. The project leverages the complementary expertise of an interdisciplinary research team to advance our understanding of healthy aging and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunosuppression is the key intervention that makes kidney transplantation possible, while it is also a significant risk factor for infection, cancer, and cardiovascular diseases, the top 3 causes of mortality among kidney transplant recipients. Immunosuppression individualization will improve the health and longevity of kidney transplant recipients by maximizing the protection against acute rejection while minimizing immunosuppression-related side effects; however, the scientific evidence to guide this practice is severely lacking. This grant will allow us to lay the groundwork for an evidence-based, patient-centered, and clinically relevant framework for immunosuppression individualization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impaired left ventricular relaxation or compliance, commonly referred to as diastolic dysfunction, is associated with the progression to heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, a devastating syndrome with poor prognosis for which limited therapeutic interventions currently exist. Pharmacological inhibition of histone deacetylases (HDACs), epigenetic enzymes that regulate chromatin-dependent signal transduction in the development of heart failure, have shown promise pre-clinically in the setting of diastolic dysfunction, however little is known regarding the HDAC isoform specificity and molecular mechanisms regulating this cardioprotection. The present proposal will leverage innovative small molecule inhibitors, genetics-based strategies for cell-specific gene ablation, and the integration of multifaceted state-of-the-art epigenomics and bioinformatics techniques to elucidate the cellular specificity and molecular mechanisms of HDAC inhibitor efficacy in diastolic dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Progressive degeneration of photoreceptors triggered by inherited destabilizing mutations in the rhodopsin (RHO) gene and consequently activated cellular stress response triggering apoptosis cause retinitis pigmentosa (RP), currently an incurable blinding disease. Therapeutic approaches to correct these impartments focus on the development of pharmacological chaperones that stabilize Rho to prevent this retinopathy. We propose here comprehensive biochemical, structural, and animal studies to develop a novel therapeutic remedy to counter RP pathology and prevent vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaccination rates vary considerably by race/ethnicity with rates for Whites at least six times higher than for any other group. Many factors contribute to these inequities in vaccination rates including differences in vaccine acceptance and intention, and related variability in social behavioral norms, knowledge, risk perception, trust, and structural barriers. This research will examine whether an intervention that is delivered by community health workers to provide education, help with behavior change, and assistance with navigating barriers to increase equal access to vaccination, is effective in increasing vaccination rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol abuse impairs the intestinal mucosal immune system which plays a critical role in maintaining the equilibrium of a highly complex gut ecosystem. This project is to investigate the mechanisms of how alcohol abuse impairs the intestinal mucosal immune function and induces dysbiosis in the development of alcoholic liver disease. The goal of this project is to explore molecular targets for developing therapeutic interventions.

PHR: Project Narrative Schwann cells not only form myelin that is critical for nervous system development, but they also perform several pro-regenerative roles after peripheral nerve injury. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Being able to see and measure enzyme activity in the complex context of live animals would enable entirely new investigations into the role these critical proteins play in health and disease. Seeing through the animal tissue requires using near infrared or, more recently, short-wave infrared wavelengths of light that penetrate tissues with minimal scattering, yielding very clear luminescent images. This project will use bioluminescent enzymes (luciferases) and semiconductor quantum dots to generate self-illuminating, enzyme-responsive, SWIR-emitting contrast agents optimized to non-invasively produce bright, clear images of enzyme activity in the context of the living animal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it could reveal strategies to target the combinatorial control of Notch-dependent promoter and enhancer elements in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, a cancer affecting both children and adults and in which Notch inhibitors have been proven to be too toxic in early clinical trials. We discovered that ETS1 promotes enucleation of many oncogenic transcription factor players at Notch-responsive elements. In this proposal, we will learn how these players cooperatively interact and find ways to disrupt these interactions to target oncogenic Notch transcriptional programs and circumvent the toxicity of pan-Notch inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The weaponization of Ultrapotent synthetic opioids (UPS) has made finding a novel reversal agent a priority. The current opioid response agent, Naloxone, is not as effective against UPS opioids and does not reverse one of it’s know effects, wooden chest syndrome. Using an advanced mouse population, with genetic diversity comparable to a human population, we will identify novel targets for the development of UPS opioid reversal agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HIV/AIDS remains an important health concern, despite significant progress in managing this chronic disease. Here we investigate one element of the viral life cycle, the translocation of the capsid across the nuclear envelope and into the nucleus of human cells, which is mechanistically poorly understood. The work in this project is designed to be translational in the long term and provide a basis to identify new molecular targets that might lead to specific treatments for patients in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cytosolic detection of viral nucleic acids elicits the activation of type I interferon (IFN-I) cytokines to foster an antiviral state. While a non-canonical NF-ĸB signaling pathway plays key roles in lymphoid organogenesis and B-cell homeostasis upon extracellular ligation by TNF receptor superfamily members, we unexpectedly found that intracellular cytosolic sensing of viral nucleic acids also triggers the non-canonical NF-ĸB pathway. The proposed research utilizes published data sets to identify and characterize a novel regulator of a key signaling component that coordinates cross-talk events between these two disparate pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Type 2 Diabetes (T2D) is one of the most prevalent and fastest-growing causes of disability, lost productivity, mortality, and health-care costs in the US and disproportionately afflicts ethnic minorities and particularly Puerto Ricans (PR). Recent evidence suggests that social stressors and/or protective factors may affect health via epigenomic modifications. Delineating mechanisms by which identified DNA methylation modifications and associated pathways relate to T2D risk will support the development of innovative strategies in public health to cope with environmental and social stressors and subsequently prevent T2D and related health disparities in vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: BENAROYA RESEARCH INST AT VIRGINIA MASON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to UV irradiation can lead to inflammation in the skin and cause disease flares in patients with cutaneous SLE. We have found that expression of a FOXP3 isoform lacking sequences in exon 2 (FOXP3∆Ex2) is increased in SLE. We have generated an animal model lacking this exon of Foxp3 and have found that these animals increased skin inflammation following UV exposure. This model will provide important insights into the mechanism of inflammatory skin disease and open up novel pathways for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Influenza viruses remain a global health concern due to yearly epidemics and their pandemic potential, therefore, understanding immunity to these viruses and further research on the development of improved vaccines is of high importance. The anchor epitope is a recently discovered region of the H1N1 influenza HA protein that elicits broadly neutralizing antibodies. In this proposal, we will computationally design scaffolded anchor proteins and test their immunogenicity and efficacy in animal models of influenza infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in DNMT3A and TET2 genes are common in the immune cells of elderly individuals and increase the risk for age-related comorbidities such as severe infections and cardiovascular disease. Efforts to identify factors that can be targeted to mitigate the pathogenic consequences of DNMT3A and TET2 mutations are hampered by their complex effects, which involve chemical modification of genomic DNA that subsequently affects gene expression and immune responses. To unravel this complexity, our study combines two state-of-the-art engineering approaches: (1) genetically engineered human immune cells and (2) mathematical modeling of gene regulatory networks.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Membrane trafficking of receptors is crucial for synaptic activity. This proposal will further test the hypothesis that a newly discovered trafficking pathway in non-neuronal cells, is also critical in neurons. In addition, this proposal will determine whether this new pathway is coordinated with a previously discovered pathway.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is an effective microbiome-manipulation based therapeutic for the treatment of recurrent Clostridioides difficile infection (rCDI). However, due to its undefined composition and dependency on human produced fecal samples for each transplant, FMT presents challenges with its scalability and with determining its safety profile. To accelerate the transition from fecal transplants to defined cocktails of bacteria (i.e., live biotherapeutic products; LBP), we will compare FMT with LBP for the treatment of rCDI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Central retinal artery occlusion is an acute emergency that results in retinal cell death via a number of mechanisms. Preventing retinal cells from dying is a major public health necessity. Our objective is to study mesenchymal stem cell secreted extracellular vesicles (EVs) as a therapeutic tool to prevent the loss of vision from central retinal artery occlusion, wherein we plan to develop functionally engineered EVs (FEEs) for retina- specific protective actions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Pediatric Restricted Cardiomyopathy (RCM) is a severe, childhood onset disease that causes heart failure and death and has no definitive treatment other than heart transplantation. This proposal uses human in vitro stem cell-based models of RCM to evaluate the therapeutic potential of a newly approved drugs that have shown promise in other forms of heart disease. The proposed mechanistic studies and drug testing are critical steps needed prior to clinical implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Receptors for glutamate, the main excitatory transmitter in the brain, come in three types of which kainate receptors, functionally, are the least well understood. Kainate receptors have been implicated in the signaling of pain, epilepsy, and mood disorders, and thus understanding more about this class of receptor is relevant to human health. Kainate receptors play a surprisingly large role in retinal signaling where both their function and interactions with drugs can be studied.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Cognitive dysfunction after surgery and anesthesia is a frequent, devastating complication in patients over the age of 65. Sleep disturbance around the time of surgery has been identified as an important risk factor but the mechanisms by which disrupted sleep contributes to impaired cognition after surgery is poorly understood. This research will investigate how neurons in the hypothalamus that regulate sleep-wake states mediate sleep- dependent cognitive performance after surgery and anesthesia, and test a novel pharmacological approach that can potentially benefit surgical patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative This project experimentally investigates how the amount, identity, and structure of genetic variation shape the fundamental biological process of adaptation. Using molecular genetics tools in natural experiments with Drosophila melanogaster to manipulate and observe adaptation in real time will provide crucial new insight into what dictates the pace and predictability of adaptation. The knowledge gained about the process of adaptation from these experiments is directly relevant to several biological dynamics influencing human health (e.g., vector-borne disease, human genetic variation, the dynamics of cancer), and to understanding how global change alters populations and ecosystems that are central to human well-being.

PROJECT_TITLE: Empirical tests of the contributions of genomic variation to the trajectories of adaptation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: The proposed project seeks to clarify the mechanism of action of tau antibodies in Alzheimer's disease and related tauopathies, and to develop novel therapies to target pathological tau protein in these diseases. The studies should provide valuable insight into tau pathogenesis, are likely to identify clinical candidates to target pathological tau protein for therapy, and will guide the development of other candidates by various companies. Hence, this research is very relevant to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations are heritable changes in the cellular genome and are key events in the induction of cancer, birth defects, and neurological diseases. Screening chemicals for their potential to cause mutation in a human- relevant assay offers an effective strategy for improving public health. The lack of a mutagenicity bioassay in human cells is a major data gap in the genetic toxicology test battery used by regulatory agencies for hazard identification and quantitative risk assessments. Current human cell mutagenicity bioassays are labor intensive and rely on 50-year-old clonal selection techniques. Error Corrected Next Generation Sequencing (EC-NGS) is a direct method for analytical assessment of mutagenicity with precise quantification of these very rare events in DNA. The focus of this Direct-to-Phase II SBIR application is to develop a New Approach Methodologies (NAMs) combining human cells and EC-NGS as an in vitro alternative to current regulatory mammalian cell mutagenicity assessment using rodent cell lines, and as an in vitro alternative to in vivo mutation assays. The development of human cell mutagenicity assays will be part of ScitoVation’s nonanimal Next-Generation genotoxicity assessment using NAMs and dosimetry to improve human safety assessments. We will accomplish this by defining experimental parameters to quantify the induction of mutations by EC-NGS in two distinct human cell lines: TK6 lymphoblastoid cells and metabolically competent human HepaRG™ cells. Although EC-NGS is highly innovative and a “game changer,” without integration into well-defined human cell-based systems and careful validation studies, its application in regulatory Genetic Toxicology is limited. Human TK6 cells are a well- established and validated cell line with worldwide acceptance for mutagenicity assessments. However, TK6 cells lack drug-metabolizing enzymes. Metabolically competent human liver HepaRG™ cells express Phase I and Phase II drug metabolizing enzymes and have been used to assess genotoxicity. However, the requirement for two rounds of cell cycling to fix DNA damage into mutations, the prolonged cell cycling time of 10-14 days, and lack of clonal selection techniques to quantify mutations in HepaRG™ cells have precluded the development of mutagenicity testing in HepaRG™ cells. In this SBIR, we aim to replace 50 yr. old clonal selection techniques to assess mutation in mammalian cells by using EC-NGS to quantify mutations in human TK6 and HepaRG™ cells. Specific Aim 1 – Define experimental parameters to assess mutagenicity by EC-NGS in human TK6 cells and validate TK6 EC-NGS as a replacement for current mammalian cell in vitro mutagenicity testing bioassays. Specific Aim 2 – Define experimental parameters to assess mutagenicity by EC-NGS in HepaRG cells and validate HepaRG™ EC-NGS as a replacement for in vivo mutagenicity assessment in rodents. Completion of this Phase II SBIR will produce two human cell-based mutation assays that can be used as a follow-up to bacterial mutation assays and as a NAM to reduce reliance on current in vivo gene mutation assays in rodents. These assays will be a cornerstone of ScitoVation’s NAMs-based vision on Next Generation genotoxicity assessment using human-relevant cell-based models and dosimetry for human safety and risk assessments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Chronic pain continues to be a major health, social and economic problem throughout the world, affecting an estimated 1 in 3 individuals. Current therapies for chronic pain offer only modest efficacy and/or have serious side-effects. As a result, there is a need to focus on treating pain, on preventing the development of chronic pain, and on research and development of novel treatments (including restoration of lost function and improvement of quality of life).

PHR: Project Narrative “NIA Collaboratories for Artificial Intelligence and Healthy Aging” or AHA Collab will serve as the coordinating center for AI and Technology Collaboratories for Aging Research (AITC). In addition to providing strategic leadership, efficient coordination, creative dissemination, and effective project management, review, evaluation, and reporting services, AHA Collab will feature AHA Combinator—an incubator that not only matches technologies with capital but also more importantly connects funded pilot projects with strategic and tactical guidance, resources, and mentorship. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Psychiatric disorders are prevalent and contribute to long-term social and occupational dysfunction, including poverty, homelessness, suicide and substance abuse, as well as chronic suffering and family burden. It is known that psychiatric disorders are caused by changes in the brain due to genetic and environmental factors, but the specific factors and brain changes causing psychiatric disorders are not well understood. Training psychiatrists-scientists who are able to lead cutting edge translational research projects will allow us to understand the causal factors and brain abnormalities involved in psychiatric disorders, and to develop better treatments and diagnostic and prevention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Wyoming IDeA Networks for Biomedical Research Excellence (INBRE) Program is funded by the National Institutes for Health National Institute for General Medical Sciences (NIGMS). The ultimate goal of Wyoming INBRE is to work with the University of Wyoming and Wyoming’s community colleges to promote the development, coordination, and sharing of research resources and expertise that will expand biomedical-related research and education opportunities and increase the number of competitive investigators in Wyoming. INBRE programs implemented are intended to enhance the caliber of scientific faculty at research institutions and undergraduate schools, thereby attracting more promising students to these organizations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Miscarriage is the most common pregnancy complication in the US occurring in 15-20% of clinically recognized pregnancies; current analytic approaches, however, depend on early pregnancy losses being identified in the medical system. Ambient air pollution is an increasingly recognized risk factor for pregnancy complications, but quantification of the impact on pregnancy loss is limited by these events being identified through medical records. We propose to use a novel approach, using the outcome metric of live birth-identified conceptions and a variation of the time-series design, to (1) investigate the association between air pollution and pregnancy loss, (2) identify critical windows of vulnerability, and (3) identify important maternal- and neighborhood-level modifiers of this association to inform targeted policies and interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Anxiety disorders such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) affect a large number of individuals with a significant portion of patients failing to improve with current treatments. The proposed project will provide first insight into the intracranial neurophysiological signatures of fear and anxiety in patients with varying levels of dysfunction and/or dysregulation of arousal and negative valence systems. Findings will address questions about the relationship between intracranial neurophysiological activity, neurostimulation, and physiological responses during fear-related states and help lay the foundation for future treatments for illnesses marked by debilitating anxiety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The use of electronic cigarettes has increased despite limited knowledge about their toxicity and health effects. We will recruit diverse e-cigarette users and non-users to evaluate the association of e-cigarette use with subclinical atherosclerosis (and also with endothelial cell health, blood pressure, and inflammation), the association of e-cigarette use with metal exposure, and the potential role of these metals to explain, at least in part, the cardiovascular effects of e-cigarettes. The findings will help fill a critical gap in the knowledge about the long-term effects of e-cigarettes and help guide e-cigarette regulatory action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-related liver disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide with limited effective therapies. This project is to investigate the roles and mechanisms of alcohol-induced peroxisomal dysfunction in bile acid synthesis disorder and the pathogenesis of organ damages. The goal of this project is to explore novel molecular targets for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Laryngeal diseases are common and have major impacts on human health, health care costs, and economic wellbeing. The larynx and vocal folds are lined by a protective epithelium that becomes deranged in cigarette smoke-induced laryngeal diseases. Our research focuses on determining the contribution of laryngeal epithelial basal progenitor cells to normal, injured, and diseased epithelium in order to develop therapies to prevent and treat cigarette smoke-diseased vocal folds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the Alliance Biorepository and Biospecimen Resource (ABBR) is to safeguard and facilitate the use of patient tissue and fluid biospecimens for practice changing cancer research. The ABBR helps to collect, process, and store biospecimens from patients enrolled on NCTN Alliance clinical trials. The ABBR distributes biospecimens for biomarker studies associated with Alliance clinical trials and for secondary studies proposed by the broader cancer research community. Members of the ABBR work with the NCTN and other NCI research networks, contributing scientific leadership to maximize the scientific impact of NCI biospecimen resources. Encompassing multi-PI, multi-institutional pathology and biobanking expertise and hundreds of thousands of high quality, densely annotated biospecimens from several decades of clinical trials, the ABBR represents an unequaled academic resource for translational cancer research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The availability of nanoparticles that deliver small interfering RNA (siRNA) have significantly expanded the specificity and range of ‘druggable’ targets making them promising agents for precision medicine in cancer. This is especially important for cancers such as triple negative breast cancer for which there are no targeted treatments. Our goals are to understand the role of the complex tumor microenvironment in siRNA NP delivery and function using clinically translatable molecular and functional imaging techniques as well as ex vivo imaging, to improve the delivery and outcome of siRNA treatment in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Many of our front-line, broad-spectrum antibiotics target the synthesis of the bacterial cell envelope and ultimately cause cell death via fracture of this structural exoskeleton. Therefore, determining the molecular basis for the mechanical properties of the cell envelope and, in turn, the mechanisms by which bacteria modify these properties to promote antibiotic resistance will provide brand new strategies to combat this crisis based on undermining the mechanical integrity of bacterial cells. Furthermore, the ability to manipulate the mechanical properties of the cell envelope will provide new tools with which to probe the mechanics of other important physiological processes important for pathogenesis, such rapid proliferation and adaptation to environmental fluctuations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Lockdowns to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) have had profound social and economic consequences. There is a critical need to better understand the economic consequences of lockdowns on mental health, social cohesion, and long-term adaptation, because these consequences have significant policy, clinical intervention, and community-level implications. Using a quasi-experimental multi-level longitudinal design, the proposed project will examine the interplay of broader social- contextual factors and individual social behaviors in response to COVID-19-related economic stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Lung transplantation is a life extending treatment for patients with end stage lung diseases; however, lung transplant is a relatively new field, and long-term outcomes are disappointing with only ~55% of patients alive at 5 years and many survivors experiencing disabling complications. As a result there are considerable gaps in the understanding of the clinical and biological process that impact upon long term patient and graft outcomes after lung transplant. In this application, we aim to extend follow up data to include detailed long-term graft function and patient centered outcomes on 4177 subjects from of the Lung Transplant Outcomes Group cohort, a multicentered cohort study with rich clinical data and a wealth of biosamples currently focused on primary graft dysfunction and other events occurring in the initial days following lung transplant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD), a severe progressive neurodegenerative disease of aging and the most common form of dementia, affects an estimated 30 million people worldwide. This in turn may ultimately lead to potential therapeutic interventions for the benefit of all those affected by AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Flexible coils improve patient comfort and can be formed into desired shapes to match the human anatomy of interest, exhibiting improved filling factor and signal-to-noise ratio, especially when imaging curved anatomies such as cervical spinal cord, pelvis, and hands. Although the challenges in building flexible coils have been solved, in practice, it is still an open question to make fully flexible coils since the balun or cable trap circuits associated with coils are still rigid and bulky. In this project, we propose a novel miniature (size as small as a chip capacitor, ~3×3×4 mm3) balun circuit that can be integrated with the coil’s feed circuit to realize fully flexible RF coils.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Proper formation of distinct types of neurons and glial cells in the central nervous system is essential for motor and intellectual function. The long-term goal of this project is to understand how oligodendrocyte lineage cells, which includes cells that wrap axons with insulating myelin, are produced by neural progenitors. Completion of the project aims will substantially extend our understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control formation of glial cells for myelination.

PHR: Teacher Enrichment Initiatives: “It’s Contagious! Promoting the Biomedical Workforce Pipeline through Infectious Diseases” aims to establish a novel model to promote the growth of a diverse future STEM education and workforce pipeline. Teacher and student participants in the programs proposed will be recruited from diverse San Antonio districts. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance MYC is a central driver of cancers and is a validated drug target, however, no MYC-targeted therapeutic is available despite over 35 years of pursuit because the MYC protein is considered “undruggable”. The MYC promoter G-quadruplex represents a novel target for MYC inhibition; the indenoisoquinolines provide an excellent clinically tested scaffold and the DDX5-MycG4 interactions represents a novel target for inhibiting MYC. If successful, our study will have important impact because it lays the groundwork to develop new anticancer drugs with MYC-targeted activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE - “Chemical Tools for the Investigation and Manipulation of Protein Glycosylation” Glycoproteins represent a large fraction human proteins that become modiﬁed by carbohydrates. The structure and levels of these carbohydrates often change in diseases, but the exact nature of these changes and how they aﬀect the underlying biology of diseased cells are extremely diﬃcult to determine with existing technologies. The goal of this project is to create new, facile tools that can be used by the broad scientiﬁc community where they can be applied to a range of biomedical investigations in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoarthritis affects members of almost every family in the United States. This project will examine gene expression patterns at tissue and single cell levels and regulatory mechanisms that characterize cartilage homeostasis and osteoarthritis in human knees. Data and insight generated from this proposal will provide new and important insights into the pathobiology and osteoarthritis, lead to new biomarkers, and identify more promising targets for therapeutic interventions to prevent or treat osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Small RNAs are critical regulators of gene expression and genome organization, pathways that are highly conserved across eukaryotic phylogeny. The goal of this project is to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms of RNA silencing so we can better understand its role in human development and disease. In particular, a critical function of small RNAs is transposon silencing, which, if unregulated represents a major threat to genome integrity and is associated with infertility, birth defects, cancer, and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research study uses DNA sequencing to find a diagnose for families with children with a rare disease who may not be able to afford DNA sequencing studies. We use clinical testing, followed by more extensive computer technology and genetic research using the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster to study genetic variation in patients with rare and undiagnosed disease. The study will allow new insights and a better understanding of rare diseases which often provide insights into common disease as well.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Young women between the ages of 18 and 22 have high rates of undesired pregnancy and many interventions designed to reduce undesired pregnancy rates rely on faith-based approaches. In this project, we will assess whether highly religious young people differ from their less-religious peers in terms of their sexual behavior and contraceptive use, and how those differences work together to influence the risk of young pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. NARRATIVE Mental illness is a major health problem; The Stuart T. Hauser Research Training Program in Biological Psychiatry and Social Psychiatry provides research and mentor-mentee opportunities, as well as core and individualized curricula, that are critical for developing the next generation of scientists in biological, developmental, and translational psychiatry. This program, ending its 42th year, will train the most diverse and talented young investigators, and equip them with the tools and knowledge needed to succeed in developing their own research so that they can better understand, treat, and ultimately prevent and possibly cure mental illness. The relevance of the program is that we need to improve the health care of those with mental illnesses and this can only be done by investing in the next generation of clinical researchers who will make mental illness more tractable via novel discoveries that lead to improved treatment.
PROJECT_TERMS: Biological Psychiatry;Research Training;Social Psychiatry;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Stuart T. Hauser Research Training Program in Biological and Social Psychiatry

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE The need for rigorously trained statistical scientists and data scientists in cancer research is massive and continues to increase. In addition to advanced coursework in biostatistics and epidemiology the interdisciplinary training program will give trainees who are obtaining a Ph.D. in Biostatistics or Epidemiology (i) a solid understanding of cancer biology, (ii) experience and ability to communicate and collaborate with cancer scientists, (iii) understanding of recent developments in cancer requiring innovative statistical research and (iv) independent research skills. The aim of the University of Michigan Cancer Biostatistics Training Program (CBTP) is to increase the participation in cancer research of the new generation of biostatisticians who are educated not only in the powerful methods of modern statistics and data science, but also in the biology and epidemiology of cancer, the current body of knowledge about the etiology of the disease, its prevention, detection, natural history, and treatment.

PROJECT_TITLE: Biostatistics Training Program in Cancer Research

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The goal of this training program is to train psychological clinical scientists to conduct research that will promote the scientific and training priorities of NIMH and enhance the public health. Clinical psychologists are well-qualified to promote the translation of research findings to the clinical setting in meaningful ways because they have been in the forefront of the development of efficacious treatments that incorporate evidence-based mechanisms associated with specific psychopathology. This training program seeks to capitalize on the unique foundational skill set of clinical psychologists and to further equip these scientists to make meaningful scientific contributions to enhance mental health across the lifespan.
PROJECT_TERMS: Clinical Research;Psychologist;Research Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Clinical Research Training for Psychologists

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) arises from aging-associated acquired mutations in hematopoietic stem cells that expand in the bone marrow giving rise to white blood cells with increased inflammatory activity. This project investigates the hypothesis that CHIP driven by DNMT3A mutations increases the severity of periodontal disease. If confirmed, this knowledge has medical significance: screening of the elderly for CHIP may identify individuals with increased risk for periodontal disease and such patients may benefit from preventive treatments aiming to block the aberrant expansion of CHIP mutant clones and their harmful impact on periodontal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using a patient centered approach, our studies reveal a potential protective player that may influence one or more astrocyte functions critical for support of neuronal functions in the context of migraine. Accordingly, this proposal seeks to understand how the GPR37L1 signaling pathway conveys this protective function using an innovative combination of genetic, biochemical, electrophysiological, and animal modeling approaches. Ultimately, we expect the findings will identify new avenues for improving prevention and treatment of migraine, for which current medicines are inadequate for a large segment of the population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Compared to the general aging population, older persons with HIV (PWH) experience higher rates of chronic aging-related conditions, including frailty, diabetes (DM), and cardiovascular disease (CVD) The proposed research will examine longitudinal associations between levels of soluble biomarkers of the Senescence-Associated Secretory Phenotype (SASP) and frailty, DM, and CVD among a cohort of older PWH. The findings from this study will provide pilot data regarding potential biomarkers associated with development of frailty, DM, and CVD that can also be used in future interventional trials using senotherapeutic agents to prevent or alleviate these conditions in PWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is important to study how aging and cellular senescence affect persistence of the HIV reservoir to inform strategies to cure HIV-1 infection. Preliminary observations made by our group suggest that age is a key determinant of reservoir dynamics on long-term ART. In the current proposal, we will leverage a rich repository of stored blood samples and extensive clinical data from the AIDS Clinical Trials Group A5321 cohort, a longitudinal cohort of individuals who have had viremia suppression on ART for an average of 14 years (IQR 12- 17 years), to determine whether the dynamics of the HIV reservoir are associated with age, sex, and levels of cellular senescence markers in blood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Premature immune aging or immune senescence may be a key contributor to downstream end- organ damage in the setting of HIV and hepatitis virus infections. In this study we will characterize the effect of these chronic viral changes on biomarkers of immune cell aging and try to link these findings to damage to regulatory cells that help control normal immune functions. The effect of HCV cure will be examined.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Molecular Biophysics Training Program provides competitive graduate students at the University of Washington with rigorous training in modern biophysics and application of state-of-the-art physical and quantitative approaches to the studies of molecular and cellular systems with high biomedical relevance. The training program is uniquely positioned in the local biomedical research community by bringing together highly talented graduate students and training faculty from a wide variety of disciplines, such as Biochemistry, Chemistry, Cell Biology, Pharmacology, Microbiology, Physics, and Engineering. This interdisciplinary training experience affords future leaders of academia and industry to broaden their scientific horizons well beyond what they would normally learn in graduate school and prepare them to undertake rigorous and responsible research and commit themselves to pursue a scientific career in research and biomedicine-related areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The personal, public-health, and economic consequences associated with insufficiently treated opioid use disorder (OUD) are enormous, especially for vulnerable populations who face significant barriers to evidence- based care. While traditional randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have demonstrated the effectiveness of medications for OUD, their limitations in generating evidence that addresses the unique needs of these populations call for the development and application of novel methodologies to improve health economic RCT research designs. The goal of this project is to develop an empirical framework that integrates real-world evidence (RWE) into RCT data analysis using innovative maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) methods to produce more comprehensive, robust, and actionable evidence that can directly inform clinical decision-making and improve patient care for vulnerable individuals affected by the opioid epidemic.

PROJECT_TITLE: Novel Econometric Research Designs (NERD) to Help End Addiction Long-term

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the Rheumatic and Musculoskeletal Disease (RMD) Epidemiology and Outcomes Training Program at the University of North Carolina is to provide state-of-the-art resources and a rich environment to train independent interdisciplinary researchers who will improve our understanding of the magnitude, etiology, impact, and treatment of RMDs, and who will assume leadership roles in RMD epidemiology and outcomes research. The proposed Training Program supports the mission of NIAMS through advancing investigation into the causes, treatment, and prevention of RMDs; training scientists to carry out this research; and dissemination of information about research progress in RMDs. It is responsive to all four cross-cutting scientific themes described in the NIAMS 2020-2024 Strategic Plan (i.e., precision medicine, shared mechanisms of disease, incorporation of patient viewpoints, and involvement of diverse populations) and will help to attract and maintain a robust, diverse, scientific workforce.
PROJECT_TERMS: Epidemiology;Musculoskeletal Diseases;North Carolina;Outcome;Rheumatism;Training Programs;Universities
PROJECT_TITLE: The Rheumatic and Musculoskeletal Disease Epidemiology and Outcomes Training Program at the University of North Carolina

These scientists will have the skills to continue to study and work towards solving drug use disorders thereby supporting the mission of NIDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Surgical pain is a major clinical problem requiring new non-opioid treatment strategies. Here we will develop a peptidomimetic targeting NF-κB essential modulator (IKGKB, UniProt #Q9Y6K9) and test whether a peptide binding NF-κB essential modulator limits surgical pain in young and old rodents. This proposal can provide a non-opioid drug to treat surgical pain while also more broadly uncovering how NF-κB essential modulator contributes to inflammatory pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Progressive pulmonary fibrosis (PF) denotes a group of related diseases that slowly replace the gas exchanging units of the lungs with scar tissue, often resulting in respiratory failure and death. This Program will leverage a large and ongoing study of at-risk relatives of patients with Familial PF to develop a new level of understanding of the earliest stages of disease, prior to the onset of symptoms. Our goals are to discover critical mechanisms that underlie pre-clinical PF and to identify new targets that can be used in future studies aimed at preventing progressive PF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose the development of the Surgical Oncology Research Training at Indiana (SORTI) program to develop the next generation of surgical oncology-focused scientists. The SORTI program is anchored by our successful history of two-year dedicated research training by (1) a highly accomplished team of researchers and clinicians to provide tailored mentoring for the trainees and (2) the unique 15-year partnership in training surgical research trainees in conjunction with the American College of Surgeons’ Cancer Programs. The SORTI program will be a national leader in increasing the pipeline of qualified surgical oncology physician-scientists who go on to faculty positions, with independently funded research agendas, making seminal contributions to the field, and mentoring their own trainees, while also delivering high-quality, compassionate care to cancer patients.
PROJECT_TERMS: Indiana;Research Training;Surgical Oncology
PROJECT_TITLE: Surgical Oncology Research Training at Indiana (SORTI)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The Iowa Neuroscience Training Program emphasizes a highly interdisciplinary orientation, tied to the Jointly Sponsored Predoctoral Training Program in the Neurosciences’ mission to foster work toward the diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of nervous system disorders, and the basic sciences fundamental to this purpose. Our Program remains committed to training a diverse, quantitatively literate, and highly expert workforce of neuroscientists who will go into leadership roles related to the Nation’s biomedical and behavioral research agendas. The Program’s interdisciplinary training produces neuroscientists who are conversant across the many disciplines that comprise contemporary neuroscience.
PROJECT_TERMS: Neurosciences;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Neuroscience Training Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research into the causes of SUD has led to the identification of multiple factors that contribute to vulnerability and the hope for better treatments in the future. For this to continue we need to actively train the next generation of addiction researchers in multidisciplinary, translational approaches such that treatments can move forward from the bench to the clinic. The aim of this T32 is to provide these opportunities to postdoctoral researchers who plan to have a career in SUD research.

PHR: NARRATIVE The Biotechnology Training Program at Northwestern University supports a series of core activities for training a diverse group of students, nucleates the biotechnology community, and provides numerous training opportunities. The program addresses the interdisciplinary and rapidly changing nature of biotechnology training through coursework, research, experiential learning, industrial internships, seminars and other opportunities that broaden students’ training in and understanding of modern biotechnology. Innovative and unique training activities supported by the Program include events such as the Biotechnology Seminar Series, Biotechnology Practicum, Biotech Nexus, and many Professional Development Opportunities customized to promote diverse paths in biotechnology.

PHR: Project Narrative The overall goal of this project is to establish a premier CaREER (Cancer Research Education Excellence in Radiotherapy) program to train a highly diverse next generation of scientists, technologists and physicians who will be empowered to pursue careers involving research in emerging and transformative areas of radiotherapy. These transformative areas of research have major potential to address radiotherapy limitations in substantial ways, extend radiotherapy to curative treatment of both local and metastatic disease, and reduce disparities with innovations to reduce treatment time and cost, enhance patient convenience, and significantly increase survival and quality of life for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black women living with HIV (BWLWH; 40% unsuppressed) in Miami, FL (a southern HIV epicenter) and in the U.S. in general, need effective interventions to improve viral suppression. Unique and intersectional adversities (e.g., trauma, discrimination, stigma, gender-related stressors) faced by BWLWH are associated with mental health symptoms, medication nonadherence, and viral non-suppression, however there is no existing effective adherence intervention explicitly addressing their impact. The proposed randomized control trial (a) will assess the efficacy of Striving Towards EmPowerment and Medication Adherence (STEP-AD) in increasing viral suppression (via medication adherence), (b) is built on a successful NIMH funded K23 that provided strong preliminary evidence of acceptability, feasibility, and efficacy among BWLWH, and (c) may equip us with an evidence-based adherence intervention to improve viral suppression among BWLWH, a U.S. National HIV/AIDS Strategy designated priority population.
