IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Quantitative sensory testing (QST) and brain neuroimaging can both give important mechanistic insight into chronic pain, but they could be improved by a technique that can stimulate nociceptors in isolation. Our lab has developed a procedure for nociceptive-specific heating (NoSH) stimulation with no interference from innocuous warm fibers. Nociceptive sensitivity will be measured in patients with fibromyalgia, a nociplastic pain condition, and compared with data from pain-free controls, which may constitute a novel biomarker for use in other mechanistic studies and clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The major mission of this T32 is to train dedicated, motivated, and well-qualified predoctoral and postdoctoral fellows in aging biology and translational gerontology research. Given the projected increase in the number of older adults living in the US by 2050, it is critical that significant advances be made toward understanding the biology of aging and related diseases, and that these findings translate into enhanced care of older patients. The present T32 Program will provide state-of-the-art training in aging biology research to talented scientists, preparing them for academic careers at institutions throughout the country and equipping them to make novel contributions toward understanding the biology and enhancing management of disabling diseases of aging.
PROJECT_TERMS: age-related disease;aging related;Biology of Aging
PROJECT_TITLE: Biology of Aging and Age-Related Diseases

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative Zoonotic diseases like Monkeypox and Ebola virus disease are a significant public health threat in Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and have a high risk of international exportation. This project aims to improve the ability of DRC to respond to zoonotic diseases by developing rigorous surveillance systems, investigating medical countermeasures and clinical treatments, identifying key risk factors in primary transmission of disease, and creating a resilient interdisciplinary public health workforce.

PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CK-22-001, Investigation of Monkeypox and Other Zoonotic Diseases in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) - 2022

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Lupus Midwest Network (LUMEN) will improve our understanding of how kidney disease and antiphospholipid syndrome (a condition leading to recurrent blood clots) impact life expectancy, hospitalizations, healthcare utilization, and development of cardiovascular disease, infections, and osteoporosis in persons with systemic lupus. This work will inform interventions to optimize patient care, prevent or reduce poor outcomes in patients with lupus, and will identify a window of opportunity in persons with cutaneous lupus to prevent the transition to systemic lupus.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP22-002 Epidemiology of Lupus: Longitudinal Studies in Population-Based Cohorts - 2022

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed application will extend longitudinal follow-up of the California Lupus Epidemiology Study (CLUES) cohort, which is designed to advance our understanding of the natural history, biology, treatment and outcomes of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) among a racially/ethnically diverse population. Two special projects are proposed to investigative the metabolome during and after flare and the natural history of disability.

PROJECT_TITLE: DP22-002 Racial/ethnic and socioeconomic disparities in biologic and clinical SLE outcomes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Relevance) Lupus is a complex autoimmune disease that disproportionately afflicts women, particularly from minority groups. Significant racial health disparities remain and may be getting worse. Investigation into areas that will reduce these disparities is important for our population’s health and will inform us about how best to treat everyone with this condition.

PROJECT_TITLE: DP22-002 Georgians Organized Against Lupus: The GOAL of Better Understanding Social Determinants of Health in Lupus

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE Systemic Lupus Erythematosus is a life long autoimmune condition which can be life-threatening. Up to 20% of all Lupus patients are children diagnosed prior to 18 years of age. This study will utilize a large cohort of pediatric Lupus patients in a long-term United States registry to understand the disease, best treatments and what factors influences important outcomes important to both patients and providers.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: Project Narrative-Williams RFA-CK-22-004 Cases of tick-borne diseases continue to both increase and pose a threat to public health across the United States largely due to range expansion of native and invasive tick species. An integrated tick management strategy that includes the oral delivery of acaricides for systemic treatment of the major reproductive host (white-tailed deer) and major pathogen reservoirs (small rodents) has significant potential to be highly effective in suppression of host-seeking abundances of infected ticks over large areas. Acaricide-laced bait could eventually be commercialized and willingly distributed by homeowners or vector control professionals as millions of Americans currently spend billions of dollars annually feeding wildlife for their own enjoyment.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Suppression of Host-Seeking Ixodes scapularis Abundances and Interruption of Pathogen Transmission Through Orally Delivered Systemic Acaricide Treatment of White-tailed Deer and Peromyscus spp.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. HEALTH: Harnessing Epidemiology to Advance Lupus Treatment and Health Lupus remains a leading cause of death in young women, with racial/ethnic minority patients having worse long-term outcomes, including progression to end stage renal disease and overall mortality, and worse intermediate outcomes of disease activity, damage accrual, and quality of life. This proposal leverages our well-established, longitudinal, ethnically/racially and socioeconomically diverse, and phenotypically well-characterized cohort of 900+ patients with lupus to better understand the epidemiology of disease. The overarching goals include clarification of the long-term natural history of SLE by evaluating disease severity, morbidity, and multi-morbidity; assessment of disparities in illness experience associated with race/ethnicity, age, and socioeconomic status; novel collection of genetic biospecimens to identify targets to improve lupus care; and evaluating an innovative strategy to identify early kidney disease in high-risk patients.
PI_NAMEs: BUYON, JILL P;GOLD, HEATHER TAFFET;IZMIRLY, PETER  (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: DP22-002 HEALTH: Harnessing Epidemiology to Advance Lupus Treatment and Health

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Drug resistant TB strains are still able to successfully transmit despite the fitness cost associated with these resistance causing mutation. Elucidating how the transcriptome of rifampicin resistant mutants with or without compensatory mutations evolves within an in vitro and in vivo environment. Understanding whether different rifampicin mutations with or without a compensatory mutation effects the bacilli’s susceptibility to second-line anti-TB drugs and whether these mutants more rapidly acquirer drug additional resistance, will allow us to inform TB control programs on patient management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinically, we lack ways of identifying adults at high risk of adverse outcomes after a first venous thromboembolism, which is a blood clot in the veins including pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis. Adults who have experienced a venous thromboembolism may be at high risk for patient-relevant symptoms, a second venous thromboembolism, and death. In this study, we will characterize adverse outcomes in the 12 months after a first venous thromboembolism and will evaluate whether 3 biomarkers and 2 modifiable risk factors (anticoagulant type and physical activity) are associated with these outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As organisms age they lose the ability to maintain proper levels of viable proteins, a function termed proteostasis. We have shown that ultradian, 12-hour rhythms of nuclear speckle liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) dynamics are essential for proteostasis, and that these LLPS dynamics change during cellular senescence. We aim to establish changes to nuclear speckle LLPS dynamics as hallmarks of senescence and aging, and to demonstrate that these changes can be reversed genetically and pharmacologically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will address a critical need for effective intervention approaches for psychiatrically hospitalized suicidal adolescents, who remain at high risk for recurrent suicidal behavior and related crises following hospital discharge. Leveraging a novel sequential multiple assignment randomized trial (SMART) design, the project will identify an optimal technology-augmented adaptive intervention that will guide the delivery of post-discharge support—provided via text messages and booster calls—in an adaptive way that minimizes resources and burden. Findings from this study hold promise to inform urgently needed intervention strategies for reducing suicide-related outcomes among adolescents transitioning from inpatient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Skeletal muscle cells have a remarkable capacity to increase their size in response to exercise, and to decrease size upon inactivity, aging, or disease. Despite the importance of skeletal muscle cell size to its function, the mechanisms that regulate muscle cell size and its organelle scaling are poorly understood. We will quantify and mathematically model different parameters of muscle cell size in normal, hypertrophic, and atrophic conditions, determine how these integrate with neural activity and mechanical forces, and finally determine the functional definition of the individual myonuclear domains within the muscle cell in vivo and on a single cell level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic intestinal scarring and thickening, termed intestinal fibrosis, afflicts up to 40% of Crohn’s disease (CD) patients, yet there is no known cure and few treatment options. The fundamental processes underlying CD-associated fibrosis are unknown, partly due to the lack of relevant animal models that recapitulate this complex disease process. Our lab has developed a novel CD inflammation-associated fibrosis model driven by a metal-binding small molecule of the gut microbiota. The objective of this project is to define the mechanisms by which this metal-binding molecule promotes fibrosis and link microbial metal scavenging with fibrogenic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The epithelial lining of the gastrointestinal tract forms a regulated selective-permeable barrier and controls immune defense, which can be significantly compromised by conditions such as inflammatory bowel diseases, ischemia, mechanical injury and surgical procedures. Epithelial intercellular junctions play a pivotal role in barrier regulation. This proposal seeks to identify the molecular basis by which intercellular junction proteins control barrier function in health and disease, and will also identify how these proteins control repair after injury. Knowledge gained from these studies in the short term will provide a better understanding of basic mechanisms that control epithelial barrier function and wound healing, and in the long term, these studies will aid in the development of new therapeutic strategies aimed at strengthening the barrier and in promoting mucosal wound repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative  Foreign-born Latinos in the United States are at risk for poor health outcomes, including poor outcomes for cardiovascular disease. It is uncertain whether or not they receive fewer prevention services for cardiovascular conditions, and if so, which specific factors may be most responsible for the lower receipt of these services. This project will use a highly innovative electronic health record database that contains country of birth information and is linked to community information in order provide policy makers and healthcare providers better information about what cardiovascular prevention services their patients or community members are most at risk for underutilizing.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: Cannabis use and cannabis use disorder are increasing across the United States, and likely under-recognized among Veterans using VA primary care. This means that Veterans who would benefit from treatment and/or referral are not being identified. Cannabis is often perceived as harmless and marketed as helpful for a range of health conditions, despite a lack of evidence for these claims. Chronic health and mental health conditions that are common among Veterans, including depression, anxiety, posttraumatic stress disorder, and insomnia, are often reported as motivation for cannabis use. However, regular cannabis use may instead maintain or worsen these conditions and contribute to other health risks. This proposal will clarify relationships between patterns of cannabis use and physical and mental health outcomes, identify gaps in care, and assess the need for implementing screening for cannabis use in primary care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Atrial fibrillation is a common heart rhythm disorder, and it is responsible for up to 1.2 million Emergency Department (ED) visits per year, with an estimated cost of $6.65 billion per year in the United States. In appropriately selected patients per professional guidelines, oral anticoagulants (OACs) prevent strokes, yet clinicians rarely prescribe OACs during an ED visit, leading to delayed and fragmented care. By implementing a clinical decision support tool consistent with evidence-based guidelines and optimizing the tool through feedback from clinicians and patients, this research plan has the potential to improve both the transition of care for ED patients with AF and long-term clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE We will conduct new genetic assays of stored biospecimens from the Dutch Hunger Winter Families Study (DHWFS). This is needed to further examine the long-term impact of famine at the time of birth on the development of chronic disease in later life accounting for selective fertility and fetal mortality. Using the famine as a model, the study will significantly increase understanding of how perinatal insults affect health in aging, opening new avenues for intervention to prevent and reverse damage caused by perinatal insult. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement/Project Narrative Sickle cell disease affects millions of people worldwide, and is characterized by painful vaso-occlusive crises (VOC) that cause great morbidity and mortality. Although the main molecular mechanisms causing VOC are known, there are no ways to image them in humans, which hampers clinical research and care. We propose that positron emission tomography (PET) imaging targeting important molecules responsible for VOC will allow precision medicine approaches to transform clinical care, and new endpoints for clinical research of this disease that primarily affects underserved, minority populations in the US and elsewhere.

PHR: NARRATIVE Hurricanes Irma and Maria in 2017 killed over 1000 people in the U.S. territories of Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands. This proposal will develop an emergency preparedness plan to reduce morbidity and mortality due to diabetes, hypertension, and heart failure after natural disasters in the U.S Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regulatory T cells (Tregs) are suppressors of the immune system that prevent autoimmune diseases and also dampen immune responses to tumors. The goal of this project is to define the role of the BAF (BRG1-associated factors) chromatin remodeling complex in Treg function. The proposed research will further enhance knowledge of the epigenetic mechanisms that control Treg cells, which can potentially lead to the development of novel Treg-targeting therapies for autoimmune disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathology is defined by aberrant protein aggregation within the brain, underscoring the importance of neuronal protein degradation and the autophagy-lysosomal system. Of particular interest are the selective autophagy proteins optineurin (OPTN) and BCL-2-associated athanogene 3 (BAG3), which appear to be relevant in the degradation of neuronal tau protein. Therefore, this proposal aims to further the understanding of tau protein degradation via autophagy and define the molecular mechanisms governing OPTN and BAG3 regulation and function in neurons, which may lead to novel therapeutic modalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The hyperactivity of cell signaling pathways, such as the nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) pathway, facilitate cancer progression through the upregulation of cell survival and proliferative activities in numerous malignancies, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Recent reports have found that expression of the Cajal body marker protein coilin is elevated in ALL patients and that coilin positively regulates NF-κB signaling via coilin- mediated microRNA biogenesis. The investigations proposed here will uncover the molecular basis by which coilin is contributing to microRNA biogenesis and cancer progression via the NF-κB signaling pathway and will lay the groundwork for future studies involving therapeutic and biomarker development surrounding coilin- mediated cancer progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Understanding how evolutionary forces shape genetic variation for quantitative traits is crucial for determining the prevalence of genetic disease in human populations, but we lack a comprehensive view of how genotype by environment interactions (GxE) contribute to the maintenance of variation. I will address this gap by developing new methods for determining the evolutionary forces shaping GxE and applying them to large genomic and phenotypic datasets. This work will reveal the contributions of local adaptation, variation in evolutionary constraint across environments, and negative selection in maintaining GxE across natural populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular complications negatively affect the quality and quantity of life in cancer survivors. This project will explore the role that known cardiotoxic treatments have on cardiovascular complications and the role exercise may play in mitigating these late effects within a specific age group (those diagnosed between the ages of 15 and 20 years old) of cancer survivors. This award will support my development towards becoming an independent nurse scientist dedicated to understanding the effects of cardiotoxic treatments on adolescent and young adult cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During influenza infection, regulation of anti-viral T cells is necessary to promote clearance of the virus and prevent injury of the lung. Dendritic cells activate anti-viral T cells, and both dendritic cells and T cells express a regulatory protein called Tim3. A better understanding of how Tim3 controls immune cells during influenza could lead to new treatments for this disease and other respiratory viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NIH R35 GM118121; DNA transposons and alternative pre-mRNA splicing. D. Rio – PI. PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA transposons and alternative pre-mRNA splicing. D. Rio – PI Mobile genetic elements or transposons are found in the genomes of all organisms and 50% of the human genome is made up of transposable elements with ~ 2.7% corresponding to DNA-based transposons. Alternative pre-mRNA splicing is a common mechanism for regulating gene expression in metazoans. The protein factors involved in controlling DNA transposition and patterns of alternative splicing are found in the human genome, so results obtained in this proposal will have direct relevance and application to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Elucidating mechanisms that regulate erythroid differentiation continues to unveil fundamental discoveries that inform erythroid biology, hematology and broader mechanistic, biological and pathological problems. As mechanistic defects generate ineffective erythropoiesis, e.g. in bone marrow failure syndromes, sickle cell disease and other congenital anemias, which can be resistant to erythropoiesis-stimulating therapeutic agents, new mechanistic knowledge will provide the logic to devise efficacious strategies and advance technology to manufacture blood products from stem cells. Our multi-omic studies utilizing genetically engineered cultured cells and primary mouse and human cells will develop new paradigms to explain how GATA factors govern intracellular small molecule ensembles that control genome function and create feedback loops to regulate GATA factor function, hemoglobin synthesis and erythroid differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Drugs are designed to modulate the function of specific protein disease targets; however, there are currently no general methods for determining all off the unintended targets a drug may modulate leading to toxicity. In this project, we will develop a method designed to determine all the proteins to which a drug binds, which will enable chemists to develop compounds that engage the disease target with higher specificity. We will use this methodology to generate a new class of drug-like compounds that target an important class of cancer proteins; namely the histone deacetylases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Project Narrative The goals of the proposal are to identify novel genetic causes of autosomal recessive non-syndromic deafness in a large repository of families and confirm their causative roles in extensive functional studies. Identified mutations along with their associated audio-vestibular findings will be stored in an online database to facilitate further studies. The outcome of this proposal will expand the scientific knowledge on the genomic basis of deafness, provide better molecular diagnostic tools to the affected families, and identify potential treatment targets for hearing loss. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the dynamic cellular environment, high concentrations of small molecules and ions can change rapidly and dramatically over time and in different locations in the cell, but how proteins function in this shifting environment is poorly understood. For disordered proteins, which play major roles in diseases including cancer, Parkinson’s, and Alzheimer’s, such changes in the chemical makeup of the cell can have a major impact on activity and pathology. We propose to study how the cellular environment affects disordered proteins, linking their function to changes in the cell’s chemical composition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  If we want to unlock the potential of personalized medicine, we first need to understand the impacts of each of the millions of protein sequence variants that exist in the human population. We will create a set of recombinant DNA technologies capable of simultaneously testing thousands of protein variants per experiment while also being generalizable enough to be easily applied to study a wide range of disease- relevant proteins. These biotechnologies will be made freely available to other researchers, and the data we generate during the development will reveal how changes to cancer-related genes promote oncogenesis, and how cancer-driving genes evolve resistance to different approved therapeutics.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent girls and young women in sub-Saharan Africa have the highest rate of undesired pregnancies and HIV incidence (relative to other ages) but little is known about the dynamics of contraceptive use and of HIV-prevention behaviors among this vulnerable age group because face-to-face data collection (the predominate data collection approach in sub-Saharan Africa) is too expensive and time-consuming to collect repeated measures. Therefore, the impact of changing states (income, schooling, residential mobility) on contraceptive use and pregnancy desire, as well as how HIV risk perception changes contraceptive behaviors is understudied. Using cell phones to collect high frequency, longitudinal data is an innovative approach that will lead to new insights about the circumstances surrounding adolescent girls and young women’s sexual and reproductive health, creating actionable data for increased reproductive autonomy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project narrative Induction of specific retrotransposon families have been observed during preimplantation development of multiple mammalian species, generating numerous retrotransposon derived promoters that drive alternative, preimplantation specific gene isoforms. Using mouse genetics, next generation sequencing, cell and molecular biology, our proposed studies will comprehensively categorize retrotransposon-dependent gene regulation, functionally characterize specific retrotransposon in essential developmental processes, and elucidate the importance of retrotransposon in gene regulatory diversity among different mammals.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondria are the major energy producing organelles in eukaryotic cells and their dysfunction is implicated in many human diseases. AAA+ proteases help maintain mitochondrial activity by removing damaged and/or unneeded protein components in a timely fashion. This grant seeks to investigate how AAA+ proteases select and destroy specific mitochondrial proteins to shed light on the molecular basis of related human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to understand how cells repair one type of DNA lesion, the double strand break (DSB). DSB repair is essential for a broad range of cellular processes from DNA replication to innate immunity, while dysregulated DNA repair is a hallmark of cancer and other human diseases. Research described in this proposal will increase our understanding of a fundamental biological process and may improve gene editing and chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human reproductive health can be compromised both genetically or by exposure to myriad compounds found in prescription drugs, food containers and toxic waste products found in the environment. This work is significant because it will identify genetic and biochemical pathways that may be direct targets of these insults during gametogenesis. A detailed understanding of these pathways will aid in identifying the underlying causes of human infertility, birth defects and pregnancy loss by exposure to environmental contaminants.

PHR: Amputation is a devastating but preventable complication of diabetes and peripheral arterial disease. Rural populations have multiple risk factors for amputation, however there is very little research about this issue in rural communities. This project will use community engagement approaches to develop and assess an amputation prevention intervention in a high-risk rural community in West Virginia that will be applicable to other high-risk rural areas in the country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This NIA K76 Beeson Career Development Award resubmission application seeks to develop an electronic health record (EHR) measure (“eMeasure”) of low-value proton pump inhibitor (PPI) prescriptions among older adults, which would represent a timely and potentially transformative innovation in the quality of care field. The proposal also aims to design, pilot test, and implement an intervention consisting of a behavioral economic EHR-based clinical decision support tool to reduce low-value PPI prescriptions among older adults, informing a future NIA R01 application for a multisite pragmatic trial. The long-term goal of the project is to develop state- of-art and scalable methods to utilize the EHR to measure and reduce harmful, low-value care among older Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Research in high income countries demonstrates the neurotoxicity of ambient and household air pollution on brain development, yet data are lacking from sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) where exposure magnitudes are among the highest worldwide. We develop a prospective cohort and capacity building to understand early life exposure sources and impacts on child healthy neurodevelopment in Nairobi. We leverage a foundation of linkages between the University of Washington and academic and governmental stakeholders in Kenya to establish a sustained program to inform future clinical trials, screening tools, program and policy.

PHR: Project Narrative  Gallstone disease is one of the most common and most expensive of the digestive diseases in the USA. A major, but poorly understood, contributor to this disease is decreased function of the gallbladder muscle cells that are responsible for gallbladder function. This research will elucidate the mechanisms for decreased muscle function in gallbladder disease, and identify novel approaches to prevent and reverse gallbladder disease.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Veterinary Laboratory Investigation Response Network (Vet-LIRN) Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory Cooperative Agreement Program is designed to promote human and animal health by providing scientific information and building laboratory capacity for routine and emergency response for investigation of outbreaks and to investigate problems with animal feeds and drugs. Detection of outbreaks requires the ability to collect samples from geographically diverse areas. The objective of this proposal is to provide additional infrastructure in Texas to support collection and testing of samples from pets to support the FDA Vet-LIRN mission of protecting human and animal health by prompt recognition of outbreaks and testing of samples associated with outbreaks as well as surveillance assignments as needed by the Vet-LIRN Program Office.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Chemical Biology Training Program at Stony Brook University trains students to work at the interface of chemistry and biology and to apply quantitative skills to solve biomedical problems so that they can make major contributions to the health and welfare of the United States. The training program provides students with skills to communicate the significance of their work to the public and provides a venue for discussing career plans and developing plans to successfully pursue their chosen career path. Training in chemical biology provides graduate students with the chemical and biological methods necessary for developing new and improved diagnostics and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease affects more than 2 million American women of childbearing age, and is associated with decreased fertility and increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes. Planning for pregnancy prior to conception is advocated for all women but is especially important for women with kidney disease because of their potential complications. This research will develop and test a decision aid that will help women and their kidney doctors share information to support informed decision making related to reproductive health care and pregnancy in women with kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given that prostate cancer kills more than 350,000 men per year worldwide, there is an urgent need for development of more effective therapies for this disease. Bipolar androgen therapy (BAT) is an ideal backbone on which to layer additional therapies because it is associated with minimal biological and financial toxicity. The proposed research will explore metabolic vulnerabilities induced by BAT to identify metabolic synthetic lethal drug combinations that might improve outcomes for patients with prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parent mental health and caregiver self-efficacy can be significantly and negatively impacted by the trauma associated with a child’s PICU admission, affecting parents’ ability to help their child optimally recover. This research seeks to build a feasible intervention that will help PICU parents gain skills that help reduce immediate distress, which in turn, could reduce future parent PTSS and enhance caregiver self-efficacy. This is expected to have a positive impact by improving parents’ ability to support their child’s recovery and is relevant to the NICHD’s mission to lead research that enhances the lives of children and adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 50% of all cancer patients will receive radiation therapy during the course of their illness; unfortunately, bone is often in the direct path of exposure during treatment. As disease free survival continues to improve, bone damage from radiation which includes increased risk for fracture has become a prominent clinical issue. In this proposal we seek to aid patients by identifying unique molecular mechanisms and pharmacological agents which can be used to protect bone after exposure to radiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Oral microbiota are thought to play a significant role in determining the efficacy of therapeutic interventions using dietary nitrate. However, many individuals do not respond well to these interventions which we hypothesize is due to poor oral microbiotic conversion of nitrate to nitrite which is then converted to the important signaling molecule nitric oxide. This proposal aims at developing a probiotic that enhances oral conversion of nitrate to nitrite to improve interventions based in use of dietary nitrate and to understand the role of the oral bacteria in these interventions.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Veteran suicide rates have remained elevated compared with the general population over the past 20 years. The Veterans Health Administration has national care guidelines recommending an enhanced care package (e.g., increasing outpatient mental health visits) after a Veteran engages in self-directed violence. Adherence to each care component is considered a marker of care quality for suicide risk (i.e., suicide-related care quality). Recent studies find care components are not provided equitably to all Veterans. As the extant literature shows Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC) Veterans consistently receive poorer quality mental health care than white Veterans, they may also experience poorer suicide-related care. However, no research to date has examined suicide-related care for BIPOC Veterans. The current proposal seeks to evaluate suicide-related care quality among BIPOC Veterans using a concurrent, mixed-methods triangulation design to inform future intervention development and improve suicide-related care quality for all Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective muscle tissue repair requires a coordinated series of state transitions during muscle repair. Understanding how coordination is achieved is critical to understand tissue regeneration in disease and aging. We have developed an exciting and novel project that will identify and characterize an unexplored role of P16Ink4a in healthy replicating muscle stem cells.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: SOUTHERN ARIZONA VA HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: This study addresses a critical gap in quality of care for Veterans with heart failure (HF). Only 1/3 or fewer eligible Veterans are receiving SGLT2 inhibitors and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, both medications that save lives and prevents HF hospitalizations. We will combine insights from behavioral science and quality improvement science to create two types of ‘nudges’ – informational alerts and peer comparison feedback - to increase prescribing of these medications. We will compare the effect of these two nudge strategies alone and in combination compared to usual care. This project will develop simple, scalable, and low-cost strategies to improve the health of Veterans with HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Continued progress toward solving today's complex health and scientific questions requires diverse perspectives and skills, but the ethnic and racial diversity of the U.S. scientific workforce remains remarkably low. This research will improve our understanding of how aspiring scientists from different backgrounds make decisions about, persist toward, and succeed in various science careers. This project also tests a novel group coaching approach, based on early results and well-tested social science theories, that addresses theoretical and practical reasons for stalled progress in diversifying the faculty ranks of colleges and universities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis results in the deaths of millions of humans worldwide because of a dysregulated immune response to infection. There are no effective therapies for sepsis beyond antibiotics and supportive care, so there is great unmet need in advancing our understanding of the host response to infection. In this proposal, we will generate new understanding of how platelet production from the spleen contributes to the immune response in sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Nearly 40% of descendants from East Asia possess a genetic variant severely limiting their ability to metabolize reactive aldehydes. In addition, several other genetic differences in the lipid peroxidation pathway also occur in Asians which may impact organ injury, particularly during surgery. This project will develop tools in the basic science laboratory to better understand how genetic differences in the lipid peroxidation pathway may impact organ damage and translate these strategies to monitor and reduce organ damage in humans undergoing surgery.

PHR: This grant award will support the Medical Scientist Training Program (MSTP) at the University of Maryland School of Medicine. The mission of our MSTP is to train a diverse and creative cadre of physician-scientists who will become leaders in their chosen fields of research, develop new knowledge and translate it to enhance clinical practice. This training will serve the nation by developing physician-scientists who can accelerate the progress of biomedical research from the laboratory to the direct benefit of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Olfactory dysfunction is an early indicator of several major neurological diseases in humans including Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. As the loss of cholinergic neurons is a hallmark in both of these diseases, it is particularly important to understand the basic mechanisms by which cholinergic modulation affects the neuronal circuits involved in sensory processing and sensory discrimination which could help in the diagnosis and treatment of these diseases. This proposal will elucidate how acetylcholine release in primary cortical sensory structures impacts sensory coding, stimulus salience, and perception and will provide insights into sensory and cognitive impairments with disturbances in cholinergic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative About one-third of patients afflicted with epilepsy have repeated seizures, which dramatically increases the risk of unexpected seizure-related death (SUDEP) thought to occur due to suppression of breathing and heart rate. Here, we will characterize the negative consequences of repeated seizures on breathing and heart rate, pathological changes within brainstem regions critical for regulating these functions, and test interventions that may improve outcomes in a unique mutant rat with sound-induced seizures. Completion of these proposed studies will identify molecular pathways leading to cardiorespiratory dysfunction/failure in rats in order to develop new therapies in human epilepsy patients to prevent or reduced the risk of SUDEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Adductor laryngeal dystonia (AdLD) is a neurological voice disorder characterized by laryngeal spasms and increased vocal effort, symptoms that significantly impact patients' quality of life. Current medical management is not curative and involves invasive injections of toxin into the larynx several times a year to mitigate symptoms. The development of new, long-lasting treatments is hampered by a lack of sensitive and specific measures of vocal function in AdLD. This proposal will construct and validate automated measures of vocal function to facilitate future clinical trials to improve voice in AdLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Permanent, disabling hearing loss in children is most commonly caused by genetic mutations. Not all types of hearing loss are effectively treated by hearing aids or the surgical method of cochlear implantation and previous research has shown that patients with mutations in the gene TMRPSS3, one of the most common causes of genetic hearing loss, may have worse speech perception outcomes after cochlear implantation. In this grant, we aim to improve our understanding of the complex interplay between genetics and cochlear implant speech perception outcomes using human genomics, a new mouse model for TMPRSS3 genetic hearing loss, and a new gene therapy approach for this form of hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE COVID-19 is an unprecedented public health threat in modern times, especially for middle age and older adults with a chronic illness; beyond the threat of infection, the pandemic may have a longer-term impact on their mental and physical health. We have a unique opportunity to examine the psychosocial and healthcare experiences of a novel cohort of adults with chronic conditions - from before the pandemic’s onset through 5 years after - allowing us to inform public health and health system initiatives by identifying 1) individual risk factors of persistent self-management problems, and 2) viable, modifiable targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cells respond to their surroundings by perceiving extracellular signals, which trigger intracellular signaling events that shape how energy resources, including lipids, are allocated between fundamental cellular processes. The goal of this project is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which pro-growth signaling remodels lipid metabolism pathways to maintain organismal energy homeostasis. This work will identify new proteins and signaling networks that participate in metabolic regulation, as well as yield mechanistic insight into the underlying causes of a wide range of human metabolic diseases and cancers.

PROJECT_TITLE: Regulation of lipid homeostasis by proliferative signaling pathways

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: One of our long-term goals is to aid in the development of effective HIV cure strategies by gaining a better understanding of the host processes by which persistent reservoirs of HIV are established and maintained in the body despite long-term use of antiretroviral therapy. Notwithstanding the fact that the gastrointestinal (GI) tract is a major site of HIV replication and pathogenesis in people living with HIV, the relative contribution of the Gl tract to the HIV reservoir is unknown as well as the impact of the GI microbiome. Our objective is to implement an innovative in vivo model system to increase our understanding of how the GI tract and in particular how the presence of the GI microbiome contributes to HIV persistence.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The pandemic brought on by SARS-CoV-2 has profoundly impacted health and care for veterans, who are generally older, sicker, more rural, and more economically vulnerable than the overall U.S. population. Veterans are likely to face lasting risks related to disruptions of care and healthcare has been hindered by clinic closures, interruptions in public transportation, financial instability and self-imposed isolation. Veterans with chronic diseases may have missed medical appointments, lack access to critical prescription medication and routine monitoring of disease, resulting in poor control, serious adverse outcomes including lower extremity amputation and stroke, hospitalizations and mortality. These disruptions and varied responses across VA Medical Centers provide an unprecedented opportunity to examine the impact of widespread changes in care delivery on disease outcomes and the extent to which health disparities have widened during the pandemic. Results from this study will inform post-pandemic care throughout the VA and will provide a blueprint for responding to future crises.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Reducing and predicting unplanned readmission are major unmet needs of psychiatric care. This project will use electronic health record databases and computational linguistic approaches to develop a psychiatric specific temporal relation annotation scheme, create readmission prediction models, and compare against expert human performance. Developing readmission prediction tools could not only be used to help target the delivery of resource-intensive interventions to those patients at greatest risk, but also reduce psychiatric health-care costs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Antibiotics are among the most commonly used medications in pregnancy, yet the potential of teratogenicity and fetal toxicity of antibiotics in humans remains an area largely devoid of evidence. To address this critical information gap, we propose to generate high-quality evidence on the comparative safety of antibiotic treatment options for common bacterial infections during pregnancy by leveraging existing data on over 4.5 million pregnancies. The findings from this research will directly inform the treatment decisions regarding antibiotics selection in pregnant women and women of reproductive age who may become pregnant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Disruptions of sleep-activity cycles account for a wide range of diseases affecting behavior, neurology, metabolism, and muscle physiology. Circadian rhythms drastically alter animal behavior through a diversity of actions on cellular targets throughout the body. We will perform basic research in larval zebrafish to understand the mechanisms and interactions of circadian effects on cells and systems spanning the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Apert syndrome is a devastating genetic syndrome with abnormal skull development and strabismus, or eye misalignment. This research proposal will use a model for Apert syndrome to examine why patients have abnormal muscles around the eye and what might be causing their abnormal vision using state-of-the-art techniques in muscle biomechanics and genetics. Gene therapy will also be tested using this model to investigate innovative therapies for patients with strabismus in Apert syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance: Hypertension is fundamentally a vascular inflammatory disease that causes increased constriction and impaired relaxation of blood vessels. This inflammation is associated with excess production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and we found that LRRC8 family anion channels not only regulate the production of these ROS, they may also provide a pathway by which a very critical oxidant, superoxide anion, enters vascular smooth muscle cells and impairs vasodilation. This proposal will define the role of these channels in hypertension and identify novel therapeutic strategies for the treatment of vascular inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of diverse malignant hematological disorders that originate from hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs). Here, we will investigate the novel role of ALKBH5 in the maintenance of hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells (HSPCs) in response to oxidative stress, and elucidate the underlying mechanism. Our study will provide new insights into molecular mechanism that mediates the leukemic transformation of HSPCs, thereby leading to the identification of a new therapeutic strategy for targeting pre-leukemic stem cells in MDS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The outcome of this study will provide crucial insights into the neurobiological changes that could account for the broad range of psychiatric disorders in youth who have experienced high early life adversity, as well as the differences between those who are more versus less vulnerable. Knowledge of these factors and mechanisms would enable the early identification of at-risk youth, allowing novel and timely prevention strategies, and the development of personalized interventions for adversity-exposed youth that target the specifically affected neural and biological pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer research is dependent on the availability of high-quality biospecimens linked to patient information from clinical trials. The EET Biospecimen Bank will collect, process, bank, and distribute biospecimens from cancer patients enrolled on NCI-sponsored early-phase clinical trials. These biospecimens will eventually be used to study different types of cancer, and the results of this research will benefits patients through discovery of targeted therapy and/or improved outcomes and survival with the ultimate goal of cancer prevention and cure.

PHR: NARRATIVE The chromatin state at enhancers is well-defined, but it remains unknown how each feature of enhancer chromatin contributes to overall enhancer activity. This proposal will determine novel principles regulating p300 activity during pluripotency and pre-implantation development. Understanding developmental enhancer activation may provide insight into the pathogenesis of many diseases and syndromes in which enhancer dysregulation has been implicated, including developmental syndromes and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Black patients with lung cancer in the United States experience disparities in quality of care and outcomes across the spectrum of the disease. This proposal is relevant to public health because we will identify modifiable societal and health system factors that are associated with these disparities and learn about strategies to address racial disparities in lung cancer care directly from stakeholders in the community and health care settings. This research will provide concrete information about factors that perpetuate, and mitigate, lung cancer disparities, with the ultimate goal of providing equitable care for all lung cancer patients, regardless of race.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research focuses on extended family caregivers (i.e., grandchildren, siblings, nieces/nephews, step-kin) experiences with home and community-based services to assist with the care of older relatives with Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia. Its purpose is to gain an understanding of how extended family caregivers manage their care responsibilities, the informal support and formal services they use to meet the needs of their care recipients as well as to sustain their own well-being. Findings will extend scientific knowledge about informal caregiving beyond what has emerged from the extensive literature focused on spouse and adult children caregivers and provide new and highly relevant information for community services and programs designed to support family dementia care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Habitual consumption of a high-fat diet is a risk factor for diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Eating a fat-rich meal triggers a surge in blood lipids and inflammatory cells that can last for several hours. We aim to understand why a fatty meal has different effects in males and females, which may inform about the optimal preventive and therapeutic measures that should be taken for cardiometabolic disease in men and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular calcification is the pathological deposition of minerals in the walls of the blood vessels, leading to the hardening and increased stiffness of arterial walls, and increased cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. In this proposal, we aim to define the effects of endothelial cells from the adventitia, the outmost layer of the blood vessels, on the development and progression of atherosclerotic calcification, and identify the unique molecular signature of these adventitial endothelial cells. The completion of the proposed studies may pave the way to develop novel therapeutic strategies to selectively target these endothelial cells, thereby attenuating atherosclerotic calcification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Most small molecule pharmaceuticals contain multifunctionalized arene rings. Despite their prevalence in medicinally relevant molecules, it is challenges to synthesize these decorated arene rings in one step. This proposal aims to solve this problem through development of new aryne precursors, introduction of transition metal catalysts to solve problems with selectivity, and expansion of the scope of available aryne difunctionalization reactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Autophagy of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), called ER-phagy, is a selective autophagy pathway that clears misfolded aggregation-prone proteins from the ER to prevent their aggregation. Several ER shaping proteins linked to neurodegenerative diseases, including hereditary spastic paraplegias (HSP), are required for ER-phagy. This proposal addresses how sites of ER autophagy are formed on the ER and the relationship that ER structure has to the formation of these sites and to HSP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease and related dementias have devastating consequences for affected individuals and their families, and despite no clear ways to prevent or treat them at this time, there is increasing evidence that certain lifestyle and health-related risk factors during midlife are likely determinants of cognitive function in later life. Our MidCog study will investigate modifiable, psychosocial factors during middle age that are under-studied in cognitive aging research (e.g. health literacy, self-management capacity, health activation), but may be effective levers for optimizing personal health and self-care, promoting appropriate healthcare use, preventing chronic conditions, improving treatment adherence and ultimately preserving later cognitive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Mal de Débarquement Syndrome (MdDS) is a rare and under-recognized disorder that in most cases occurs after exposure to prolonged passive motion, but it is nevertheless counted among the most common balance disorders. Despite the overall improvement in MdDS outcomes since the recent discovery of the treatment method based on readaptation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex, substantially many patients do not benefit from this method. This project aims to further advance MdDS intervention by improving access to treatment with a portable device and by targeting physical and visual motion sensitivities as well as a subtype symptomatology of falsely sensed gravitational pull.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project explores the structural-molecular basis of communication between enzymes catalyzing consecutive chemical reactions in proline metabolism. These enzymes are increasing recognized for their roles in cancer and the virulence of pathogens, and mutations in proline metabolic genes cause numerous hereditary diseases. Understanding how the activities of proline metabolic enzymes are coordinated enriches our understanding of complex enzyme mechanisms and the multifaceted roles of proline metabolism in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The establishment and maintenance of healthy cells and tissues relies on the timely transport of numerous cellular factors to their respective subcellular destinations. Highly regulated molecular motors, such as cytoplasmic dynein, ensure the appropriate delivery of such cargoes such that the final destination matches the needs of the cell. The goal of our research program is to understand how dynein is regulated with a high degree of spatial and temporal precision to ensure that inappropriate transport, which is causative of various human diseases, does not occur.

PROJECT_TITLE: Regulation of Dynein-Mediated Transport

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this proposal is to bring nanopore sequencing technology to its fullest potential. With funding through this program, our group has developed core technologies that are now involved in industrial nanopore sequencing implementation. To be valuable in health care applications the base calling accuracy of nanopore sequencing must be continually improved. We propose several transformative improvements to nanopore sequencing that will increase the base calling accuracy to 99% and which will make nanopore sequencing more inexpensive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cocaine abuse and dependence remains a health problem in the United States; however, its pathophysiology is not clear, and treatments are inadequate. In order to develop treatments for cocaine use disorder that are effective and minimize side effects, an understanding of alterations that only occur in brain cells associated with cocaine seeking memories and not in brain cells responsible for other behaviors must be made. This career development application serves as both a training tool for the applicant (Dr. Gheidi) and an original research plan that addresses the critical need to explore treatments for cocaine use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Prestin, a voltage-dependent motor portion, is found in high densities at the basolateral membrane of outer hair cells (OHCs) where it is responsible for the process of electromotility, which boosts the sense of hearing particularly at high frequencies. Understanding the structure and function of Prestin will define the molecular mechanisms underlying cochlear amplification, a process that relates directly to health and disease. This information serves, not only as key element in the most basic aspect of various cellular sensory functions OHCs but has the potential to influence the way we address late onset and high noise-derived hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the well-documented risks of administering iodinated CT radiocontrast and gadolinium-based MRI contrast agents to renally impaired patients and the prevalence of heart disease renally impaired population, there is a major unmet need for new contrast media that is safe for renally impaired patients. Reveal Pharmaceuticals is developing a manganese-based MRI contrast agent (RVP-001) as safe gadolinium-free alternative (NCT05413668). The objectives of this proposal are to demonstrate that RVP-001 is functionally equivalent to Gd-based contrast agents in pig models of chronic ischemic and non-ischemic heart disease and to perform late phase clinical trial enabling toxicology studies in rats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The project aims to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying the etiology of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) caused by insulin resistance. By studying the role of hepatic ceruloplasmin (CP, a copper- binding protein) and copper in lipid metabolism and the development of NAFLD, we expect to gain novel knowledge on molecular mechanisms by which insulin resistance promotes NAFLD. Our hope is to facilitate the rational design of treatments for NAFLD, the most prevalent liver disease in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insulin is a potent mitogen, and hyperinsulinemia can promote and sustain tumor growth. In this R35 MIRA proposal, we will determine the function and mechanism of insulin action in chromosome stability, and investigate the structural basis and regulation of spatiotemporal insulin receptor signaling. This research will advance our understanding of a relationship between hyperinsulinemia, cancer, and diabetes, which is essential to develop novel clinical treatments for type 2 diabetes and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid use disorders are a substantial public health burden, with high rates of relapse, morbidity, and mortality, with existing treatments working for some but not all living with this addiction. This project proposes to test whether the strategic ectopic expression of a low-affinity mu opioid receptor, LAMuOR, can suppress the reward value of exogenous opioids of abuse without reacting to endogenous opioid peptides. If successful, LAMuOR could prove to be a novel translational strategy by which a single treatment would confer life-long protection from opioid use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Relevance to Public health Aortic aneurysms are life-threatening diseases characterized by progressive dilatation and rupture and are a significant cause of death in aging populations. Currently, there is no effective clinical treatment to prevent aortic aneurysm expansion and rupture. The proposed study will explore the roles, pharmacological effects, and the mechanisms of action of targeting different PDE1 family enzymes in the development and progression of aortic aneurysm. The translational value of this study is highlighted by the fact that PDE1 pan inhibitors are proposed for clinical trials to treat other diseases, suggesting an urgent need to characterize the potential outcomes of targeting different PDE1 isozymes in aneurysm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders can disrupt the ability to regulate both motor responses and arousal levels during unexpected, potentially threatening, or rewarding events, leading to excessive startle reactions, defensive postural tone, and psychomotor disturbances. Increasing evidence indicates that the cerebellum can learn to suppress or enhance defensive movements and arousal levels and that cerebellar damage produces impairments in both movement and the regulation of brain state, but little is known about the brain connections that coordinate cerebellar regulation of movement and arousal. This research project will use rigorous neural circuit connectivity, electrophysiological, and behavioral techniques to identify how neurons in the cerebellum regulate motor function of the trunk, neck, and eyes together with arousal levels in response to unexpected, potentially threatening stimuli; the results will provide critical missing information for diagnosing and treating arousal dysfunction in neurological and neuropsychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Children who receive less warmth, support, and responsiveness from their parents typically have higher inflammation levels, blood pressure, and allostatic load, indicators that predict future cardiovascular problems, reduced cognitive functioning, and risk for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). This project examines the significance of family experiences in adolescence for physical and cognitive health outcomes in adulthood by conducting a follow-up into midlife of the Sibling Interaction and Behavior Study (SIBS), a longitudinal study of 409 adoptive and 208 non-adoptive families. The adoption design of the study allows a strong test of the hypothesis that family experiences are linked to physical health and cognitive outcomes with downstream implications for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) risk through environmental pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Recent advancements in the understanding of regulation of bone remodeling, specifically through TGFβ-induced osteocyte perilacunar/canalicular remodeling (PLR) offer new insight into the maintenance of bone quality. This project seeks to elucidate the role of miRs in modulating TGFβ-mediated PLR and mitochondrial function, and whether these molecular processes may be leveraged to treat bone-remodeling defects. Understanding these molecular mechanisms in osteocytes may identify novel therapeutic targets to modulate bone remodeling and rescue bone quality defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Myocardial infarction (MI) and the progression to heart failure is a major public health concern that puts a large economic burden on the healthcare system. We propose an innovative approach to treat patients after an MI, where injectable biomaterials are injected into the heart early after MI to provide mechanical and biological signals that can improve the healing response. We evaluate our approach in a clinically-relevant animal model of MI, which if successful represents a translational therapy that could impact the welfare of many patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Pattern Electroretinography (PERG) is an important indicator of Retinal Ganglion Cell (RGC) health, and can be used to monitor the progression of degenerative retinal diseases such as glaucoma. The implementation of the proposed PERG device and analysis methods is expected to increase the accessibility of detection systems both clinically and in research. The improved stimulator and analysis techniques are expected to increase the diagnostic value of the PERG response by increasing the quality and quantity of diagnostic measures. As such, the proposed work will greatly impact public health by improving screening measures for glaucoma and potentially other retinal disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The rapid increase in obesity is a major economic burden on our healthcare system. Current therapies available to fight complications associated with obesity are insufficient, costly and entail risks. Our research aims to understand how fat tissue burns energy to reveal new therapeutic avenues directed at reversal of obesity-related diseases such as type 2 diabetes, stroke and heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Voltage gated sodium channels are essential for action potentials in excitable cells located throughout the body (central nervous system, smooth muscle, heart and skeletal muscle), and loss of, improper, or untimely function, can each cause or contribute to disease. There has been much controversy regarding the mechanism and interpretation of data for calcium modification of sodium channel gating due to: (1) the approaches used for investigation, and (2) knowledge gaps that arise from a lack of: (i) data describing the kinetic rate of the calmodulin interactions, and (ii) investigating calmodulin function in the presence of calcium transients. This proposal will uniquely combine structural biology, stopped-flow kinetics, and electrophysiology to dissect the precise roles of the calmodulin interactions in excitable cells, and it will then explore if we can alter the kinetics of these interactions with a small molecule probe; which could give rise to a novel treatment strategy for certain types of sodium channelopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: Opiate and stimulant addictions remain significant public health problems worldwide. Despite revolutionary advances in our understanding of their neurobiological basis, much remains to be learned about different etiological factors underlying addiction heterogeneity. We have identified a unique cohort of substance users characterized by predominantly monosubstance-dependent patterns of opiate and stimulant use and by protracted abstinence, which may help decipher some of the neurobiological risk factors associated with different types of addiction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it will result in a series of preliminary data that will inform future grant applications that aim to develop inexpensive and fast molecular robots to diagnose and treat diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Impairments in cognitive flexibility are a hallmark of many psychiatric and neurological disorders including schizophrenia, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, addiction, Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, where these deficits have been linked to functional outcome. A convergence of evidence across species indicates that GABAergic interneurons in the prefrontal cortex support cognitive flexibility in both humans and mice. This application investigates how this occurs in the adult, as well as developmental time periods and mechanisms enabling prefrontal GABAergic interneurons to properly wire into prefrontal cortical circuitry, to support the emergence of normal prefrontal network function and cognitive flexibility in adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The large double stranded DNA viruses, including herpesviruses and many bacteriophages which are directly responsible for antibiotic drug resistance, bacterial evolution and the ecology of the human microbiome, package their DNA into a capsid shell using a terminase enzyme. We propose studies designed to probe the essential features of genome packaging in these viruses, many of which play major roles in human health, morbidity and mortality. The results of this research will provide a better understanding of virus development a may reveal new targets for novel anti-viral therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Most genetic effects that impact gene regulation and complex traits act in trans, but very little is known about trans-genetic effects, largely due to the difficulty in detecting trans-QTLs. We propose to develop powerful methods to generate high-quality, comprehensive maps of trans-QTLs in multiple human tissues. We will use these maps to understand the molecular mechanisms of trans gene regulation and to identify new disease genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Ewing sarcoma and other Ewing family tumors are poorly treatable bone and soft tissue cancers diagnosed predominantly in children and young adults. This project is relevant to public health, because it aims to develop selective chemotherapeutics to treat Ewing sarcoma through investigating oncogenic mechanisms of the causative agent of Ewing sarcoma, transcription factor EWS-FLI1. This mechanistic inquiry will be complemented by pharmacological studies and aid the development of selective anti-Ewing sarcoma therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Influenza is a major cause of death in the US and evidence suggests that some patients die from overwhelming lack of ability to mount an anti-viral response, making people prone to severe lung injury. We have discovered a new model that may explain how the influenza virus first rapidly causes loss of a key receptor, called the interferon lamda receptor. We also discovered at the molecular level how the lung recovers to increase levels of this receptor. This discovery fulfills an unmet need in this critical illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The molecular mechanisms of triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells 2 (TREM2) in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) remain not fully understood, in part due to the lack of conclusive identities for TREM2’s endogenous ligands and the lack of a good understanding of how different endogenous ligands interact with TREM2 to affect TREM2 function. The central hypothesis is that AD- associated variants at TREM2 basic site allosterically regulate endogenous ligands bound at the hydrophobic site of TREM2, and allosteric co-stimulation by endogenous ligands at both basic and hydrophobic binding sites could enhance TREM2 immune activity in AD. New knowledge gained from this study will unveil the molecular mechanism of TREM2 interactions with endogenous ligands and could have high impact for AD research and treatment by opening an unrecognized avenue of targeting both TREM2 basic and hydrophobic sites to identify TREM2’s endogenous ligands and to promote TREM2-regulated immune activation for AD treatment.

PHR: We will be studying two proteins that are present in the small intestine and that have roles in the uptake and metabolism of dietary lipid, fatty acid-binding protein 1 (FABP1) and fatty acid-binding protein 2 (FABP2). Both FABPs bind fatty acids and endocannabinoids, and we will be identifying other important binding partners for these proteins, as well exploring as their actions in regulating whole body energy metabolism. These studies will provide new understanding of the relationships between intestinal lipids derived from the diet, and their metabolites, with body weight and body fat.t.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Ghosh, Arun K. Project narrative: The 2021 UNAIDS reports 38 million people are living with HIV/AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) in 2020. The HIV epidemic remains enormous, and progress requires new improved treatment. The present proposal details our design and synthesis of next generation innovative protease inhibitors to address critical problems of existing therapy against this global pandemic. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use disorder (SUD) is a major epidemic, and its impact may be particularly severe for women. One of the most striking examples is “the telescoping effect” wherein women meet criteria for SUD and/or seek treatment after fewer years of drug use as compared to men. Using a novel rat model of the telescoping effect, our goals with this competitive R01 renewal application are to characterize molecular shifts that underlie the telescoping effect with cocaine, and to determine whether, similar to humans, the telescoping effect also occurs with opioids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will examine the associations of extreme heat and wildfire smoke exposures in relation to life expectancy and DNA methylation. In particular, we will evaluate whether air pollution mediates the association between extreme heat and mortality as well as characterize differences in associations across vulnerable populations. The proposed study will be conducted among 112,000 participants from the California component of the Multiethnic Cohort Study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammation in the brain is involved in the pathology of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and alcohol use disorder (AUD). The goal of this project is to determine if heavy/binge alcohol use earlier in life can promote progression of Alzheimer's pathology. This project uses new and innovative therapeutic strategies to test this hypothesis and reverse alcohol-enhancement of AD pathology.
