IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mechanistic studies pertaining to sex-based differences in the metabolic syndrome are currently insufficient to explain and prevent the higher prevalence of certain metabolic conditions in women versus men and higher prevalence of other symptoms such as hyperlipidemia in men versus women. In addition, epidemiologic studies have reported that exposure to environmental chemicals such as persistent organic pollutants, including organochlorine pesticides, yield different health outcomes in men and women, and therefore, the current project aims to evaluate the underlying cellular mechanisms impacted by sexual dimorphism that potentially drive such differences. The concepts and information that will be gained from this grant will better address sex disparities in environmental health as well as provide health authorities with further knowledge to identify metabolic syndrome-related factors in susceptible populations and design sex-specific therapeutic strategies to better control future health care costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Role of somatosensory Dorsal Root ganglia (DRG) neurons innervating internal organs are underexplored. Specifically, the anatomy and function of these DRG neurons innervating fat pads have remained unknown. In this proposal, with preliminary data in hand, we will utilize various innovative molecular, imaging, and genetic tools to explore the role of fat-innervating DRG neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM), the most lethal and cureless primary brain tumor in adults, carries a notorious yet poorly understood capacity to suppress the host immune system and prevent immune cells from destroying and removing cancer cells. In patient and mouse models of GBM, we find that the primary cilium found on the tumor cell, an antenna/transmitter-like organelle, appears to attract specific immunosuppressive cell types that may keep anti-tumor T cells at a distance. This project will examine this association in detail and determine how the tumor-immune cell landscape develops in mouse and patient tumors depending on their ciliated profiles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many human behavioral disorders and mental diseases arise from naturally occurring genetic and molecular changes altering neuronal functions. By leveraging natural species diversity in a genetically and neuronally tractable system, our research program will establish the key missing links between the and underpinnings causal mechanisms natural behavioral variations, providing complementary insights into the genetic and molecular of human neurological diseases and human-specific behavioral traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite an increased prevalence of both feeding and anxiety disorders, the key neural inputs linking these two states, and the potential heterogeneity between males and females, remain poorly understood. This proposal will be the first step in defining the role of the melanocortin-3 receptor (MC3R) in the integration of feeding and anxiety which could ultimately lead to new therapeutic treatments for maladaptive feeding behaviors associated with obesity and eating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common genetic cardiac disease and causes a variety of major cardiovascular events such as arrhythmias, heart failure, stroke, and sudden cardiac death; however, effective pharmacotherapies to prevent disease manifestation or cardiovascular events are not available. In an ongoing, large multi-center cohort of patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the investigators will define the role of signaling pathway dysregulation in the disease pathobiology and the development of cardiovascular events by performing parallel transcriptomic profiling in both myocardium and plasma. This research has the potential to identify molecular targets for the prevention of disease manifestation and progression, and to offer novel approaches to specify high-risk subpopulations that benefit most from preventive interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemical reactions in cells require enzymes to proceed efficiently. Many enzymes need dedicated “helper molecules” called cofactors. When cofactors are deficient, our enzymes do not function correctly leading to metabolic disease. This project aims to understand how cells maintain appropriate levels of the essential molybdenum cofactor and cope with metabolic imbalance when molybdenum cofactor is deficient. Molybdenum cofactor deficiency is a rare genetic disorder that causes neonatal lethality in humans. Our fundamental insights into molybdenum cofactor biology will inform new therapeutic strategies for this and related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: The overarching goal of the “Partnership for Advancing Cervical Cancer Prevention in Women Living with HIV” is to improve the cascade of cervical cancer prevention for women living with HIV (WLWH) including increasing uptake of cervical cancer screening services, improving management of screen positive women, and optimizing precancer treatment outcomes, particularly in resource-constrained settings. Partnership members have established collaborations with a history of conducting successful clinical trials and impacting clinical care. As a CASCADE Research Base, we will provide impactful scientific and statistical direction for pragmatic clinical trials to be conducted at the CASCADE Clinical Sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: úú PROJECT NARRATIVE Point-of-care diagnostics have shown the potential to transform health care by the real-time screening of disease states and treatment outcomes as needed. Alongside the computational protein design of de novo switches and binders, this proposal aims to develop a new class of reliable, rapid, and inexpensive protein biosensors at point-of-care that generate measurable light or color signals only when mixed with patient samples containing disease biomarkers with a drop of patient specimens. By enabling detection, the proposed projects align with the National Institute of Health’s mission to reduce illness and disability and to advance basic research and medical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project narrative Osteoarthritis is an enormous and increasing public health problem that often involves multiple joints, and like many other complex chronic conditions, is not a single disease but a heterogeneous condition with various risk factors. This project will investigate the role of increased intestinal permeability (i.e., “leaky gut”) as a contributor to development and worsening of osteoarthritis at multiple joint sites in humans and a naturally- occurring osteoarthritis model in pet dogs, to advance our understanding of this nascent area of study, improve risk stratification, and lay the groundwork for novel therapeutic development. The proposed work, in a high- priority topic area for NIAMS (NOT-AG-19-037), represents a necessary step towards understanding risk factors and outcomes in this common and frequently debilitating condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: TB is the second most common cause of meningitis in sub-Saharan Africa and carries a 50% case mortality rate in part due to inadequate and/or costly diagnostic tests. The current testing paradigm leads to delayed diagnosis, reliance on empiric therapy, and poor outcomes. The overall objectives of this proposal are to improve TB meningitis outcomes by evaluating SILVAMP TB Lipoarabinomannan for TB meningitis (a test that may improve the speed and accuracy of TB meningitis diagnosis) and improving the understanding of the costs effectiveness of TB meningitis diagnostic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because ascending thoracic aortic aneurysms and dissections are frequent causes of death in the United States, largely because current medications are ineffective. The project is relevant to the NHLBI’s mission because it focuses on the treatment and prevention of life-threating cardiovascular disease; the development of new, effective medications would prevent the progression of aortic disease and save the lives of patients with these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The autoimmune disease giant cell arteritis (GCA) is an inflammatory blood vessel disease that targets the aorta and its major branches and causes blindness, stroke, aortic dissection and aortic aneurysm. This project seeks to understand the pathologic immune responses that attack the blood vessel wall and cause vessel occlusion and destruction. By applying new technologies to unravel the mistakes in the patients’ immune system and by defining how the artery itself supports the disease process, the project will aid in the discovery of novel biomarkers measuring the intensity of vascular inflammation and support the development of new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative    Transcription is a fundamental cellular process whose proper regulation is essential to establishment and maintenance of healthy cell states. Transcription of genes that control cell state involves dynamic formation and dissolution of large assemblies of protein and RNA molecules called biomolecular condensates. This project aims to provide important new insights into transcription by studying the biochemical features and regulation of transcriptional condensates.

PHR: Lay Narrative Birth defects that interfere with development of the brain and/or pituitary gland can cause hormone deficiency, intellectual disability, and death. Mice are an important laboratory mammal that can be used to understand the cause of human disease. We aim to characterize existing mouse strains that have brain and/or pituitary gland developmental defects to increase our understanding of the cause of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE How breastfeeding improves the health of children has been extensively studied, but the maternal benefits are not well understood. Multiple observational studies have linked lactation with reduced maternal cardiovascular disease in later life. This novel study will clarify the role of lactation in maternal health and may lead to identification of mechanisms activated during pregnancy and lactation, which may be targeted for interventions to prevent cardiovascular disease in women.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PD/PI: Takemaru, Ken-Ichi 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Infertility is a public health issue, affecting approximately 15% of all couples, and in about 50% of cases, a male factor is involved. The sperm flagellum is responsible for sperm motility and fertilization of the egg, but how flagella are properly formed remains poorly understood. Our research focuses on understanding the roles of Chibby (Cby) family members and their binding proteins in the formation and function of sperm flagella, thereby contributing to our better understanding of male germ cell development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will develop scalable and cost-effective gene therapy to elicit directed immunity against human immunodeficiency virus infections which impact tens of millions of patients worldwide. We are proposing to use gold nanoparticles to deliver precise genetic insertion of broadly neutralizing antibody genes against HIV in immune cells and repopulating hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells inside the body. This single step approach combines the latest CRISPR delivery technology with a new strategy to direct humoral immunity which could represent a one-time treatment with cure potential for persons living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  The proposed research is focused on understanding the mechanism of Hox function in regulating skeletal differentiation. Loss of Hox function impacts the ability of skeletal stem/progenitors to complete differentiation down the osteogenic and chondrogenic lineages via unknown pathways. The conserved, region-specific, expression of Hox genes in the skeletal stem/progenitors (MSCs) in all vertebrates, including humans, supports the significance and relevance of these studies and fulfills the mission and goal of the NIH to understand the processes of human growth and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Membranes are barriers of proteins, fats, and sugars that form the borders of all living cells on earth, and are essential to cellular viability; understanding how membranes function is crucial for many key areas of biomedicine including cancer, drug resistant infections, development, drug delivery, and energy production. However, future progress in membrane research requires that a new generation of scientists be trained who can combine approaches and concepts from many disparate fields such as physics, chemistry, biology, and computer science. The Integrated Membrane Program (IMP) training grant is especially designed to train scientists to integrate multiple approaches to address these next-generation challenges.

PROJECT_TITLE: Integrated Membrane Program (IMP)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hydrogen peroxide is a signaling molecule used by cells to sense, adapt and respond to their environment. We propose to investigate the mechanisms by which hydrogen peroxide signals at cell membranes and how this impacts cellular processes such as vesicular trafficking and migration which are important for in many human diseases. The results of these studies will allow us to explore potential new strategies for the prevention and treatment of a broad range of disorders including inflammatory diseases, cancer and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will produce high quality genome assemblies of An. squamosus and An. cydippis that are critical in understanding malaria transmission in Zambia. The resulting genomes will also be sufficient to develop a diagnostic assay for rapid screening of adults and any life stages where species-specific morphological features are not apparent. The new genomic resources for An. squamosus can be leveraged for studying mosquito vector behavior and devise effective control strategies of understudied malaria vectors in pre- elimination settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Chronic pain is a major public health problem, and there is a need for novel effective treatments that do not target opioid receptors. Acetylcholine is an important neuromodulator in the brain, and we found that its levels are reduced in descending pain control circuitry under acute and chronic pain conditions. Here, we will explore how pain reduces acetylcholine release, and whether reversing this maladaptive change can lead to novel analgesic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overweight and obesity is a associated with fatal diseases such as type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and cancer. Recent research shows that a special type of fat—called brown fat—is present in adult humans and it has a remarkable capacity to “burn off” excess calories (nutrients) rather than store them as fat when active. Adults with brown fat are often healthier, and to better understand why, we investigate here how brown fat uses different nutrients in response to the diverse stimuli that activate it with the goal of identifying therapeutic strategies to increase brown fat energy expenditure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how cellular behaviors add up to organ-scale phenotypes requires the ability to observe organs in their native contexts, with subcellular resolution, over sufficiently long periods to capture long-timescale processes. My lab has pioneered live imaging techniques that enable us to make long-term and longitudinal observations in the Drosophila midgut, a superb model for stem cell and epithelial organ biology. Here, we propose how stem cells array themselves to respond to and replace cells that are being eliminated from the tissue as well as how new, differentiating cells integrate into existing cellular networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: The mission of the Pittsburgh Biomedical Informatics Training Program is to prepare trainees to become outstanding leaders in biomedical informatics research, education, and practice, through world-class training with a focus on artificial intelligence and computing methods for biomedical problems. This proposed renewal will support upcoming predoctoral, postdoctoral, and short-term trainees in translational bioinformatics, clinical informatics, imaging information, clinical research informatics, and public health informatics. Enhanced plans for recruitment, outreach, and evaluation will strengthen and diversify our program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Because of the increasing threat of a terrorist nuclear attack or radiological accident, the US government is urgently supporting development of drugs to treat the hematopoietic acute radiation syndrome (H-ARS), which is the leading cause of death during the first 30 to 60 days following exposure to radiation doses greater than 2 Gy. The few drugs that have been approved by the FDA to treat H-ARS increase survival when administered within 24h of radiation exposure, but do not increase survival when administered 48h post-irradiation in animal H-ARS models. This grant further characterizes a novel drug and 3 drug combination that significantly improves survival when administered 48h following radiation exposure and potentially could become life-saving treatment options for a heretofore untreatable H-ARS population – patients who cannot be treated until 48h or later post-irradiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE K01 support will allow me to establish myself as an independent researcher on cardiovascular disease disparities with expertise in Bayesian nonparametric clustering techniques and nutrition epidemiology. Training activities will focus on deepening my understanding of cardiovascular disease epidemiology, nutrition epidemiology, and health disparities, enabling me to model and evaluate the role of modifiable exposures such as diet in understudied populations. My research activities will focus on developing methodologies to gain new insight into population-based dietary exposure patterns of US women and their contribution to cardiovascular health disparities, which will ultimately inform the development of nutrition policy interventions suitable for vulnerable subgroups to promote population health equity.

PHR: Project Narrative  State-of-the-art biomedical research is highly multidisciplinary, requiring contributions from a diverse group of researchers. The Chemistry-Biochemistry-Biology Interface (CBBI) Program at the University of Notre Dame has met the challenge for cross-disciplinary training and has produced researchers with a synergistic combination of highly rigorous scientific skills, a broad knowledge base across both chemistry and biological disciplines, and excellent communication skills. Our goal is to continue to train PhD scientists with the skillsets and knowledge to solve challenging and significant biomedical problems, regardless of discipline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UCLA Biomedical Data Science Training Program for Precision Health Equity is aimed at creating the next generation of scientists who are equipped to translate cutting-edge computational methods into practice for im- proving more individually-tailored medicine. Tapping into leading experts with significance experience in develop and translation of key methods, trainees in this program will have mentorship and learning experiences that establish a deep appreciation for both the technological and the social elements that relate to adoption of new approaches like precision heath. Through this training program, a new type of scientist able to realize the vision of precision health – for everyone – will be created with an ability to transform research into practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Numerous human diseases have as a major indication epithelial barrier dysregulation and the Ah receptor (AHR) has recently been shown to play an emerging role in the maintenance of epithelium and local immune status in barrier tissues, such as skin and the intestinal tract. We propose to identify and characterize the multiple sources of AHR ligands, determine the appropriate level of AHR ligand exposure that leads to optimal barrier tissue homeostasis and examine how low dose exposure to environmentally relevant potent AHR ligands may influence barrier tissue function. The possibility of using the AHR as a therapeutic target to enhance barrier tissue function will also be explored with a series of selective AHR modulators/agonist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Longitudinal, within-subject approaches, have the potential to increase sensitivity and specificity, improving the efficiency of clinical trials by requiring fewer subjects and providing potential surrogate endpoints to assess therapeutic efficacy. Unfortunately, exactly matching all acquisition details across time is difficult if not impossible in the face of software and hardware changes to scanners over time. In this project we seek to develop deep learning techniques that will rapidly and robustly detect subtle anatomical changes that presage cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias that are accurate for any combination of MRI scanner or acquisition type.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Integral membrane proteins are the targets of the majority of drugs used in the clinic, yet the mechanism of action for most of these drugs is not fully understood. One reason for this is that most mechanistic studies of membrane proteins extract the protein from its native membrane environment – akin to studying a soluble protein in a dehydrated state. The research proposed by our team will apply new technologies to identify and understand how the native membrane environment impacts membrane protein structure and function, which will inform new strategies to modulate membrane proteins pharmacologically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Each year 13- to 24-year-olds disproportionately compose the number individuals diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in the United States. Preexposure prophylaxis (PrEP), a once daily antiretroviral regime, is an effective method to prevent the transmission of HIV in adolescents at substantial risk for acquiring HIV, however, the effect of this regimen on the development of critical brain structures during adolescence is unknown. The proposed experiments will address the gap in knowledge that is the mechanistic basis of the inhibition of oligodendrocyte maturation by antiretrovirals in an HIV-negative, adolescent population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current treatments for depression, including cognitive behavior therapy (CBT) and medication, are not effective for many people, leading to a high global burden of depression. We propose to investigate the effects of a novel intervention approach, intentionally sequencing aerobic exercise immediately prior to CBT sessions to take advantage of the powerful short-term biological and psychological effects of exercise to increase the potency of the psychotherapy (termed ‘ActiveCBT’) using established and cutting-edge techniques to measure both specific and common factors underlying the antidepressant effect of CBT (ie, mechanisms of CBT). This series of studies will determine the potential of this elegant exercise priming approach to enhance key mechanisms of CBT (R61 project) prior to a larger replication of the trial that establishes the effects of ActiveCBT on overall depression outcomes while linking augmented mechanisms in ActiveCBT to better treatment effects (R33 project).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Every year, thousands of Americans die from cancers related to human papillomavirus (HPV). The vast majority of those deaths could be prevented with a safe and effective vaccine, yet many parents choose not have their children vaccinated when it is recommended at age 11 or 12. In this study, we will examine in a randomized trial whether earlier initiation of the vaccine at age 9-10 years will result in less parental refusal and higher rates of full vaccination at younger ages, before early sexual activity begins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias are an urgent public health challenge, since no disease-modifying treatments are currently available. The selective vulnerability and resilience of specific neuron types to these diseases can provide important clues for potential therapeutic strategies. The proposed research combines innovative approaches in human tissue as well as human cell-based and mouse models of disease to uncover mechanisms underlying selective vulnerability with the ultimate goal of identifying new therapeutic targets for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL COMPONENT Drug abuse, including tobacco, causes hundreds of thousands of premature deaths annually in the US, and is responsible for much human suffering. The research projects that our P30 Center supports seek to reduce this human toll, by understanding the factors that cause drug addiction, in order to develop more effective treatments and prevention programs. Since smoking tobacco, cannabis, and other drugs produces toxic substances, measuring human exposure to them is necessary to assess health risks, which we do using biomarkers, for people or human subjects using these drugs, and for some studies for people exposed to secondhand or thirdhand smoke, in order to guide public policy and reduce exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to study the factors associated with development of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP), and racial disparities in associated outcomes, in order to identify individuals at increased risk. With the availability of low cost sequencing techniques, we expect the number of individuals with CHIP to increase in future, and, it will be important to develop appropriate strategies to manage these individuals. Knowledge gained from the proposed study is expected to set the stage for interventions to inform management of CHIP and decrease the risk of associated adverse outcomes such as hematologic malignancies, cardiovascular disease and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE PHD2 is the central oxygen sensor in the pathway that controls the number of red cells in blood. We are still at an early stage of our understanding of how it works. We propose to study how PHD2 interacts with other proteins in this pathway in order to obtain a detailed understanding of how PHD2 controls red cell mass.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The formation of sperm and eggs with the “wrong” number of chromosomes is a key contributing factor to infertility, miscarriages, and birth defects in humans. The proposed project seeks to identify and characterize the mechanisms that contribute to sex-specific chromosome structure and chromosome separation in sperm vs. eggs. The completion of this project will advance our understanding of how the disruption of components that determine chromosome structure and separation contributes to both male and female infertility and to the development of birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Acute kidney injury is a common and serious complication among hospitalized patients and confers substantial risks of end-stage kidney disease and death. While dialytic support for severe acute kidney injury can be life- sustaining, outcomes are poor and methods to guide a safe rate of fluid removal during hemodialysis are inadequate. The objective of this work is to leverage noninvasive devices to simultaneously quantify the systemic and tissue hemodynamic response to fluid removal throughout hemodialysis to better understand mechanisms underlying adverse consequences of hemodialysis and advance the development of more precise approaches to the delivery of renal replacement therapy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Adequate language input is required for typical language development, however, NICU infants are at particularly high risk for experiencing a language deprived environment early in development and may spend weeks-to- many-months of a critical developmental period in this setting. Importantly, we know that the language environment in the NICU matters: the quantity and quality of language input NICU infants receive has been associated with positive short-and-long-term outcomes (e.g., alertness, attentiveness, verbalizations, vocalizations, language). In this proposal, the applicant will engage in mentoring, training, and research activities to leverage implementation science frameworks, health equity constructs, and psychological and organizational theories to refine a proposed causal model of parent and clinician intentions to use IDS with NICU infants in preparation for a Hybrid Type 1 (effectiveness-implementation) trial that emphasizes intervention accessibility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a primary medical concern due to the increasing prevalence in older people and a very high mortality rate upon rupture, there are no effective pharmaceutical treatments for AAA to date. We propose to define the protective roles and underlying molecular mechanisms of vascular smooth muscle cells specific BAF60c in the development of AAA, which will set the basis to target BAF60c or its downstream factors for AAA treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE One of the great challenges of modern medicine is to understand how environmental factors, such as diet, contribute to the increasing incidence of inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. We have recently discovered that the food colorant Red 40, the most abundant food colorant in the world, may be an important factor contributing to this phenomenon. Under normal conditions, consumption of this product does not induce disease, but if it is coupled to abnormal expression of the immune hormone IL-23 in mice, it can lead to development of intestinal inflammation that has many similarities with human IBD. In this application we describe a research project to study how one environmental factor (the food colorant Red 40) interacts with IL- 23, intestinal bacteria, and immune cells to cause intestinal inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Enhancing the resolution of the human genome has been one of the major drivers of the advances in biomedical sciences, which lead to the discovery of important factors of gene expression and dysregulations in diseases. My research program seeks to precisely locate, where on the genome and where in the cell, the control mechanisms of gene expression take place using high resolution RNA analysis. We will further apply these high-resolution maps of the RNA regulation in human immune cells from metabolic diseases and cancer immunotherapy aspects, which will lead to the discovery of novel target genes and disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic lung diseases are among the top contributors to mortality in the United States and have previously been linked to air pollution. The proposed research will leverage advances in machine learning to develop novel statistical methods for the analysis of complex existing data on air pollution and lung disease progression over time. By combining his expertise in causal inference and machine learning with newly obtained training in air pollution science and environmental determinants of disease, Dr. Malinsky will advance the state of environmental data science and establish himself as an independent investigator in the intersection of biostatistics, machine learning, epidemiology, and environmental science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Aedes aegypti is the main vector of dengue, yellow fever and chikungunya viruses, and is a model system for studies of other mosquitoes that vector arboviruses. Gene drive strategies to introduce pathogen resistance genes into wild mosquito populations represent a powerful new control strategy, but no means of safely testing them in the wild exists. Our proposal seeks a validate a novel self-elimination system in the dengue mosquito that is able to remove itself autonomously from the target population after successful invasion, paving the way to safely test this technology in future field trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative There is an urgent need to improve our understanding of the mechanisms underlying effective mucosal wound closure and develop new therapeutic strategies for mucosal wound healing. This proposal will advance our understanding of the role of the CD74 signaling pathway in intestinal epithelial repair and mucosal healing. The work is relevant to public health as the information gained may ultimately lead to effective treatments to heal the mucosa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although nicotine is the main addictive chemical in tobacco products, other chemicals in these products may also contribute to tobacco use. This study will examine whether the greater abuse liability of cigarettes compared to non-combusted products (for example, electronic cigarettes) reflects the presence of other chemicals in cigarette smoke and their neurobiological effects. These studies will help understand how chemicals other than nicotine contribute to tobacco addiction and might suggest ways to tailor medications to treat addiction to different classes of tobacco products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will assess long-term changes to health/lifestyle, advanced planning, and research engagement that Black and White patients with Amnestic Mild Cognitive Impairment (aMCI) make following disclosure of positron emission tomography-based amyloid and tau burden and associated risk of conversion to Dementia-Alzheimer’s Type. Healthcare access will be explored as potential barrier to or facilitator of behavior change. The project therefore addresses a critical ethical and practical challenge facing all AD researchers by determining whether, in the absence of validated treatments for DAT, biomarker disclosure itself may result in adaptive behavior change in patients from diverse racial backgrounds.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the success of standard antiretroviral therapy, the need for an HIV cure remains compelling, both to improve the lives of people living with HIV and to bring about the end of the pandemic. The “REACH: Research Enterprise to Advance a Cure for HIV” Martin Delaney Collaboratory comprehensive scientific plan aims to uncover mechanisms driving HIV persistence, including intrinsic resistance to cellular-mediated killing, to guide the development of novel combination approaches that can harness cellular immune responses to achieve durable remission and eradication of HIV reservoirs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Humans are frequently exposed to many hazardous chemicals in the environment, tobacco, and diet, some of which damage DNA and can lead to the development of cancer. Our mass spectrometry and software technology are long sought tools that will identify how multiple chemical agents link to DNA and will provide clues to the etiology of cancers for which environmental causes are suspected.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of Americans suffer from deficits in reward-seeking in the context of psychiatric disorders, such as major depressive disorder, schizophrenia, and substance use disorders. Stress can both exacerbate these disorders and directly cause reward-seeking deficits. In this project, we will use recent discoveries about inhibitory cells within a key reward circuit in the brain (ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens) to uncover the mechanism by which stress causes reward-seeking deficits and to discover ways to prevent and reverse these negative effects of stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The tendon-bone interface is critical for the transfer of muscle loads to bone in order to move and stabilize the vertebrate skeleton. The structure and size of the tendon-bone interface is sensitive to changes in muscle loads, yet the mechanisms that guide these adaptations remains largely unknown. This proposal will test the role of fibroblast growth factor (FGF) signaling in the cell autonomous and non-cell autonomous responses of the embryonic and postnatal tendon-bone interface in mice following changes in applied muscle loads.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Tissue-resident memory T cells (T RM) reside throughout the body and provide potent, front-line protective immunity. However, our understanding of the ontogeny, maintenance, and organization of these cells - their ecology - is incomplete. This project will integrate multiple modeling approaches and data from diverse experimental systems, including a unique human tissue resource, to provide a suite of modeling tools for defining the life-histories of T RM in both mice and humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a progressive scarring disease of the lungs with minimally effective therapies. This project is relevant to the overall NIH mission of public health because it identifies a specific potassium ion channel – the BK channel – as a novel enabler of myofibroblast activation and ultimately, pulmonary fibrosis. Targeting BK channels would be a new strategy for the treatment of this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Smell dysfunction and its neurologic consequences following viral infection remain poorly understood despite a growing prevalence following the current SARS-CoV-2 pandemic. Studying epidemiologic risk factors and the associations between smell loss and deficits in central neurologic processing present an opportunity to better characterize post-viral smell dysfunction, identify at-risk populations for preventative interventions, and inform future investigation into central brain circuitry processing of scents.

PHR: Project Narrative The ability to develop new drugs to treat diseases depends on our ability to manipulate biological complexity with precision and control. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on providing mechanistic insight to develop a new and more effective treatment strategy to overcome resistance to immunotherapy in glioblastoma (GBM), a disease with dismal overall prognosis. The proposal aims to determine key epigenetic factor(s) regulating myeloid cell-mediated immune suppression and to target these epigenetic factor(s) to overcome resistance to immunotherapy in GBM. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the National Institutes of Health’s (NIH’s) mission that pertains to identification of novel strategies to overcome resistance to immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative One key decision that humans and animals must repeatedly make when pursuing a goal is deciding when to stop, a decision process that can become dysfunctional in disorders ranging from attention deficit hyperactivity disorder to obsessive compulsive disorder to addiction. Here, we propose a study of the role of lateral habenula neural circuits in promoting disengagement from goal pursuit. Our findings will suggest new targets for potential therapeutic intervention in disorders associated with excess or insufficient commitment to goals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative In autoimmune encephalitis and paraneoplastic disorders, T cells play an important role in pathogenesis, but our understanding of this process is limited because identifying the antigen targets of T cells is difficult with current technologies. This project aims to accelerate T cell antigen discovery for these and other autoimmune neurologic disorders like multiple sclerosis with a new technology that allows the profiling of T cell responses at the single cell level in a multiplexed fashion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Humans carry enormous communities of non-harmful gut bacteria (the microbiome) which have a two-sided relationship with the foods we eat: on one hand, dietary components can disrupt these bacterial communities; at the same time, gut bacteria can change these dietary components. These activities intersect when we encounter food-borne infections, which impact tens of millions of people every year in the USA and are strongly influenced by both diet and the microbiome. This proposal presents a plan to understand how an individual's microbiome transforms (and is transformed by) dietary components in our food, and how these interactions determine the outcome of food-borne infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposal’s overall goal is to investigate the mechanism of a fundamental process necessary for biosynthesis of messenger RNAs, key intermediates in the flow of information from genes to proteins. This recently discovered process, termed telescripting, is crucial for protecting nascent gene transcripts and enhances cells’ ability to produce a great diversity of proteins they need for their functions and to changes in their environment. Telescripting changes can profoundly affect expression of genes associated with many diseases and knowledge of its mechanism will advance prospects of new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For a subset of patients with lung cancer, immunotherapy has led to long-lasting remissions. However, because the majority of patients fail to respond, increasing the efficacy of immunotherapy for non-responders remains a critical priority of cancer research. This project seeks to identify and characterize anti-tumor T cells in lung cancer patients, to inform the development of novel therapies that enhance the anti-tumor response for treatment non- responders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inhalation of aerosolized carfentanil has been used as a lethal agent (bioweapon) to cause respiratory disorder and death in humans. This proposal will determine the characteristics, elucidate the mechanisms, and provide a potential countermeasure of the respiratory disorder (death) in a rat model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enteroviruses and rhinoviruses evolve within picornavirus species groups. Viral RNA recombination, a form of sexual replication, contributes to the formation of species groups and to the ongoing evolution of viruses within species groups. Our study will advance our understanding of picornavirus species groups, reveal molecular features of viral polymerases that maintain species groups in nature, further elucidate the antiviral mechanisms of ribavirin, and provide opportunities to control or eradicate important pathogens such as polioviruses, rhinoviruses and EV-D68.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Candida albicans is the most common cause of human fungal disease, yet how it causes lethal invasive disease is not well-understood. We recently discovered a novel mechanism of immune modulation in which a Candida albicans secreted lipase, Lip2, drives virulence by suppressing an IL-17 antifungal immune response in deep tissues. In this work, we will build on these new insights to identify the host proteins that mediate this response, thereby producing a new molecular understanding of an invasive fungal pathogen causes disease and enabling the identification of new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Astrocytes are glial cells that interact with neuronal synapses via their distal processes, where they remove glutamate and potassium (K+) from the extracellular space following neuronal activity. Following traumatic brain injury (TBI), this regulation becomes disrupted and is thought to lead to neurological dysfunction. Here I propose to use cutting edge imaging, genetic, and electrophysiological approaches to determine how molecular changes that alter astrocyte function contribute to synaptic dysfunction using a training plan that will ensure my long-term success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Advancement in our understanding of molecular mechanisms of key molecules in the inner ear is a prerequisite to developing therapeutic strategies for hearing loss. The studies outlined in this proposal explore structural and functional effects of all eleven reported patient mutations in GIPC3 protein that have been identified to date as a cause of non-syndromic autosomal recessive deafness DFNB72. In addition, since GIPC3 is a previously unexplored molecular partner of other “deafness” proteins, our study will provide fundamental knowledge into the pathophysiological mechanisms of other forms of deafness that will help to reduce the burden of human hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy has revolutionized the treatment of relapsed and refractory hematologic malignancies; however, the immunologic impact and risk for infections and mortality following treatment have not been well-characterized. This Career Development Award focuses on applying advanced clinical epidemiology and simulation modeling to understand the immunologic impact of CAR T-cell therapy. Our overall objective is to identify predictive risk factors and cost-effective screening methods to allow for risk stratification, protocols for immunologic monitoring, and initiation of earlier interventions to mitigate the risk for morbidity and mortality and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative We are trying to understand how a single molecule, prestin, can influence the mammal's exquisite sense of hearing by studying its cryo-EM structure. We propose to study the influence of voltage and other manipulations that alter its voltage-dependent state to identify conformations that normally occur duing outer hair cell activity. This will aid in understanding how the OHC enables us to hear so well and in turn how we might combat pathologies of the OHC that afflict millions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neighborhood disadvantage is a potent predictor of youth risk-taking and aggressive antisocial behaviors (ASB). The proposed project will empirically evaluate methylomic modifications as one pathway through which neighborhood disadvantage leads to youth ASB. We specifically postulate that exposure to the physical (lead, cotinine) and social (harsh parenting, exposure to community violence) `active ingredients' of neighborhood disadvantage alter the development of the methylome, and in doing so, increase youth ASB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The research proposed here will investigate the feasibility of using novel applications of computer vision and cooperative control robotics to enforce virtual safety barriers in neurotologic surgery. Our long-term goal is to develop semi-autonomous, robotic methods to improve the safety and efficiency of neurotologic surgery, and open the possibilities for surgical interventions which currently are beyond the abilities of the human hand alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among the gynecological cancers, patients with ovarian cancer have the worst outcomes, indicating the need for new and improved treatments. Our published work has shown that high levels of DNA ligase I, a key DNA replication enzyme, correlate with poor outcomes and resistance to chemotherapy in ovarian cancer, and that specific forms of ovarian cancer are sensitive to a DNA ligase I inhibitor. We expect that the results of this grant will identify DNA ligase I as a valid target for development as a drug that will be used to improve outcomes for patients with ovarian cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emergency department clinical decisions vary widely for febrile infants, who are at risk for potentially fatal invasive bacterial infections; some infants may experience harms from under-testing or over-treatment. There is a gap in scientific knowledge regarding how clinicians make decisions for febrile infants and the extent to which key sources contribute to practice variation. Addressing this gap will provide a foundation for addressing NICHD priorities of improving care to febrile infants and promoting health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed studies are aimed at developing a fluorescence microscopy method to monitor, on angstrom-and-millisecond scales, three-dimensional conformational changes of proteins, such as ion channels, a class of proteins that enable specific types of ions to flow across cellular membranes to generate vital cellular electricity. The resulting data will in turn allow us to understand the mechanisms of these protein molecules, necessary knowledge for developing therapeutic agents such as antibiotics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We propose that available BH3 mimetic drugs such as navitoclax (targeting BCL2/BCLXL), and newly emerging BH3 mimetics that target MCL1, can be exploited in prostate cancer (PC) to lower the apoptotic threshold, and in subsets with certain genomic alterations or in combination with appropriate agents can generate marked apoptosis and hence durable responses. Identification of genomic alterations and optimal combination therapies that exploit these drugs and the unique vulnerabilities of PC cells, is the overall objective of this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The key enzyme in cholesterol synthesis, HMG CoA reductase (HMGCR), is controlled through multiple mechanisms, including regulation of protein degradation. This grant will investigate mechanisms through which UBIAD1, an enzyme that synthesizes a vitamin K form called menaquinone-4 (MK-4), modulates HMGCR degradation and elucidate tissue-specific functions of MK-4. Completion of proposed studies will provide insight into mechanisms for HMGCR degradation, therapies that reduce the incidence of cardiovascular disease and heart attacks, and significance of tissue-specific distribution of MK-4.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal seeks to unravel the molecular mechanisms underlying severe non-syndromic cochleovestibular and cochleovestibular nerve malformations. We will employ a comprehensive genomic analysis to identify the key molecular events implicated in the development of these malformations. Our proposed research promises to yield novel insights into inner ear development and can pave the way for the development of better molecular diagnostic tools and future personalized treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Human tumors are complex mixtures of normal and tumor cells. We propose to develop a photolithographic system that integrates image analysis with 3D printing to isolate nearly pure (>90%) tumor DNA from human cancer sections on a microscope slide. Mutation detection is much easier with highly pure tumor DNA, which should improve the reliably and reproducibility of precision oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper genome integrity and stability are essential as aberrant alterations to genome folding and gene regulation are related to congenital malformations and cancer. The proposed research aims to characterize how parental contribution determines genome structure and function, which can ultimately impact organismal viability and disease susceptibility. This increased haplotype-specific knowledge may inform new strategies for personalized genomic medicine, including diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Given the known serious consequences of uncontrolled blood sugars during hospitalization, this research proposes an alternative seamlessly integrates continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) in the hospital to test a dynamic and digitized, team-based approach to glucose management in an underserved and understudied, yet high-risk population. The Digital Dashboard is progressive, as it facilitates real-time, remote monitoring of a large volume of patients simultaneously; automatically identifies and prioritizes patients for intervention; and will detect any and all potentially dangerous hypoglycemic episodes in a hospital environment. Finally, our focus on clinical metrics (glucose control, infection) that are in-line with patient priorities and US hospital quality initiatives will increase relevance to healthcare systems and enhance incentive to adopt Cyber GEMS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have discovered that the statin drugs (‘statins’) induce airway smooth muscle (ASM) relaxation in disease models of airway hypercontractility. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE A wave of rural hospital closures and acquisitions in the past decade may have reduced access to primary percutaneous coronary intervention for ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction patients by disrupting transfer networks. We will use Medicare claims, original data on hospital closures and acquisitions, original survey data on emergency medical services pre-hospital STEMI treatment capabilities, and novel network analysis methods to estimate the effect of disruptions in STEMI transfer networks on through-network time to PCI (Aim 1), and choice of treatment and mortality (Aim 2). We will identify network characteristics that protect outcomes for ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction patients after disruption (Aim 3) and quantify the role of disruptions in health disparities for ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction patients (Aim 4). Our work will inform clinicians and policymakers about new ways to improve the health of rural Americans at risk for cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NEC is a serious intestinal disease that primarily affects preterm infants and is a leading cause of death among premature infants in the United States. In this project, we will address fundamental questions about why and how NEC occurs in a group of high risk premature babies upon postnatal exposure to NEC-associated environmental factors in combination with activation of antimicrobial immune responses. The knowledge generated is expected to pave the way for the development of novel therapies to prevent and treat NEC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Serious bacterial infections are among the most common medical complications of injection opioid use. Hospitalizations for these infections are common and represent opportunities for intervention. The proposed research is to develop a simulation model to project the long-term injection-related bacterial infections and overdose and assess the long-term clinical impact of novel hospital-based interventions that directly treat or modify risk associated with the underlying OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE A large body of evidence indicates that high-quality social relationships are correlated with decreased risk for morbidity and mortality from a range of disease outcomes and that poor-quality relationships or social disconnection are correlated with considerable risk for negative health outcomes. Although most of the work in this area is correlational in nature, it is often interpreted as if it is causal. This grant uses a genetically informed research design to help build an empirical foundation for public health intervention efforts around social relationships, health, and cognitive functioning that is based on strong causal inference.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE We have created an innovative clinical and translational radiofrequency ablation (RFA) collaboration to study RFA in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). This proposal is a phase II single-arm clinical trial to evaluate outcomes using repeated Endoscopic ultrasound guided (EUS) RFA that leverages our strong clinical and preclinical platform to explore immunotherapy strategies in combination with RFA to improve clinical trials and overall survival for patients with PDAC. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to part of the NIH's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will enhance health, lengthen life and reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will investigate RNA-protein interactions that are essential for healthy cells and will allow us to better understand how mutations in these systems result in genetic disorders and diseases. For example, defects in the U6 small nuclear ribonucleoprotein particle cause the genetic disorder poikiloderma with neutropenia and mutations in the Lsm1 RNA binding protein gene cause severe developmental delays and congenital defects. We are also studying the interaction of poly-UG (pUG) RNA with the protein TDP-43, which is associated with the neurodegenerative diseases amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, frontoral lobe dementia and Alzheimer’s.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Protein aggregation is a recalcitrant problem in the purification of valuable proteins for basic science and industry as well as in several fatal neurodegenerative diseases, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD), an Alzheimer's Disease-Related Dementia (ADRD). Our studies will enable a high-resolution mechanistic understanding of Hsp104 and Skd3, two enzymes that reverse aberrant protein aggregation. Realization of our goals will enable potentially transformative solutions to reverse protein aggregation in diverse neurodegenerative diseases, including ALS/FTD and other ADRDs, and allow facile purification of aggregation-prone proteins for critical basic, biotechnological, or pharmaceutical purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Patients with cancer represent one of the most vulnerable populations within our healthcare system, as treatment regimens and the attendant toxicities of (or lack of response to) therapies place cancer patients at high risk for adverse outcomes. The use of germline pharmacogenomic information offers a potential solution to better inform therapeutic decision-making. In this project, we posit that preemptive genotyping and point-of- care availability of pharmacogenomic information offers the potential to improve cancer care by identifying individuals at increased risk for adverse drug outcomes, allowing upfront tailored chemotherapy dosing and analgesic medication choices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because neurological gait disorders are common among older adults and pose a serious risk of falls, the leading cause of injury-related death among Americans over 60. This work will study how motor cortex generates neural signals that control skilled walking by isolating the contribution of the cerebellum and posterior parietal cortex to these signals. The project is relevant to the NIH mission because a data-driven model of how motor cortical dynamics are generated is expected to accelerate the improvement of deep brain stimulation approaches and brain-machine interfaces for movement disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell-cell signaling has essential roles in development, tissue maintenance, and regeneration, and many of the same signaling pathways are implicated in cancers and other diseases. The proposed research seeks to understand fundamental cell-biological mechanisms that control how signaling proteins move between cells and how cells interpret this information to give rise to spatial organization and cellular behaviors. This work will advance our understanding of essential molecular and cellular processes relevant to development, homeostasis, and regenerative medicine, along with diseases related to abnormal cell signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The complex biomedical research questions of today require scientists to have both specialized expertise in their field and also the skills to bridge that expertise across fields in a team science environment; however, most graduate training focuses exclusively on the development of specialized expertise. The interface between chemistry and biology is one of the most common and important intersections of fields, playing a key role in everything from basic fundamental discoveries to advanced pharmaceutical development. The Chemistry of Life Training Program will complement NC State’s existing doctoral programs in in the molecular sciences, by providing trainees with the technical skills, mentorship, and professional development needed to cross the Chemistry: Biology interface, producing a new generation of scientists prepared to tackle the most complex biomedical issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Statement: Bim1 is linked to increased virulence for Cryptococcus neoformans in a mouse meningitis infection model and participates in Cu-homeostasis. Related BLP genes are also present in several fungal pathogens affecting humans, including Coccidioides immitis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Talaromyces marneffei, and Aspergillus niger but little is known about how BLP sequence variation affects biological function. In the proposed research project, we will explore the active site design of this novel class of BLP copper trafficking proteins and explore their mechanism for Cu-delivery at the fungal cell surface; ultimately our findings will lead to a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of copper homeostasis in fungi which may be exploited for the development of future antifungal treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH: This project will clarify the characteristics of circadian systems that enhance fitness. Biological clocks have been found to be crucial for physical and mental health; cancer, growth/proliferation, metabolic disorders, cardiovascular disease, and depression are associated with the disruption of these timing systems by genetic and/or environmental disturbance (i.e., by shiftwork or "jet-lag"). Understanding the crucial features of biological timing that are selected by rhythmic environments will reveal underlying circadian organization & regulation to assist the development of therapies to properly phase sleep, enabling us to improve the health, performance, and well-being of humans suffering from mental and/or metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: AD/ADRD Focus Pilot Core (Core F) Project Narrative The overarching goal of the Alzheimer's Disease and Alzheimer's Disease Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) Focus Pilot Core (Core F) is to promote the advancement of science for predictive analytics, for clinical decision support, or for the care of adults with AD/ADRD. Led by Dr. Graciela Gonzalez-Hernandez, Associate Professor of Informatics and Senior Faculty of the Institute of Biomedical Informatics (IBI) at the University of Pennsylvania, and Director of the Health Language Processing (HLP) Center, Core F seeks to provide comprehensive, integrated, and continuous support and promotion of Pilot projects that connect novel technologies for monitoring aging adults in the home with research activities and clinical care, specifically aimed at addressing the acute needs of the AD/ADRD patients and their caregivers and the specific nuances and progression of AD/ADRD. To our knowledge, a comprehensive pipeline from home to clinic and back that addresses the many challenges of AD/ADRD does not yet exist and building and extending this pipeline will be central to our pilot funding program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Teich, Andrew, Franklin Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the number one cause of dementia in the western world, and is a major cause of mortality and morbidity. Brain inflammation involving cells called microglia has recently been recognized as an important component of AD, although how microglia contribute to dementia is not completely clear. This proposal will lead to a better understanding of the types of microglia that are active in brain tissue from patients with early AD pathology, and link this to biomarkers in cerebral spinal fluid that may be useful for predicting clinical outcomes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Klebsiella pneumoniae is a common cause of pneumonia and sepsis that contributes to high mortality and morbidity in hospitalized, immunosuppressed, and chronically ill patients. Additionally, multidrug resistant K. pneumoniae are a major public health concern. The goal of this proposal is to develop a non-transmissible live attenuated K. pneumoniae vaccine to prevent infection with K. pneumoniae.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite having near-identical genome sequences, all human cell-types have unique DNA methylation profiles that reflect their individual programs of gene regulatory activity. This research will leverage human population genetics to link DNA methylation patterns to traits recorded in the electronic health record and will couple these data with mechanistic studies to uncover the relationship between DNA methylation, the genome sequence and phenotypic outcomes. These studies will reveal how DNA methylation mediates genome function to establish normal and pathological cellular identities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The major goal of this proposal is to analyze sequencing data from ~1000 families of non-Hispanic white, Hispanic and African American ancestry to identify variants and genes that confer risk of late-onset Alzheimer’s Disease (LOAD). We will apply existing and novel family-based analytics to identify LOAD susceptibility genes that can be tested as therapeutic targets. These efforts will be in parallel with and complementary to analyses in the unrelated case-control analyses being conducted on Alzheimer’s Disease Sequencing Project (ADSP) discovery, extension replication and follow-up datasets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE End-stage kidney disease (ESKD) affects over 700,000 Americans, and dialysis requires substantial patient engagement in order to achieve optimal outcomes. The central hypotheses of this proposal are that health- related social needs (i.e. unstable housing and food insecurity) impede patient engagement and lead to worse outcomes, and represent modifiable targets for intervention that can feasibly be implemented with medical care. Public health relevance: understanding the impact of health-related social needs on dialysis may lead to interventions that improve engagement among economically disadvantaged individuals with ESKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: A lack of ideal optogenetic tools to investigate the physiology and pathogenesis of neurological diseases/disorders has been an impediment to the development of therapeutic interventions. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interventions that promote water consumption in place of sugar-sweetened beverages have shown promise for preventing childhood obesity in schoolchildren. Yet to date, no studies have examined whether applying this approach in childcare centers could help to prevent childhood obesity at an even earlier stage of development. We will conduct a cluster-randomized controlled trial to study how a multilevel childcare-based healthy beverage intervention affects young children’s consumption of beverages and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Impairment in new learning and memory is a hallmark symptom of Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and negatively impacts several important aspects of everyday life (e.g., instrumental activities of daily living), but treatment options are limited due to the lack of cognitive rehabilitation (CR) protocols supported by Class I research evidence. To address this critical need, the presently proposed multi-site randomized clinical trial (RCT) examines the efficacy of the Kessler Foundation modified Story Memory Technique (KF-mSMT), a 10-session structured CR treatment composed of the application of imagery and context to facilitate learning. Results are expected to substantially improve our ability to treat learning and memory deficits in persons with MCI, which would lead to improved everyday functioning and overall quality of life for persons with MCI, as well as reduced caregiver burden and slowed transition to dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: RESEARCH & RELATED - OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION - PROJECT NARRATIVE This PPG renewal proposes to fundamentally expand our understanding of the selective and functional modulation of the two cannabinoid receptors, CB1 and CB2. The work will be accomplished through an integrated interdisciplinary effort between collaborating laboratories centered around the development and pharmacological characterization of high-quality probes with improved pharmacological profiles. The results can be used to develop improved therapies for pain as well as addictive, inflammatory and fibrotic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Bacterial chemotaxis enables pathogens such as Vibrio cholerae (cholera), Helicobacter pylori (ulcers and gastric cancer), Treponema pallidum (syphilis) and Borrelia burgderfori (lyme disease) to invade tissues and evade the immune system. In contrast, eukaryotic circadian clocks impact nearly every aspect of behavior and their dysfunction contributes to mental illness (sleep disorders, depression, mania, schizophrenia), cancer, and metabolic disease (diabetes and obesity). Defining molecular mechanisms of these two functionally diverse, yet biochemically related, signaling systems will provide the basic understanding to guide new strategies for the treatment of infectious disease and mental disorders.

PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The human SIN3A and SIN3B paralogues are members of several distinct chromatin remodeling complexes whose functions remain poorly understood. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aplastic anemia is characterized by immune-mediated destruction of hematopoietic stem cells resulting in deficiency of blood cells of all lineages and therefore, immunosuppressive therapies has been the main line of treatment, which has significant relapse and refractory patients. Eltrombopag (Epag) has been developed as a small molecule thrombopoietin receptor (TPOR) agonist clinically used to improve platelet counts. Studies in AA showed that Epag treatment led to unexpected tri-lineage improvement and thereby more complete response which are in part due to its off-target effect on TET-dioxygenases that control cell lineage, differentiation and proliferation. We propose to study the novel stem cell activity of a known drug Epag, as TET inhibitor that can be exploited to study epigenetic regulation of HSC and to determine differences in the spectrum of effects from other thrombopoietic agents and to explain its effects or refractoriness in AA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Both insomnia and chronically insufficient sleep have independently been shown to increase risk for the onset of depression by two- to three-fold, yet the functional mechanisms underlying the deterioration in emotion regulation following chronic sleep disruption remains unknown. Given that not all patients with insomnia experience an objective reduction in sleep duration, the goal of the present study is to determine the overlapping and distinct impact of Insomnia Disorder and multiple nights of truncated sleep in healthy controls on neural and behavioral responses during emotion regulation. The results will help us link different types of sleep disruption to neural signatures of emotional distress and will provide actionable therapeutic “targets” for future research investigating behavioral, pharmacological, and somatic (i.e., stimulation) treatments for patients struggling with sleep and emotional regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the frequent use of ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) in children with CKD, little is known regarding how nocturnal blood pressure (BP) dipping should be defined, its risk factors, and its consequences in this population. The objectives of this proposal are to 1) evaluate the association of nocturnal BP patterns with progression of kidney disease in children; 2) evaluate whether impaired daytime sodium excretion is associated with blunted nocturnal BP dipping, and 3) test whether nocturnal BP dipping can be restored simply with retiming of anti-hypertensive medication dosing to the evening. Results of this study will guide pediatric nephrologists on how to act on nocturnal dipping patterns in children with CKD, provide insights to its pathophysiology, and provide preliminary data for subsequent randomized trials to slow kidney disease progression in children with CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed work will arm medicinal chemists with a new suite of chemical reactions that can expedite our society’s ability to synthesize small molecule therapies, a major bottleneck in our efforts to address critical health needs. The key strategy is predicated on using energy from visible-light to drive chemical transformations that may make life-saving therapeutics in an efficient, robust and enabling manner. The motivation for our work is to protect life by lowering the barrier to making pharmaceutical compounds that will treat diseases, reduce disabilities, and enhance the quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A multitude of chemical modifications influence the structure and function of RNA, which is central to cell function across life, in both health and disease. We will investigate how prion protein-based control of RNA-modifying enzymes affects RNA structure, gene expression, and cell growth. The proposed work will uncover a new understanding of how RNA structure can be epigenetically controlled.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic inflammation associated with HIV infection increases the risk of developing a range of comorbidities, including diabetes, kidney/liver disease and cardiovascular disease. This study proposes to identify the mechanisms of dysregulation in the intestinal epithelial barrier protective functions of gamma delta T cells and to explore the potential therapeutic effects of microbial supplementation for restoring gut barrier integrity using the highly translational nonhuman primate model of chronic treated HIV infection. Validating this approach could benefit multiple inflammatory diseases, an important goal in restoring general health.
