IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding control of gene expression requires comprehensive identification of both the functional regulatory elements encoded on the RNAs and the identification of the proteins that bind to them. Here we develop a novel scalable technology, reagent resource, experimental protocols and a computational framework for detecting RBP-RNA targets and translation at the single-cell and single-molecule levels. Our conceptual and technological innovations will, for the first time, enable translation efficiency and RBP-interactomes to be measured at single-cell level and at scale, opening up new paradigms of biological questions.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eating disorders are serious conditions associated with significant mortality, necessitating innovative research to determine causes, maintenance factors, prevention, and treatment. This multisite T32 postdoctoral fellowship program trains the next generation of scientists in interdisciplinary research methods through mentorship, teaching, and experiential learning opportunities in order to advance the science of eating disorder psychopathology and related conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory dysfunctions (including those of the tongue, chest wall, abdominal diaphragm muscles) and increased incidence of airway infections are major contributors to morbidity and mortality in Alzheimer’s disease and aging. The exact mechanisms of how respiratory muscles are compromised with Alzheimer’s disease and aging is unknown, but likely involves all levels of the motor unit, the motor neuron pools in the brainstem and spinal cord and the skeletal muscle. This project will assess two major culprits in neural loss and muscle weakness at all levels of the motor system, investigating therapeutic strategies designed to mitigate the effects of synaptic dysfunction (SPG302) and mitochondrial disfunctions (edaravone).

PHR: Narrative The program meets the demands for conceptual understanding and quantitative rigor of modern neuroscience. Training that promotes rigorous literacy in experimental design, data analysis and quantitative methods applied to neuroscience will prepare new generations of innovators who will make a positive impact on the field. Supported by committed mentors, a program that fosters a diverse and inclusive training environment, and effective career advising, trainees will be placed at a competitive edge for a variety of careers in STEM disciplines within and outside of academia.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: The Scanning electron microscope (SEM) is an essential tool to study tissue structure and local elemental components in tissues and cells. The SEM available within the CBI is over 20 years old and will no longer be supported by the manufacturer and needs to be retired. This together with a defined need for more sophisticated analytical imaging modalites (EDS) by our NIH funded user population is driving this request to place a contemporary high quality SEM in the Center for Biologic Imaging to allow practical application of SEM imaging modalities tools to the largest number of NIH funded investigators here at the University of Pittsburgh.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project aims to improve immunotherapeutic outcomes for glioblastoma (GBM) patients by investigating the role of Pyk2 and FAK signaling in regulating PD-L1 expression in GBM and their impact on the tumor immune microenvironment. The study will explore the potential of Pyk2/FAK inhibitors as sensitizers for anti-PD-L1 therapy in GBM, considering the importance of incorporating the NF1 status of the tumor in treatment decisions. The findings will contribute to personalized therapeutic approaches and treatment choices, with the goal of enhancing outcomes for GBM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal requests supplemental funding to support a minority graduate student as part of an existing U54 SCORE program exploring the long-term changes in brain function following in utero stress and inflammation. Overexposure to inflammation or to glucocorticoids can disrupt fetal development and program autonomic dysregulation and elevated risk for neuropsychiatric disorders in adulthood. The proposed research will investigate whether puberty is a critical period for autonomic nervous system development that may be altered by prenatal stressors.

PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Duke Neurobiology Training Program (NBTP) is to train the next generation of leading scientists who will discover how the nervous system normally functions to enable a myriad of complex processes, including learning, memory, movement, behavior, sensation, and perception, and how to restore normal function of the nervous system in the face of trauma and disease. The major objective of the NBTP is to endow young scientists with the intellectual breadth, technical flexibility and scientific rigor to grow and adapt to the demands of neuroscience research now and over the next several decades, enabling them to successfully navigate the variety of scientific career paths that will span the neuroscience research enterprise of the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Remaining at the forefront of cutting-edge technologies to understand the human condition, the UCLA Medical & Imaging Informatics (MII) training program aims to train and inspire a new generation of scientists who will lead the development of innovative approaches that inform and enable the translation and analysis of these methods into practice. MII establishes a cross-campus, interdisciplinary environment to teach and mentor future scientists in novel computational and data science methods for new types of sensing and imaging data; and creates novel, team science research opportunities in which graduate students work and learn from leading experts in the field. MII trainees are exposed to the breadth of contemporary research, and are ultimately pre- pared to be productive, independent scientists that will participate in shaping the discipline as biomedical re- search and healthcare evolve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: The number of child and adolescent psychiatry (CAP)-trained/committed physicians pursuing a research career is declining paradoxically at a time when there is greater need for CAP physician/scientists to advance the NIMH Strategic Plan, including increasing recognition that neuropsychiatric illnesses are often disorders of neurodevelopment, starting early in childhood/adolescence. The Child and Adolescent Psychiatry Research Institute (CAPRI) will create a national mentoring network: (1) linking early career CAP-trained/committed researchers (CAPRI Scholars) to established CAPRI Mentors for a 2-year mentorship program of overlapping cohorts, engaging in a 3-day in-person meeting plus ongoing webinars and regular 1:1 mentor meetings throughout the academic year; (2) providing mentorship for pre-contemplative CAP physicians not yet ready to apply for a K-award in preparation to become Scholars; and (3) providing sustaining mentorship for AACAP Summer Medical Students to increase their likelihood of choosing psychiatry and ultimately CAP as a career. CAPRI will mentor the next generation of CAP researchers, increasing their success in obtaining career development awards, launching their careers to improve mental health, and providing a sustainable support network and social belonging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genomic instability gives rise to aging, tumor evolution, DNA repeat expansion associated with multiple disease states, the development of antibiotic resistance in bacteria, and a general reduction in evolutionary fitness. This proposal addresses the molecular basis of an essential yet too often overlooked source of genomic instability, the repair of lesions in post-replication gaps that are left behind the replication fork. As gap repair is a primary source of mutagenesis and genomic rearrangements, we are proposing an integrated strategy to attain an in-depth understanding of gap formation and repair, aimed at providing new avenues to slow tumor growth and bacterial antibiotic resistance. Our project will address four separate vulnerabilities of bacterial pathogens that may eventually be used to address antiobiotic-resistand pathogens, one of them newly discovered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Environmental chemicals and stressors are major contributors to disease; interdisciplinary expertise is required to rigorously quantify exposure and health effects to assess and manage risk, as well as to develop novel tools for reduction of exposure, remediation of polluted sites, and treatment of disease. Duke University has outstanding expertise in these areas, with top-ranked Schools of Medicine, Environment, and Engineering; Departments of Statistical Sciences, Environmental Engineering, and Biology; and the Global Health Institute. Through integration of this transdisciplinary expertise, the Duke University Program in Environmental Health will provide pre- and postdoctoral trainees with essential research skillsets, guidance in professional development, and an inclusive and supportive training environment, thus producing deeply trained but interdisciplinary environmental health leaders who will contribute throughout their careers to solving society’s urgent environmental health needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endocrine therapy represents the most effective targeted therapy for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancers; however, their effectiveness is greatly limited by resistance development, toxicity and recurrence/relapse, posing a major clinical challenge. This proposal will lay the foundation for testing a new and nontoxic strategy for inhibiting tamoxifen resistant tumor growth and metastasis. In this proposal we will (1) elucidate the molecular underpinnings of a novel transcriptional reprogramming mechanism of tamoxifen resistance, (2) develop a nontoxic therapeutic strategy to overcome tamoxifen resistance, and (3) identify novel markers with diagnostic, prognostic, and/or targeted therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: When the cochlea is injured or infected, immune cells exit the blood vessels and enter the fluid spaces of the cochlea. How normal vascular barriers exclude these cells from the inner ear during times of health and how these barriers open to allow passage of immune cells when they are needed, is not known. We will explore how vessels control traffic of these cells, how the opening and closing of the barrier occurs, what cells in the cochlea are susceptible to virus, and what steps lead to irreversible damage and hearing loss after viral infection in the inner ear. Because viral infection in utero is a well established condition that frequently leads to hearing loss, we choose to study the effects of congenital viral infection on the blood labyrinth barrier and auditory development and determine how these two may influence each other.

PHR: Project Narrative The University of Florida Gators Advancing Through Opportunities in Research for Aging and Alzheimer's Disease Education (GATORAADE) Program aims to provide comprehensive research training and didactic instruction to postbaccalaureate trainees interested in advancing our understanding of brain aging and Alzheimer's Disease and related dementias (ADRD). By addressing the behavioral, socioeconomic, biological and clinical aspects of brain aging and ADRD, the GATORAADE program will contribute to increase the pipeline of diverse researchers and healthcare professionals thus promoting a more inclusive environment and workforce in the aging and ADRD fields. In alignment with the National Institute on Aging (NIA)'s mission of fostering the development of research and clinician scientists in aging, the GATORAADE program will also empower early career researchers and pre-health professionals to gain a deeper understanding of aging and related disorders, and its impact on public health outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative The Neonatal Research Training Program supports the mentored career development of pediatric physician- scientists who play a vital role in advancing knowledge related to child health. It provides a structured, intensive research experience for neonatal-perinatal post-residency fellows to obtain rigorous training in basic science, translational, or clinical research in order to advance our knowledge of developmental and newborn diseases towards the eventual implementation of novel therapeutic strategies. We aim to develop future leaders and mentors who will train the next generation of physician-scientists in the field of neonatal-perinatal medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This study aims to uncover how somatic cells regulate proper chromosome organization during human development. Pairing of homologous chromosomes during meiosis accomplishes genetic diversity. However, during mitosis, homologous pairing in somatic cells can lead to genetic instability and tumorigenesis. The proposal explores this significant, yet largely untouched, biological paradigm of how homologous chromosomes achieve anti-pairing organization during cellular development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative To improve the health of America’s aging society requires greater understanding of the complex factors affecting cognitive and physical health during aging. Since aging health is affected by biological, sociological, economic, and psychological factors which operate within a policy, epidemiological, and environmental context, multidisciplinary training is essential for future researchers in aging. This program provides developing researchers with the tools to understand the complexity of age-related health outcomes and to enrich their work by placing it in a larger context.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative We propose to renew our 20-year-old UCI Training Program in Epilepsy Research. Epilepsy is the third most common brain disorder, and one that affects the young preferentially, with a tremendous loss of human potential. Surprisingly, Epilepsy is relatively understudied and underfunded; thus, there is a major unmet need to encourage and train the new generation of the Epilepsy Investigator Workforce. Our program has strived and succeeded in preparing a diverse groups of students for their Research Career in Epilepsy and Neuroscience Research. We hope to continue this effort and educate the next generation of diverse, outstanding trainees and provide them with state-of-the-art approaches to the understanding of Epilepsy and its co-morbidities, as well as professional skills for their career development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will shed light on a wide variety of genetic, prenatal, early-life and family factors that influence the risk for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and on differences and similarities in the behaviors, abilities, and health of preschoolers with ASD. It will also provide insights into the experiences of adolescents with ASD as they mature. By helping to explain the causes of ASD and how ASD affects children, youth and young adults, this project will contribute to efforts to reduce the risk of ASD and improve the outcomes of affected children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Many types of solid tumors, including anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC), are treated with external beam radiation with cytotoxic chemotherapy to improve cure rates and/or tumor control. BRAF activating mutations are the single most common oncogenic mutation in ATC (occurring in 30-40% of tumors), and our preliminary data supports that BRAF mutations promote therapeutic resistance to radiation and other genotoxic therapies. Developing a better understanding of this mechanism as well as developing more tumor-selective approaches to improve sensitivity to genotoxic therapies in BRAF mutant and BRAF wild-type ATC will improve our ability to control and cure this difficult cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MapHabit’s proposal is focused on the development of science-based, innovative assistive technology for people living with Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease related dementias (AD/ADRD). The technology objective is to help individuals maintain their independence and autonomy longer and reduce the burden of AD/ADRD caregiving by using visual mapping that cues behavior. These goals reflect the nation’s public health goals of reducing the burden of AD/ADRD on individuals, their families, and society at large. LiveWell's science-based, innovative caregiver training program (CTP) offers educational and self-care training to caregivers to reduce their burden of AD/ADRD caregiving. The integration of the MapHabit System (MHS) with the CTP will be the first app-based, personalized caregiving product to integrate caregiver training that focuses on self-care with an evidence-based visual mapping interactive care management platform. These combined behavioral tools will translate to improved independence, autonomy, and enhanced quality of life for individuals under care with AD/ADRD and their circle of support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Prominent successes of the NIH BRAIN Initiative to date include the identification of many new types of neurons, but to understand how these cell-types work together in the live brain it will be crucial to have techniques that can record the coordinated voltage dynamics of multiple classes of identified neurons simultaneously. To create such techniques, we will engineer four novel fluorescent indicators of neuronal trans-membrane voltage and three new optical instruments tailored to use these indicators to image either the spiking or oscillatory voltage dynamics of up to four neuron-types concurrently in the brains of awake behaving animals. These innovations will reveal how multiple neuron-types act concertedly at the millisecond-scale to support information-processing and shape a wide range of neurophysiologic states.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The high rate of mutations in human mitochondrial DNA is a major cause of inherited and age-related diseases, but the mechanisms responsible for these elevated mutation rates are still uncertain and controversial. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social interactions with peers are the building blocks of adolescent social development and puberty is a developmental period during which processes underlying social interactions, such as social attention and mentalizing, are in flux. Integration of social attention and mentalizing during puberty may facilitate social reorientation, preparing adolescents for adult life and solidifying or disrupting risk for social anxiety. The proposed project will take a naturalistic approach to examine cross-sectional and longitudinal relations between social attention, mentalizing, puberty and social anxiety.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Contusive cervical spinal cord injury (cSCI) impairs upper limb function (reach-and-grasp) which limits daily-life activities and thus decreases the quality of life. Promoting neuroplasticity may support upper limb recovery after SCI. Repetitive exposure to acute intermittent hypoxia (rAIH) combined with motor training promotes recovery of motor function after SCI; however, the overall effects of rAIH/training are limited. We will use an adult rat model of long-term contusive cSCI to study novel approaches to enhance the effect of rAIH/training on forelimb function and study the neuronal substrate underlying the effects. The findings will be used to direct the development of more effective rAIH/training approaches for people with contusive, functionally incomplete, cSCI. Because deficits in upper limb function are a major problem after stroke, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, multiple sclerosis, and other motor disorders, our work may also be relevant for patients with other types of CNS lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Exposure to drugs of abuse, such as alcohol, induces plasticity in the brain and creates persistent drug-related memories that contribute to alcohol dependence. This project seeks to characterize transcriptional alterations in AUD, notably pathways related to the extracellular matrix (ECM) in human subjects and to test how genetically modifying a microglial ECM protease signaling pathway may alter alcohol-related memories. Results from these studies will inform more effective treatments for and/or optimize current treatment paradigms for AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emotional experience shows well documented shifts across adulthood. Emotions impact all aspects of health and well-being ranging from physical health to mental health to adaptive decision-making and social relationships. Consequently, a better understanding of the neurobiological mechanisms underlying maturational shifts in emotional experience can support scientists, practitioners and policymakers working on the prevention and treatment of health disorders (e.g., geriatric depression, cardiovascular disease, dementia) and policies to support our globe’s growing population of older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: GRADUATE SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND HEALTH POLICY
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to implement and rigorously evaluate a novel ‘data-to-suppression’ (D2S) intervention with Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program Part A (RWPA) support-service programs, to address a viral suppression (VS) deficit among RWPA clients in HIV care. While data-to-care (D2C) efforts pursue data sharing and linkages with medical providers, our premise is that support-service (particularly behavioral health and housing) program staff are best positioned to address major barriers to antiretroviral adherence, once they have the information needed to triage those who struggle to maintain VS. Surveillance data sharing by health departments with their community-based Ryan White programs may be especially critical to fill communication gaps between clinical and support-service providers as ‘telehealth’ becomes more prevalent in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is an escalating major health concern in the United States. The proposed research will use cutting-edge neuroscience techniques to map vulnerable cell types and neural connectivity changes using mouse models of aging and AD. Our research meets multiple major goals of RFA-AG-22-008 and is expected to have high impact by providing critical reference information for molecular and neural circuit studies of multiple established and new AD models for the large AD research community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a progressive and deadly fibrotic disease of the lung, where early microscopic diagnosis and assessment of disease progression are essential to determine which therapy may be the most effective for patients and whether individual patients are responding to those therapies. Unfortunately, computed tomography cannot detect early IPF or microscopic changes over time, and surgical lung biopsy to obtain tissue for microscopy has high risks of adverse events and even death. The goal of this proposal is to validate a low-risk, minimally-invasive optical bronchoscopy tool for early microscopic IPF diagnosis and monitoring of therapy response in order to offer patients the most effective treatment for their specific diagnosis and monitor treatment efficacy early on in the disease, which will improve patient outcomes and survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Deciding whether to explore a new opportunity or exploit what already has been learned is a fundamental component of behavioral flexibility. Unbalanced exploration or exploitation can have dramatic consequences on well-being and quality of life, however, explore-exploit decision making is understudied in psychiatry because the neural mechanisms underlying it are not well understood. The research in this grant will uncover the neural mechanisms underlying explore-exploit decision making and determine if different cortical and subcortical circuits are engaged when the motivation to explore novel opportunities is driven by a desire to maximize gains or minimize losses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative: With the use of cART, even after the complete suppression of viral load in the peripheral system, active/latent HIV infection, neuroinflammation and associated neurocognitive impairments could not be eliminated in cannabinoid abusers due to the continuous production of HIV-1 Tat protein and inability of the drugs to cross the blood-brain barrier. In this study, we are using a novel gene-editing CRISPR/Cas9 technology targeting HIV-1 Tat gene in microglia in combination with a recently discovered (by Dr. Alexandros Makriyannis, co-PI of the grant) stable endocannabinoid analog AMG315 in both in vitro and in vivo iTat mice model employing our patented (US 20130317279 A1 and WO2014074584 A1) nanotechnology drug delivery approach. Successful delivery of the nanoformulation across the BBB will have a translational significance in the prevention of neurocognitive impairments in HIV positive cannabinoid-abusing patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The ability of mosquitoes to detect, process, and respond to olfactory information emitted by their hosts can affect disease transmission. The magnitude of their responses to odors varies drastically throughout the day, but, despite their clear epidemiological relevance, the neural and molecular mechanisms acting at the circuit levels to control mosquito behavior remain to be determined. The proposed research will employ an interdisciplinary approach combining behavioral assays, electrophysiological recordings, transcriptomic analysis, and CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing, to characterize rhythms in odorant detection, perception, and olfactory behavior, thereby identifying the genetic basis of the temporal plasticity in mosquito-host interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Although the gut microbiome and human genetic variation are both associated with disease, we do not know their relative contributions and how they interact to affect host health. Here, we propose to use a combination of genomic, computational, and experimental techniques to quantify the heritability of microbiome functions, characterize associations between host and microbial genes, and identify microbiome strains, genes, and pathways that regulate host gene expression. Results from this project will generate unprecedented insight on the interaction between host genetics and the microbiota across populations and disease states, and will facilitate the development of novel microbiome-based diagnostics and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This work will use molecular diagnostic methods to define the epidemiology and impact of infections with diverse Campylobacter species in children in low-resource settings, many of which have been poorly characterized or missed by traditional culture-based approaches. It will define the specific mechanisms underlying the association between Campylobacter infections and linear growth faltering and identify the primary reservoirs and pathways for transmission of Campylobacter to young children in an endemic setting. Successful completion of this work will lead to interventional studies designed to reduce Campylobacter infections and associated malnutrition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE One in eight US women is expected to develop an invasive breast cancer in her lifetime, and among the various breast cancer subtypes, triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) carries the worst prognosis, in part, due to a lack of effective therapies. Mutations in p53 are present in over 80% of TNBCs, and we have found that ASAH1 is required for tumor and metastatic growth of p53-mutant TNBCs. The results of the experiments proposed in this application will establish the role of ASAH1 in promoting p53-mutant TNBC tumor growth and metastasis, as well as investigate the translational potential of ASAH1 inhibitors for p53-mutant TNBC therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure which afflicts nearly 5 million people in the United States, and an additional 550,000 new cases are diagnosed each year. Non-compaction (LVNC) is the third most common cardiomyopathy with an estimated prevalence from 4.5 to 26 per 10,000 adult patients referred for echocardiographic diagnosis; however, there remains a poor genotype-phenotype association in LVNC patients, and a paucity of knowledge on the biomechanical forces underlying the initiation and organization of trabeculation and compaction during cardiac development. For these reasons, our multi-disciplinary team seeks to embrace advanced optics, genetic animal models, and precise computation to provide mechanotransduction insights into the organization of cardiac trabeculation for ventricular structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: CENTER OVERVIEW: Project Narrative For the last 35 years, the Joslin Diabetes Research Center has provided critical infrastructure to catalyze groundbreaking diabetes research efforts at Joslin, at Harvard, and in the broader research community. Contributions of the Center’s Cores, Pilot & Feasibility Program, and Enrichment Program can be measured by their heavy use by 49 Joslin Research Base investigators and more than 40 outside investigators in the Boston area, and by the seminal publications that have benefitted from Center support. The Joslin Diabetes Center fosters collaborative, multidisciplinary approaches across the basic and translational spectrum to advance our understanding of diabetes and related metabolic disorders and to develop new treatments and preventive strategies for the disease and its complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major problem facing clinicians is their inability to identify idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) patients who will experience rapid progression before irreversible loss of lung function occurs. The proposed research will fill a significant void in pulmonary medicine through integration of longitudinal clinical data with chromatin accessibility and gene expression to uncover biologically relevant pathways that drive, or result from, disease course variability. The results will form an innovative platform in which to explore the biologic underpinnings and identify patients at high-risk for rapid IPF progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Nanoscale vesicles are known to shed from tumor cells into the blood stream, carrying with them the molecular signatures of pancreatic cancer. We propose an innovative, clinically practical approach to probe the RNA contained within these nanoscale vesicles to better understand the disease's development and spread. Our rapid and multiplexed platform is designed to offer uniquely high precision to diagnose and to guide physicians towards the most efficacious treatments, offering tremendous benefits for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance While the underlying etiology/pathophysiology remain unclear for a majority of human neuropsychiatric diseases, it has become clear that early developmental defects can be a significant contributor to behavioral sequelae later in life. Our proposal examines a poorly understood area of developmental neurobiology: neural circuit activity control of postnatal neural stem cell proliferation and differentiation. We will focus on a newly identified neural circuit, specifically innervating the lateral ventricular neurogenic niche in the postnatal brain, and believe these studies will advance our understanding of how neuronal activity in the brain can modulate neurogenesis during development, as well as provide important insights into their potential changes in disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1 (SCA1) is a rare autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder for which there is no treatment. We have discovered that the angiogenic cytokine vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a promising treatment strategy given that recombinant VEGF considerably mitigates the disease phenotype in a mouse preclinical model. Since recombinant VEGF has significant limitations for use in the clinic, we are optimizing a VEGF mimetic nanoparticle approach to move forward in translating a VEGF-based therapy to human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa are a worldwide public health concern. A continued increase in antibiotic resistance along with limited understanding of how P. aeruginosa causes severe and invasive disease reinforce our need to develop better treatment options. This proposal will investigate a novel mechanism by which P. aeruginosa overcomes host barriers to disease with the goal of identifying new areas for the rational design of therapeutics that augment the ability of the immune system to eliminate the infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common genetic heart disease, affecting as many as 1:200 individuals in the general population. HCM, initially described in the context of sudden cardiac death (SCD), is commonly associated with heart failure (HF) and atrial fibrillation (AF). The goal of this proposal is to develop novel risk stratification paradigms by leveraging recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI) to improve HCM patient management. The premise of the study is that AI provides a promising solution to intelligently extract and combine imaging and non-imaging markers of adverse cardiovascular events in HCM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wnt signaling is a biological pathway that allows cells to communicate and to coordinate their behavior during animal development, tissue maintenance, and regeneration. It is also often dysregulated across a wide variety of human diseases. We are working to discover the mechanisms that allow Wnt signals to induce the activation of genes and thereby regulate changes in cell growth and differentiation. Our discoveries will be applicable to new therapeutic strategies that regulate signaling in Wnt-driven developmental disorders and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Astrocytes serve critical roles in neuronal circuit maturation by regulating the formation and elimination of neuronal synapses, as well as circuit maintenance by tightly controlling ionic balance and neurotransmitter recycling. We propose to investigate how an evolutionarily conserved, astrocyte-enriched protein, DBI, regulates the development and physiology of astrocytes and controls proper function of the neural circuitry using both fruit flies and zebrafish as model organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Physiological transport of fluid, molecules, proteins, and cells throughout the body is critical for homeostasis. While transport processes like cell migration and molecular passage across cellular barriers are well documented, less is known about transport across the interstitial tissue spaces and into lymphatic vessels, the natural conduit from peripheral tissues to draining lymph nodes, where the immune response is shaped. The proposed research program combines mucosal, lymphoid tissue, and lymphatic vessel physiology with engineering approaches, such as building relevant in vitro model systems and designing nanoparticle probes, to increase our understanding of protein, particulate, and other material transport across interstitial tissues and into lymphatic vessels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hearing including analytic change  loss is a leading cause of disability in the United States and worldwide, affecting billions of people, individuals across age groups and those of Hispanic background. By using genomic technologies and techniques, this project will identify genetic variants as well as regions of the human genome that gene expression and function and cause hearing loss in Hispanic children.Results of this study will aid not only in the identification of causes of hearing loss and genetic counseling of families with hearing loss, but also in understanding the basic functions of the human ear and the discovery of new therapies for hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human carcinomas and transport disorders are characterized by the dissolution of cellular junctions, the attachment points that link cells together and to the surrounding tissue. One possible therapeutic target for these diseases is the cytoskeleton, which is abundant in healthy cell junctions but dysregulated during disease progression. This proposal seeks to develop a molecular toolkit for controlling the cytoskeleton with specificity at cell junctions, thereby reducing toxic side-effects and offering the possibility of reinforcing healthy junctions to treat cancer and transport disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Influenza virus continues to pose a worldwide threat to humans, requiring identification of new cellular targets to regulate viral pathogenicity for its control. Sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P)-metabolizing enzymes were found to function as mediators that control important cellular or disease processes, which prompted us to investigate roles of the S1P-metabolizing enzymes during influenza virus infection. Investigating the molecular mechanisms by which S1P-metabolizing enzymes regulate host defense or signaling pathways to impact influenza virus pathogenesis comprises a promising means for developing novel therapeutic interventions to remedy influenza.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Physiological actin dynamics are indispensable for normal function in many important processes such as cell migration, wound healing and the immune process of phagocytosis. Our proposed research is focused on elucidating molecular mechanisms underlying actin dynamics in living cells. Understanding of these mechanisms will pave the way for development of new therapies to combat diseases like Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), metastatic cancer and neurological disorders (e.g. Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's diseases).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Speech production deficits and behavioral inflexibility are among the most functionally disabling behavioral features of Fragile X Syndrome (FXS), but continue to lack effective treatments due to limited mechanistic understanding. The proposed study will investigate speech production and behavioral flexibility deficits in FXS using performance-based tasks during high-density electroencephalography (EEG) to measure fronto-temporal and fronto-parietal circuits in individuals with FXS, respectively. These electrophysiological studies have the potential to elucidate atypical local neural circuity and its integration in widely distributed brain networks underlying these behavioral features, thus this work will provide critical insight into underlying neurophysiological mechanisms and will assist in the identification of disorder-relevant biomarkers, ultimately, helping to speed treatment development to improve speech production and behavioral flexibility in FXS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE G‐RISE at Auburn University is designed as an umbrella to enhance diversity in graduate programs focused on doctoral degrees in the biomedical sciences. Programmatic activities are focused on recruiting, admitting, and supporting six highly qualified students yearly from underrepresented groups through multiple mechanisms, with common threads of inclusive excellence and mentoring constellations. Given the history of racial inequities and the demographic composition of the region, G‐RISE at Auburn will focus on African‐American, Latinx, and Native American students in recruiting efforts, but will welcome all applicants.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CSHL Laboratory Course in Single Cell Analysis This application seeks funds to support an advanced cell & molecular lab-based short course at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, New York. The goal of this two-week course is to teach students cutting-edge wet-lab approaches for single cell analysis, and to provide familiarity with basic bioinformatic approaches to single cell data. Modules of the course will be taught by scientists with expertise in distinct areas of single cell analysis. Trainees include advanced graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and young faculty from throughout the United States and abroad. The selection process for entry into this course is highly competitive, and trainees leave the course armed with new techniques, know-how and potential collaborators to apply to their own areas of research. A significant proportion of trainees subsequently undertake basic or applied research in diseases of child health and/or human development. Methods and concepts taught in the course are disseminated to the wider research community through the publication of laboratory manuals and online resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Difficulties of labor initiation and progression are responsible for much of the injury and death seen around the time of birth in both women and their neonates, and Black women are much more likely than white women to experience injury and death around the time of birth. The proposed project will measure social determinants of health, pregnancy lifestyle, and blood samples in two groups of Black women who receive prenatal care in either a freestanding birth center or a hospital clinic to better understand how pregnancy experiences and health influence labor outcomes. The purpose of this project is to promote health and eliminate health disparities through a better understanding of the physiology of labor dysfunction.

PHR: Public Health Relevance We propose to confirm the ability of individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD) to increase and sustain activity of the amygdala during positive memory recall, and that this ability results in outcomes that are clinically relevant for those with the disorder. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Herpesviruses are ubiquitous human pathogens and their infection has been implicated in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Aging and herpesvirus infection (as an environmental factor) may synergize to induce neurodegeneration, although our understanding concerning their interaction is incomplete. This proposal will investigate how aging and herpesvirus infection interact in normal and AD model mouse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Compelling data now link latent herpes virus infection and, in particular, viral reactivation in the brain to increased incidence of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), a nearly pandemic neurodegenerative disease for which there are no effective therapies. This proposal will investigate the cell type- specific effects of HSV1 RNAs in human AD brains and AD model systems by leveraging single- nucleus sequencing technologies as well as explore the hypothesis that the viral latency RNA transcripts (LATs) modulate transcriptional events in the host associated with AD. Further, we will elucidate a novel innate immune pathway that may contribute to HSV1-induced inflammation and neurotoxicity and characterize the distinct genomic actions as well as non- genomic protective properties of the HSV1 latency-associated transcripts that can be exploited as a prophylactic modality for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of these studies is to determine whether tau accumulation in serotonin neurons causes affective and sleep disturbances, leading to chronic sleep deprivation and hyperexcitability in serotonin neurons and accelerating the spread of tau pathology to the entorhinal cortex. The resulting loss of 5-HT input to the EC also enhances excitability of EC neurons that project to the hippocampus, promoting spread to this region and precipitating cognitive decline. Ultimately, this investigation may identify neural substrates underlying the early non-cognitive symptoms of AD which could lead to better treatments for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Arithmetic and reading are the most fundamental skills acquired during elementary school, but despite their significance for academic achievement, employment prospects, and mental health, many children and adults in developed societies exhibit non-proficient reading and arithmetical abilities. A strong neurocognitive and genetic link between reading and arithmetic ability as well as high co-occurrence rates of reading and arithmetical learning difficulties have been shown, and this application proposes a longitudinal investigation that aims to (a) compare typical and atypical developmental trajectories of reading and arithmetic from kindergarten to third grade, (b) characterize similarities, differences, and classification power of neural and cognitive measures to profile the shared mechanisms underlying arithmetic and reading, and (c) determine a set of predictors in kindergarten of arithmetic and reading outcome after four years of formal instruction. Understanding the shared and distinct underlying neural and cognitive mechanisms between typical and atypical arithmetic and reading skills will be of great significance for the development of early screening, diagnostic, and intervention tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is the most common and lethal brain malignancy with no targeted therapy available. This project is to achieve a comprehensive understanding of SON functions in altering the RNA splicing program in GBM and to evaluate the therapeutic potential of targeting SON in vivo. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human cells use actin polymer networks for health-critical activities including the migration of white blood cells to sites of infection, cancer metastasis, as well as ingesting molecules, and moving objects around inside the cell. This project seeks to understand how cells control distinct actin-mediated activities and how cells organize changes in actin networks during development. Determining the basic mechanisms that allow cells to control actin functions can help in the development of synthetic cells for targeted drug delivery as well as in the identification of new therapeutic targets for immune system disorders and cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite significant improvements in the control and treatment of malaria infections in many parts of Africa, children with sickle cell disease (SCD) remain particularly vulnerable to fatal infections, a phenomenon that remains poorly understood. Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and other red blood cell (RBC) factors influence SCD pathology and, by their effects on sickle hemoglobin (HbS) polymerization, may also affect malaria parasitemia and virulence. This research proposal aims to understand P. falciparum growth in SCD, including the SCD RBC host factors that either protect against or worsen severe malaria infection, and identify potential therapeutic targets for individuals with co-morbid SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  County public health officials have expressed the need to identify local, actionable opiate overdose trends and inform plans to reduce opiate misuse and mortality in their counties. The proposed research will examine patterns in opioid overdose hotspots; identify opioid treatment deserts; correlate outcomes with sociodemographic variables; and describe local factors contributing to opioid disparities at the sub-county level. Designing these analyses for a hyperlocal examination of opioid use disorder will inform policy, spur future innovation, and direct targeted community health interventions to address this urgent public health crisis.

PHR: Project Narrative BK virus (BKV) causes serious diseases in transplant recipients and other patients with compromised immune systems. Successful infection requires that BKV redirects specific cellular systems towards viral replication, while simultaneously evades or neutralizes antiviral defenses. This proposal aims to identify cellular proteins and signaling pathways that differentially promote or restrict BKV infection in clinically relevant cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory infections are among the leading causes of neonatal mortality worldwide with low birth weight infants particularly susceptible and at risk for perinatal mortality. Maternal immunizations are increasingly being used as an infection prevention strategy to protect neonates and infants from respiratory pathogens, yet maternal immunization and transplacental antibody transfer are incompletely understood in pregnancies complicated by prematurity or placental insufficiency leading to small for gestational age infants. This proposal aims to quantify and characterize transplacental antibody transfer and maternal and neonatal immune interactions in these high-risk pregnancies in order to optimize neonatal immunity against respiratory pathogens such as influenza and SARS-CoV-2 in at-risk low birth weight infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The accurate segregation of chromosomes during cell division is fundamental to cellular and organismal fitness, illustrated by the findings that errors in this process occur in nearly all tumor cells and are the leading cause of miscarriages and congenital birth defects in humans. We propose to investigate two critical questions about this process, how are chromosomes correctly attached to the segregation machinery, and once they are, how do they maintain these attachments? Since defects in these processes have been implicated in human disease, this work will elucidate the molecular mechanisms that mediate proper attachments and will help determine to what extent these defects lead to human diseases such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), or chronic lung disease of prematurity, is the most consequential complication of preterm birth and is strong predictor of childhood pulmonary and neurodevelopmental disability, particularly in infants diagnosed with grade 3 BPD (ventilator dependence at 36 weeks’ postmenstrual age), the most severe disease form. In this proposal, we outline our plan to (1) generate the first empirically defined phenotype classification system for grade 3 BPD developed using a rich array of objective and quantitative cardiopulmonary diagnostic, clinical, and biological data; and (2) define the association between phenotype subgroups and neurodevelopmental and respiratory outcomes through 2 years’ corrected age. Successful completion of this research will promote a long-overdue frameshift in neonatal medicine towards objective disease classification in BPD using evidence-based diagnostic testing and performance of first-of-their-kind phenotype-specific trials targeting more effective individualized care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed research is highly relevant to public health because the discovery of an efficacious approach, and the associated underlying mechanism, to improve adherence to blood pressure-lowering medications is expected to represent an important step toward improving blood pressure control, reduce disease and disability, and improve quality of life in older adults. Thus, the proposed research, which evaluates a novel method to improve adherence and blood pressure control, aligns with top research priorities of the NHLBI and NIH Adherence Research Network that pertain to advancing knowledge that will help to reduce the burden of chronic diseases and improve life-long health and well-being. When this innovative behavioral intervention trial is complete, it is expected to provide a new and scalable evidence-based approach to reducing low medication adherence and CVD burden and to improving healthy aging among older women and men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with Alzheimer's Disease have disturbances of circadian rhythms, the 24-hour cycles that control bodily processes such as sleep and hormone secretion. We will investigate how Alzheimer's Disease changes the circadian rhythms in different cell types in the brain. Conversely, we will determine how disruption of the circadian system in different cells of the brain causes inflammation and toxic protein accumulation in mouse models of Alzheimer's Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Adipocytes are central regulators of metabolic function and dysfunction. We have recently identified several subpopulations of human white adipocytes using single nucleus RNA-seq, although we still know little about how they develop, what their functions are, and where they reside in the fat pad. The studies in this proposal will address these issues using state-of-the-art multi-omic technologies, and will allow us to model specific subpopulations in vitro, enabling further downstream studies. Finally, we will build and populate a Human Adipose Tissue Knowledge Portal to disseminate our findings and those of other groups to the community at large.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to human health because it will provide novel data supporting evidence-based recommendations to improve dietary practices for optimal cognitive function and achievement in childhood. Establishing the evidence base for nutrients that may have neurocognitive implications is particularly important given that the majority of children in the United States perpetually consume diets that fail to achieve their recommended servings of vegetables. Therefore, by furthering our understanding of nutrition for children’s cognitive function, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission to improve the health of the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The Midwest Consortium for Hazardous Waste Worker Training facilitates adult-based, action-oriented, results-centered worker and community training with the goal that participants will better recognize and avoid or control risks of occupational and environmental exposure to hazardous materials and waste in nine states: Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, North Dakota, Ohio, Tennessee, and Wisconsin. While all activities are performed under a cooperative agreement with the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, the training also leverages the resources of U.S. government agencies including the Environmental Protection Agency, Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Department of Homeland Security, National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, Department of Transportation, and Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board. Midwest Consortium training centers include labor-affiliated programs, three major universities, two community colleges, an historically black university, an affiliate of a national youth training organization, a tribal nation, and several other community-based organizations, all of which form partnerships locally and regionally to build capacity among trainees to recognize and react to hazardous substances in their workplaces and communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE No effective treatment exists for Angelman syndrome, a neurodevelopmental disorder caused by maternal allele deletions of the UBE3A gene. However, activation of the epigenetically-silenced paternal UBE3A allele in neurons offers an attractive therapeutic target. We have discovered a small molecule that can be administered peripherally to unsilence the dormant paternal UBE3A allele throughout the brain, and we propose to advance this small molecule towards a potentially transformative treatment for Angelman syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Scientists have been pinpointing tens of thousands of positions in the human genome which may influence disease. In order to apply this knowledge to improve treatment options and preventative medicine, however, we need to have a better understanding of how these regions function and where in the body they are active. This project is a predictive modeling component of the IGVF Consortium, which aims to systematically study the functional impact of genetic variants and their influence on human diseases and traits by developing and applying cutting-edge computational and statistical methods to predict the functional impacts of disease-associated genetic variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Microvascular dysfunction is a central pathogenic feature of chronic kidney disease, but routine assessment of renal microcirculation is difficult without a kidney biopsy. Whether non-invasive measurement of microvascular abnormalities can identify persons at risk for future loss of kidney function is unknown. The objectives of this proposal are to 1) understand how microvascular measurements are related to kidney histology, 2) investigate clinical determinants of microvascular dysfunction in kidney disease patients, 3) determine whether microvascular dysfunction is associated with kidney disease progression over time and 4) evaluate whether non-invasive microvascular measurements can determine renal function reserve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This pilot project will demonstrate the feasibility, acceptability, fidelity, and preliminary indicators of effectiveness of a positive, recovery-focused model of post-acute community-based rehabilitation for people living with psychosis in resource-limited settings, laying the groundwork for further effectiveness and scale-up research. The adaptation of the community-based rehabilitation model for this population will be grounded in the perspectives of people with lived experience along with their caregivers, community leaders, and other key stakeholders. This work will provide a critical advance toward establishing the evidence base for community- based treatment models for community-dwelling people with psychosis to enhance rehabilitation, functioning, quality of life, and recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The goal of this proposal is to characterize mechanisms by which methamphetamine (meth) increases uninfected and HIV infected CD14+CD16+ monocyte transmigration across the BBB to CXCL12, increasing perivascular and parenchymal macrophage accumulation in the CNS of PWH with meth use disorder. There is increased prevalence of HIV associated neurocognitive disorders or impairment (HAND, HIV-NCI) in people with HIV (PWH) greatly impacting their quality of life. A significant number of people with meth use disorder are PWH, with increased neurocognitive impairments reported in active meth using PWH. The mechanisms by which meth use disorder increases HIV-NCI in PWH on antiretroviral therapy are not completely characterized, impeding the development of interventional strategies to reduce/ eliminate HIV-NCI.in this population. The role of CXCR7 and/or CXCR4 in these meth mediated effects is the focus of this proposal. We hypothesize that CXCR7 and/or CXCR4 contribute to meth mediated increases in CXCL12 induced uninfected and HIV infected CD14+CD16+ monocyte transmigration,Thus, CXCR7 may be a therapeutic target for HIV-NCI treatment in PWH with meth use disorder. We will use our in vitro human BBB model to characterize the role of CXCR7 and/or CXCR4 in meth mediated effects on transmigration and on cells of the BBB. We will determine effects of meth on CXCR7 and/or CXCR4 expression, and on CXCL12 induced signaling, adhesion, and chemotaxis in uninfected/HIV infected CD14+CD16+ monocytes. The in vivo effects of meth on monocyte influx into the infected CNS will be examined in CNS tissue sections from meth treated SIV infected macaques by immunohistochemical analyses of BBB expression of CXCL12, and perivascular and parenchymal accumulation of CXCR7 and/or CXCR4 expressing monocytes/macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To make informed surgical treatment decisions, older adults and the providers who care for them must weigh the long-term benefits of surgery against the short-term health risks for an individual patient. However, counseling on the tradeoffs of surgical intervention too often rely on population average risk rather than individualized estimates of risks/benefits. This research will create decision support for the management of primary hyperparathyroidism in older adults and, in doing so, establish a framework for how to combine individualized risk prediction with stakeholder feedback to develop surgical decision support that will inform treatment recommendations for older adults and reduce long-term morbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Trauma is a major public health crisis worldwide, and the number one leading cause of death from age 1 to 46. Neutrophils play a crucial pathological role in posttraumatic inflammatory response. Importantly, dysregulation of neutrophil responses and function due to pre-existent metabolic syndrome and associated metainflammation, contribute to increased susceptibility to develop posttraumatic complications in high-risk groups. Therefore, the goal of this work is to determine the mechanisms governing neutrophil responses in polytrauma in healthy and metainflammation conditions.

PHR: Project Narrative Early Communication in Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC) and its Prediction of Autism will determine how key aspects of language development (early vocal development, fast-mapping, vocabulary development and shared attention) predict language outcome and autism severity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Heightened experience of negative emotions, especially anxiety, are common in schizophrenia and cause significant distress and impairment; yet little is known about the underlying causes. This study will determine whether individuals with schizophrenia have alterations in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST), a brain region that mediates anxiety in rodents, but is largely understudied in schizophrenia. Such knowledge is critical for identifying novel brain targets and guiding the development of new interventions to treat schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: This project addresses the critical need for a standardized platform which improves understanding of the placental barrier and enables prediction of transplacental drug transport. This study combines modeling approaches to create a whole picture of maternal and fetal exposure to drugs taken by a pregnant woman. These studies will aide in the safe and effective treatment of the medical needs of pregnant women, enabling the provision of guidelines for prescription of medications and open up the possibility of therapeutically treating fetuses by maternal administration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Increasing evidence implicates cellular metabolism as a key regulator of cell fate and function, however, little is known about how changes in cellular metabolism impact complex, high-energy demand processes such as skeletal regeneration. In this project we will test the influence of cellular metabolism on the regenerative process and its role in regenerative decline. Our results will provide valuable insight into the mechanisms that promote skeletal regeneration and will offer new insight into therapeutic targets to promote bone formation and healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Weight bias internalization (WBI) has been associated with a number of negative physical and mental health consequences for adolescents with obesity, including negative weight-related outcomes. This study will develop, adapt, and pilot test a combined treatment for WBI and behavioral weight control for adolescents, designed to improve WBI and mechanisms of weight stigma induced weight gain including biological markers of stress and inflammation, and dysregulated eating behaviors. Addressing WBI as a particularly salient and impactful psychosocial stressor could improve behavioral weight control outcomes and improve physical and psychological stress for adolescents with obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC NARRATIVE. Psychosocial clinical interventions are the preferred mode of treatment for most people seeking care for mental health problems – particularly among people of color and those living in poverty in both rural and urban communities – but very few people have access to them because of the problems with usability, contextual fit, and engagement experienced when those interventions and the implementation strategies designed to support their use are deployed in accessible settings like primary care medicine and schools. The UW ALACRITY Center will address these issues by advancing its novel framework for redesigning clinical interventions and implementation strategies, drawing from the fields of human-centered design and implementation science. Across projects, the UW ALACRITY team will work with local practitioners and other stakeholders to develop and test four new solutions for addressing problems in the usability, contextual fit, and engagement of clinical interventions and implementation strategies in primary care and schools and will support additional pilot studies over the 5-year timeline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We seek to understand how metabolic networks connect with the development of antimicrobial resistance. The collaboration of a highly complementary group of investigators with expertise in metabolic network modeling, bacterial physiology, and infectious disease will support the proposed studies. The proposed experiments and computational modeling will lead to greater understanding of the development of antimicrobial resistance and thus catalyze the development of new therapeutic strategies to tackle this important clinical challenge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Depression of breathing from opioids, often in combination with other sedative drugs, has become a major public health problem. We have identified the areas within the breathing center in the brainstem that are most affected by these drugs. This study proposes to use a rabbit model to determine which drugs are best suited to stimulate these areas, and how completely this stimulation can offset the decrease in breathing caused by opioids and other drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The vast majority of patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (CRC) cannot be cured, mainly due to a lack of understanding and therapeutics to target the underlying metastatic process. A significant barrier for metastasis research is recapitulating the complex biology in a suitable model system. This proposal aims to utilize state-of- the-art CRC organoids and orthotopic mouse models to understand the CRC metastatic process better, informing future research into therapeutics to improve the survival and quality of life for individuals with CRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) are significant contributors to age-related dementia and a major economic burden. These diseases result, at least in part, by the abnormal accumulation of toxic proteins in the brain and harnessing the power of our immune system has significant potential to enhance their removal, reducing, or even preventing, cognitive decline. Here we focus on a largely neglected population of immune cells situated in the borders surrounding the brain and explore how these cells communicate with other central nervous system clearance routes, particularly the meningeal lymphatics that drain the cerebrospinal fluid, to facilitate the removal of these toxic proteins, thus highlighting a novel therapeutic target for AD and CAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed basic research project is relevant to public health because it aims to elucidate the role of interorgan crosstalk in the development of a wide variety of concurring immunometabolic pathologies. By employing advanced models of human multiorgan physiology, we are investigating how migratory immune cells, namely MR1-restricted lymphocytes, inform the origins and progression of inflammatory diseases that span multiple organ systems such as the gut-liver axis. Gained fundamental knowledge will be used to identify tangible targets for disease prevention and amelioration across a range of different pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammasomes have been implicated in the detection and clearance of a variety of bacterial pathogens, but little is known about whether there is active cross-talk between the host sensing mechanism and the expression of stimulatory ligands by the pathogen. In this proposal we will investigate a host cell-intrinsic innate regulatory circuit involving NLRC4 inflammasome activity, lipid biosynthesis and type 1 interferons that regulates the temporal switch of Salmonella from a flagellin-high to a flagellin-low phenotype inside macrophages. Our investigations will identify how NLRC4 inflammasome activity modulates temporal and biphasic expression of its own microbial ligand, and reveal a host mechanism that has been has adapted by Salmonella for flagellin downregulation and immune escape inside macrophages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Comprehensive-Tele-Harm Reduction (C-THR) seeks to engage people who inject drugs (PWID) into comprehensive HIV prevention services by deconstructing the traditional healthcare system and leveraging syringe services programs as trusted venues to deliver telehealth-enhanced access to PrEP, medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD), hepatitis C (HCV) cure, and treatment for bacterial and sexually transmitted infections. We urgently need a strong evidence base to prove that Comprehensive-Tele-Harm Reduction can help us prevent HIV and save lives. We seek to set the foundation to build, implement, and scale-up a new standard of care for comprehensive HIV prevention and treatment in PWID.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence is mounting that inappropriate timing of food intake contributes to obesity. The proposed research use gold-standard methods of characterizing circadian rhythm in humans to examine the metabolic impacts of food timing relative to endogenous circadian rhythm. Our study will lay the foundation for novel, circadian-based meal timing as a precision medicine approach to obesity and metabolic dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE With obesity and diabetes affecting a large percentage of the US population and the increased occurrence of associated pain states; studies on pain, diet, diabetes, and inflammation are critical. The objective of the proposed experiments is to understand if direct activation of sensory neurons or adjacent macrophages is the culprit in TLR4-specific diabetic neuropathic pain development. The results of the studies will resolve a highly contended theory in the field and undoubtedly lead to a paradigm shift to our approach on therapeutics for diet- induced and diabetic neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Assessing wounds from a subclinical physiological perspective is a novel addition to smartphone-based technologies that augment mobile health (mHealth) point-of-care wound management, potentially predicting serious complications early on, and triage diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) with high-risk lesions for clinical care. In addition, the development and validation of a smartphone-based optical device that performs physiological imaging (based on oxygen to wounds) apart from visual imaging across any skin tone and foot curvatures make the technology applicable across different racial/ethnic groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a chronic condition that can lead to heart attacks. The currently unknown impact of OSA on the coronary arteries of the heart in female and obese OSA patients and the contribution of mineralocorticoid receptor activation, which is known to cause cardiovascular disease, will be characterized using a mouse model of sleep apnea. This will permit development of treatments for OSA patients to prevent coronary heart disease

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Babesia species are thick-borne intracellular parasites that infect the red blood cells of their mammalian host, causing severe to fatal diseases called babesiosis. Novel and effective drugs against Babesia parasites are needed, given its increasing worldwide distribution and the lack of a vaccine to treat this illness. This proposal aims to determine the structure of apicoplast ribosomes from B. divergens.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE The Centers of Excellence in Regulatory Science and Innovation (CERSI) program allows the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to form extramural partnerships that foster robust and innovative research to develop new tools, standards, and approaches to assess the safety, efficacy, quality, and performance of FDA- regulated products, supporting regulatory decision-making and the overall mission of the FDA. Over the past seven years, the Yale-Mayo Clinic CERSI has pursued a series of innovative research projects that leverage real-world data sources to assess the safety, efficacy, quality, and performance of FDA-regulated products, informing regulatory decision-making as well as manufacturers, clinicians, and patients in support of optimizing patient-centered care, along with providing and supporting high-quality mentorship and training in regulatory science. The Yale-Mayo Clinic CERSI will continue this work, conducting high-quality, high-impact regulatory science research in priority areas identified by the FDA to modernize development and evaluation of FDA- regulated products, strengthen post-market surveillance and labelling of FDA-regulated products, and invigorate public health preparedness and response of FDA, patients, and consumers.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Yale-Mayo Clinic FDA Center of Excellence in Regulatory Science and Innovation (CERSI)

The findings will be used to design understand the development of immunity to facilitate the design of more effective vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative It has never been more important to create and maintain a cadre of PhD and physician-scientists engaged in translational research in lung disease and critical illness. Given the unprecedented developments at the cellular and molecular level, including knowledge of the human genome, we are now poised for unprecedented progress in translation of this new knowledge base to the study of the pathophysiology, prevention and treatment of human disease. Investment and innovation in the training and career development of this class of new investigators is greatly needed and will prepare future researchers for the unique challenges associated with advancing science and public health in the realm of pulmonary and critical care medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The current proposal exploits foundations of neuroscience to advance our understanding, through the perspective of the neural microenvironment the development of one of the most common and deadliest childhood brain tumors: medulloblastoma (MB)-- interplay which remains poorly understood and studied. We hypothesize that medulloblastoma will exploit an enzyme called ABAT used to breakdown the neurotransmitter GABA, one of the most abundant molecules in their microenvironment, for growth and spread. These studies will have potential near-term impact on understanding how the pediatric brain tumor MB is formed and uncover ABAT overexpressing tumor cells as a target to treat MB metastasis – the principal reason for MB-induced mortality.
